name_variants: Katok Dorjeden; gatuo si, kaHthog rdo rje gdan, 噶陀寺; 呷拖寺
description: Katok is a major Nyingma monastery in Derge that was founded in 1159 by Dampa Deshek. Said to be the oldest Nyingma monastery, it is known for its preservation of the Kama, or Spoken Word, tradition.

name_variants: Orgyen Mindroling; minzhulin si; minzhuolin si, smin grol gling; o rgyan smin grol gling; 'og min o rgyan smin grol gling, 敏珠林寺; 敏卓林寺
description: Mindroling, one of the six Nyingma "mother" monasteries, was founded in 1676 by Terdak Lingpa Gyurme Dorje and his brother Lochen Dharmaśrī, with the sponsorship of the Fifth Dalai Lama. Located in Drapchi (grwa phyi) in Dranang county, it was destroyed in 1717 during the Dzungar invasion and rebuilt soon after by Terdak Lingpa's daughter Mingyur Peldron with the support of Polhane. It continues to be controlled by the Nyo clan to which Terdak Lingpa belonged. Mindroling is headed by the Minling Trichen and the Minling Khenchen. Traditionally the two are brothers, direct descendents of Terdak Lingpa; the Trichen being a layman and father of the next generation, and the Khenchen being ordained, responsible for maintaining observance of the Vinaya.

name_variants: Ewam Chokgar; Jang Dorje Drak; Tubten Dorje Drak Ewam Chokgar; , thub bstan rdo rje brag e waM lcog sgar ,
description: Dorje Drak is a Nyingma monastery on the bank of the Tsangpo river in central Tibet associated with the Northern Treasures tradition. Ngari Panchen Pema Wanggyel stayed there in1540s, at the time it was known as Evaṁ Chokgar. It relocated to its present location in 1632 under the leadership of the Third Dorje Drak Rigdzin Ngakgi Wangpo. The monastery was sacked by the Dzungar army in 1717 and later restored. It is considered one of the six Mother monasteries of the Nyingma tradition.

name_variants: Dzogchen; Derge Dzogchen; Orgyen Samten Choling; Urgyen Samten Choling; Rudam Orgyen Samten Choling; zhuqing si, ru dam o rgyan bsam gtan chos gling, 竹庆寺
description: Dzogchen is one of the six most important Nyingma monasteries of Tibet. It was established in 1685 in Derge area on the orders of the Fifth Dalai Lama who sent the First Dzogchen Drubwang Pema Rigdzin to spread Buddhism in Kham. Sanggye Tenpa, the third abbot of Derge's royal monastery, Lhundrubteng, was a major sponsor. Famous for its Śrī Siṃha College, it was largely destroyed in the twentieth century but has since been rebuilt. It is the seat of the Dzogchen Drubwang, Dzogchen Ponlop, Dzogchen Kongtrul and Dzogchen Khyentse incarnation lines.

name_variants: Zhechen; Shechen Tennyi Dargyeling; Zhechen Monastery; Shechen Gon; xieqing si, 协庆寺
description: Shechen, one of the six Mother monasteries of the Nyingma tradition, was founded by the Second Shechen Rabjam, Gyurme Kunzang Namgyel, in 1734 or 1735. It is located north of Dzogchen monastery in the Derge region of Kham. According to one monastic history (khams phyogs dkar mdzes khul gyi dgon sde so so'i lo rgyus), in 1690 at the age of forty-one, the First Shechen, Rabjam Tenpai Gyeltsen, founded a monastery named Shechen Orgyen Chodzong, consisting of a monks quarters and main assembly hall, not far from Dzogchen. The Second Shechen Rabjam established an extension across from the original site that grew into the Shechen known today.

name_variants: Pelyul Monastery; Payul; Palyul Gonpa Namgyal Jangchubling; baiyu si, dpal yul dgon; rnam rgyal byang chub gling; dpal yul rnam rgyal byang chub gling; dpal yul rnam rgyal byang chub chos gling; rnam rgyal rtse sngar yod dgon chung;, 白玉寺
description: Pelyul Namgyel Jangchub Ling, one of the six mother-monasteries of the Nyingma tradition, was established in southern Derge in 1665 by Rigdzin Kunzang Sherab under the sponsorship of the Derge Gonchen abbot Lachen Jampa Puntsok.

name_variants: Sekhar Guthok, 塞卡尔古陀寺; 色喀古陀寺
description: Sekhar Gutok is a small monastery in Lhodrak built around a nine-story tower in that Milarepa is said to have built as an act of penance for his teacher Marpa. Once the seat of the Pawo incarnation line, it was converted to the Geluk tradition in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Zung Trezhing; Zhuntrelzhing; xiong zhixing si, 雄直兴寺
description: Zhung Treuzhing, a Kagyu monastery located in Gongkar county, was founded by Ngok Kunga Dorje in the twelfth century near the site of a hermitage visited by his uncle, Ngok Choku Dorje, a disciple of Marpa Chokyi Lodro. It is said that Marpa's skull was located within a stupa at this monastery, which was the seat of lamas in the Ngok lineage.

name_variants: Ngor Monastery; e-er si; aiwang quedan si, 俄尔寺; 艾旺却丹寺
description:
Ngor Ewaṃ Choden near Shigatse in Tsang was founded in 1429 by Ngorchen Kunga Zangpo. Ngor is part of the Sakya tradition, following the same doctrinal and ritual tradition, but it maintains administrative independence from Sakya Monastery. The monastery is divided into four monastic estates from which its leadership is drawn: Luding, Khangsar, Tartse, and Pende. 

Note: tenure dates are drawn from Heimbel 2017. Some dates are provisional.

name_variants: Dar Drangmoche Chokhor Yangtse, dar grang mo che; mdar grang mo che; 'dar grang mo che chos 'khor yang rtse ,
description: Dar Drangmoche Monastery, in Lhartse, Tsang, was founded in the mid-sixteenth century by Tsarchen Losel Gyatso, the founder of the Tsarpa branch of the Sakya tradition.

name_variants: Shalu; xialu si, 夏鲁寺
description: Zhalu Monastery in Tsang is one of the oldest monasteries in Tibet. The Serkhang Tramo temple was built originally in 1027 by Chetsun Sherab Jungne of the Che clan, and located close to the Gyengong Lhakhang, built in 997 by Loton Dorje Wangchuk. Buton Rinchen Drub established the Ripuk hermitage in caves above the monastery and retired there. Zhalu is loosely associated with the Sakya school, maintaining its own tradition based on the Sakya and Kadam teachings of Buton.

name_variants: Ganden Monastery; Ganden Namgyel Ling; Riwo Ganden; gandan si, dga' ldan; ri bo dga' ldan dgon; 'brog ri bo dge ldan rnam par rgyal ba'i gling ,
description: Ganden Monastery was founded in 1409 by Tsongkhapa Lobzang Drakpa outside of Lhasa. Its abbot, the Ganden Tripa, is the nominal head of the Geluk tradition. Along with Sera and Drepung, it is one of the three Geluk monastic universities of central Tibet. Its two main colleges, Jangtse and Shartse, were founded by two of Tsongkhapa's disciples, Namkha Pelzangpo and Neten Rongyelwa. The tantric college of Gyudra was established by another student, Sherab Sengge.

name_variants: Sera Tekchenling; Sera Thekchenling; Sera Monastery
description: Sera Tekchen Ling is one of the three main Geluk monasteries in Lhasa. It was founded in 1419 by Jamchen Choje Shakya Yeshe, a disciple of Tsongkhapa. Three monastic colleges survive: Sera Me, Sera Je, and the Ngakpa Dratsang. Above the monastery are a number of important hermitages established by Tsongkhapa and other Geluk masters. These include Sera Utse, Pabongkha, and Purbuchok.

Drepung is one of the three major Geluk monasteries of Lhasa. It was founded in 1416 by Jamyang Choje Tashi Pelden, a disciple of Tsongkhapa.  It contains the Ganden Podrang residence which served as the seat of the Dalai Lamas until the seventeenth century. The entire monastery was initially administered from the office of the Drepung Throne holder; since the time of the Fifth Dalai Lama the custom has been that the senior abbot of the two principle colleges, Gomang or Loseling, has served as head of Drepung. Of the seven colleges that were once part of the monastery, only four survive, the two others being the Ngakpa Dratsang and Deyang.

name_variants: Tashi Lhunpo; zhaxi lunbu si, gtsang bkra shis lhun po dpal gyi sde chen; phyogs thams cad las rnam par rgyal ba'i gling, 扎什伦布寺; 吉祥须弥寺
description: Tashilhunpo, one of Tibet's most important monasteries, is a Geluk monastery in Shigatse that was founded in 1447 by the First Dalai Lama Gendun Drub, whose remains are interred at the site. The location of the monastery is west of the great fortress and above a pre-existing sky-burial site.The monastery serves as the seat of the Paṇchen Lama incarnation line. The remains of the Second, Third, and Fourth Pachen Lama, who was tutor to the Fifth Dalai Lama, are also preserved in a stupa at Tashilhunpo. Reliquaries for the Fifth through Ninth Panchen Lamas were destroyed in the 1960s. The Tenth Panchen Lama was responsible for the construction of a new mausoleum, Dungten Tashi Namgyel, where the remains of his previous incarnations were re-interred. The Jamkhang Chenmo, which was added during the tenure of the Ninth Paṇchen Lama, contains the world's largest gilded copper image that stands 26 meters tall. At its height, Tashilunpo housed close to 5,000 monks.

name_variants: Kumbum Jampaling; ta-er si; Tǎ'ěrsì, 塔尔寺; 塔儿寺; 衮本贤巴林
description: Kumbum Jampa Ling is a major Geluk monastery in Amdo built on the site of Tsongkhapa's birth. The monastery was built around the tree that marked this site. Construction began in 1560 by a monk named Rinchen Tsondru Gyeltsen around a stupa that Tsongkhapa's mother is said to have built in 1379. In 1583 the Third Dalai Lama, Sonam Gyatso, stayed there and requested the monk to expand it. Over the subsequent centuries, the monastic complex developed and expanded into one of Tibet's great monasteries. The Cheso, Ngago and Taktser incarnation lines all have seats there. Kumbum has four colleges: the Tantric College, which was built by Choje Lekpa Gyatso in 1649; the Debate College, built in 1612 by Duldzin Ozer Gyatso; the Medical College, which opened in 1725; and the Kālacakra College, established in 1820.  The monastery has been sacked and rebuilt several times in its history.

name_variants: bla brang bkra shis 'khyil; dga' ldan bshad sgrub dar rgyas bkra shis g.yas su 'khyil ba'i gling; lapuleng si, 拉卜楞寺
description: Labrang Tashikhyil is a major Geluk monastery in Amdo. It was founded in 1709 by the First Jamyang Zhepa, Jamyang Zhepai Dorje under the sponsorship of a prince of the Qoshot Mongols, who donated the land and paid for the construction. Many incarnation lines have their seats at Labrang Monastery including the Jamyang Zhepa, Amdo Zhamar and Gungtang incarnation lines. Labrang has six colleges, the largest of which is the debate college, Mejung Tosam Ling, which was established by the First Jamyang Zhepa when he built the monastery. The Tantric College has two branches, the Lower, established by Jamyang Zhepa in 1719, and the Upper, established in 1943 by the Fifth Jamyang Zhepa. The Second Jamyang Zhepa built the Kālacakra College in 1763 and the Medical College in 1784. The Fourth Jamyang Zhepa established the Hevajra College in 1879.

name_variants: Anzom; Anzom Chogar; Osel Tekchok Ling; Osal Tegchogling, od gsal theg mchog gling,
description: Adzom Gar is a Nyingma monastery in the Tromtar region of Kham that was founded by the First Adzom Drukpa, Drondul Pawo Dorje in 1842. A branch of Katok Monastery, it is the seat of the Adzom Drukpa incarnation line.

wylie_name: smyo shul ljon pa lung dgon
name_variants: liaoxi si; liaoxi yuanlin, 辽西圆林; 辽西寺,
description: Nyoshul Jonpalung is a Nyingma monastery in Kham in the Dzin Valley of Tromtar, in present-day Pelyul county in Sichuan province. It was founded by Khenpo Ngaga in 1910. It is considered a branch of Katok.

name_variants: Zhai Lhakhang; Zhwai Lhakhang; Zhva Lhakhang; Zhwa Lhakhang; xia lakang; xiang lakang si, 霞拉康; 香拉康寺
description: The Zha Lhakhang, a small temple north of Lhasa, was constructed by Nyang Tingdzin Zangpo around the late eighth century or early ninth century on land given to him by Tride Songtsen. According to legend, Vimalamitra concealed Dzogchen teachings there which were then discovered by Dangma Lungyal in the eleventh century. Zha Lhakang was converted from Nyingma to Drigung Kagyu, and later to Geluk. It is currently affiliated with Sera Je.

name_variants: Drubchen Gon; Tsangchen Ngodrub Pelbar Ling; Dodrub Tsangchen Ngodrub Pelbar Ling, rtsang chen dngos grub dpal 'bar gling; rdo grub dgon gsang chen dngos grub dpal 'bar gling ,
description: Dodrubchen is a Nyingma monastery in Golok. Properly known as Tsangchen Ngodrub Pelbar Ling, it was founded by the First Dodrubchen Jigme Trinle Ozer in 1810 in Serta. In 1880, the Second Dodrubchen Jigme Phuntsok Jungne relocated the monastery to its present location. Previously, a tent camp monastery had been founded there in 1527 and subsequently destroyed by fire.

name_variants: Drathang; Dranang, Drathang; Dranang; gra nang, Drathang; Dranang
description: Dratang Monastery was established as a Kadam institution in 1081 in the Dranang valley in U by Drapa Ngonshe. The monastery, which was later absorbed by the Sakya tradition in the fourteenth of fifteenth century, was damaged by the Dzungar armies in the eighteenth century. It was rennovated in the 1920s and 1930s with sponsorship of the Fifth Reting Rinpoche.
Neten Monastery, a Nyingma monastery in Nangchen, was founded in 1858 by Chokgyur Lingpa. It is the seat of the Neten Chokling incarnation line.

name_variants: , rtsi ske nor bu gling; rtsi ke nor bu gling, 纳唐寺; 那唐寺
description: Tsike, a Nyingma monastery in Chamdo, was founded by Chokgyur Lingpa in the mid nineteenth century. It is the seat of the Tsike Chokling, also known as the Kela Chokling.

name_variants: narthang; natang si,
description: Nartang is a Kadampa monastery that was founded in 1153 in Tsang by Tumton Lodro Drakpa. It was renowned for its printing press and extensive library of wood-blocks. It was made a branch of Tashilhunpo Monastery in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: dala gangbu si, ri bo shAn ti, 达拉岗布寺
description: Daklha Gampo is a Kagyu monastery that was founded in 1121 by Milarepa's disciple Gampopa Sonam Rinchen, also known as Dakpo Lhaje. An early seat of the Kagyu tradition, administration was first passed through successive generations of Gampopa's family and then through an incarnation line, beginning in the sixteenth century with Gampopa Tashi Namgyel. The site was previously sanctified by Songsten Gampo, as it is considered to be at the head of the mother-ogress, the mythological progenitrix of the Tibetan people. Consequently the location has been an important site of terma revelation. Though sacked by Dzungars in 1718, and again damaged during the cultural revolution, several chapels with original art remain.

name_variants: Pakdru Densatil; Ngomsho Pakmo Drupai Densatil; , gdan sa thel; ngom shod phag mo gru pa'i gdan sa thel ,
description: Densatil is a Kagyu monastery that was founded in 1158 by Pakmodrupa Dorje Gyelpo to the east of Tsetang. As one of the seats of the Pakmodru Dynasty in the fourteenth century, the monastery acquired great wealth and included multiple spectacularly ornamented reliquary stupas.

name_variants: chaopu si; chuopu si, khro phu byams chen chos sde, 超浦寺; 绰浦寺
description: Tropu Jamchen Chode was founded in 1212 by Gyeltsa Rinchen Gonpo in Shab valley in Tsang. Expanded by his nephew Tropu Lotsāwa Jampa Pel, it is the seat of the Tropu Kagyu tradition..

name_variants: Tsal Gungtang, gung thang chos sde ,
description: Tsel Gungtang, to the south of Lhasa, was founded in the twelfth century by Zhang Yudrakpa Tsundru Drakpa, also known as Lama Zhang. Lhazang Khan offered Tsel Gungtang to the Fiftieth Ganden Tripa, Gendun Puntsok. Gendun Puntsok, who later became known as Tri Gungtangpa, converted the Tselpa Kagyu monastery to the Geluk tradition.

name_variants: Barom Riwoche; Riwoche, ba' rom ri bo che; ri bo che ,
description: Barom Riwoche Monastery was established in 1160 in Nakchu, Kham, by Barompa Darma Wangchuk, one of Gampopa's disciples, and founder of the Barom Kagyu tradition.

name_variants: , sna phu chos lung dgon; snang phu chos lung dgon ,
description: Napu Monastery is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery near Dorje Drak. It was founded in the twelfth century by Lingrepa Pema Dorje, a student of Pakmodrupa and teacher of Tsangpa Gyare, the founder of the Drukpa Kagyu tradition. It functioned as a nunnery during the time when Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo visited. In the 1960's its buildings were destroyed, with some reconstruction in the 1990's.
Lhachuk was a small Tselpa Kagyu monastery in central Tibet. It was founded by Lhachuk Kharwa Nyida O in 1193, and remained an important center until at least the fifteenth century.

name_variants: Juphu
description: Jupu, a Tselpa Kagyu monastery, was founded in 1187 by Lhachuk Kharwa Nyida O, one of the four main disciples of Lama Zhang Yudrakpa.
Rokam was a Tselpa Kagyu monastery that was founded in 1183 by Rokam Nyima Sherab.

name_variants: Taklung Tang; Taklung Gonchen, 达龙寺
description: Taklung Monastery, located in Jang north of Lhasa, is the main seat of the Taklung Kagyu tradition. It was founded by Taklungtangpa Tashi Pel in 1180 on a site where Lama Potowa had practiced with disciples in the eleventh century.

name_variants: Til Monastery; Drigung Monastery; Drigung Til Monastery
description: Drigung Til was founded in 1179 by Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel in the area where Lama Menyak Gomring had built a hermitage. Drigung Til is the seat of the Drigung Kagyu tradition. It was controlled the by Kyura clan, to which Jikten Gonpo belonged, until the seventeenth century, when leadership transfered to two incarnation lines: the Drigung Chetsang and the Drigung Chungtsang.

name_variants: Shukseb Gon; xiuse si; xiongse si, snye phu shug gseb dgon, 休色寺; 雄色寺
description: Shukseb was originally founded by Gyergom Tsultrim Sengge as a Shukseb Kagyu monastery near Lhasa in 1181. It was at some point taken over by the Geluk school but later grew into a signigicant nunnery focused on Nyingma and Kagyu teachings through the efforts of Jetsun Choying Zangmo, a female adept who settled at Shukseb in the early twentieth century. Shuksheb Nunnery has been re-established in exile near Dharamsala in northern India.

name_variants: relong si, 热龙寺; 热隆寺
description: Ralung, located in Gyantse in Tsang, was founded in 1180 by Tsangpa Gyare. It was the principal seat of the Middle Drukpa Kagyu tradition in Tibet, and was controlled by the Gya clan until the family line died out in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Jomonang, jo mo nang; jo nang rgyal ba'i ri khrod, 觉囊寺; 觉朗寺; 觉朗通卓钦摩大佛塔
description: Jonang Monastery is known as the birthplace of the Jonang tradition. The original foundation was laid by Kunpang Tukje Tsondru, traditionally said to have occurred in 1294. However, few people stayed at the monastery following Kunpang's time; the Jonang tradition as it is known today began in earnest nearby, at the Richo Chenmo, the Great Mountain Hermitage, where Dolpopa Sherab Gyeltsen, one of the most important Buddhist masters in Tibetan history and the most important figures connected with the Jonang, built a magnificent stūpa in 1333. This was the seat of Jonang activity until Tāranātha, who held the abbot chair from 1588 until at least the 1620s, built a new seat at Takden Puntsok Ling. Associated hermitages are Kyipuk Deden and Khacho Deden.

name_variants: Sangphu Neutok; sangpu si, 桑普寺
description: Sangpu Neutok is an important monastery in central Tibet, just south of Lhasa, that was founded in 1072 by Ngok Lekpai Sherab, a disciple of Atiśa, and developed by his nephew, Ngok Lotsāwa Loden Sherab. Originally a Kadam monastery with two colleges, it evolved into a monastery that includes both Sakya and Geluk traditions.

wylie_name: snye thang sgrol ma lha khang
name_variants: nietang zhuoma lakang,
description: Nyetang Drolma Lhakhang, to the southwest of Lhasa, was founded as a Kadam monastery in 1055, a year after the Bengali master Atisha passed away in Nyetang. It currently houses several of Atisha's personal relics, including his begging bowl.

name_variants: Shambu Tsegu; zijin si, thub bstan rab rgyas gling, 紫金寺
description: Tsechen Chode Tubten Rabgye Ling is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet. Founded in 1366 by Nyawon Kunga Pel with the sponsorship of Gyantse's first prince Pakpa Pelzangpo, it served as the residence of the kings of Gyantse until the early fifteenth century. It was a major site of Jonang monastic education, and also connected to the Sakya tradition. Tsechen was converted to the Geluk tradition in the mid-seventeenth century. It was destroyed by the English during the Younghusband expedition, and later minimally restored. It is currently active but many ruins remain.

name_variants: Tsurphu; Okmin Tsurpu, mtshur mdo bo lung dgon; 'og min mtshur phu, 祖普寺
description: Tsurpu is a Kagyu monastery located in to Tolung Valley in central Tibet. It was founded in 1189 by the First Karmapa, Dusum Khyenpa, and is the seat of both the Karma Kagyu tradition and the Karmapa incarnation line.

name_variants: Dragram
description: Drakram Monastery was a Jonang institution in Tsang. It was in existence by at least the early fourteenth century when Chokle Namgyel studied there.

Gharung Monastery was a Jonang monastery located in the present day Tibet Autonomous Region but not much is known about the site. The monastery was in existence by at least the 14th century when Gharungwa Lhai Gyeltsen (b.1319 - d.1401) ascended to its seat.
Palung appears to have been a small monastery, presumably Sakya, near Sakya Monastery. Gorumpa Kunga Lekpa was born there in 1477.

name_variants: bokang si; bokang cuoba, spos khang tshogs pa, 波康寺; 波康措巴
description: Pokhang is a Geluk monastery in Panam, Tsang. It was originally founded as a Kadampa monastery in 1213 by Jangchub Pelzangpo. It was converted to Geluk in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Pelkhor Dechen; Gyaltse Pelkhor Chode; Palkhor Chode; Gyangtse Monastery; baiju si; jiangzi baiju si, dpal 'khor bde chen; dpal chos dgon pa; rgyal rtse dgon pa; shel mkhar rgyal rtse'i chos sde, 白居寺; 江孜白居寺
description: Pelkhor Chode, also known as Pelkhor Dechen, in Gyantse, Tsang, was established by the Gyantse ruler Rabten Kunzang Pakpa, between 1418 and 1425 as an ecumenical center for Sakya and Geluk traditions. Khedrubje Gelek Pelzangpo and Ngorchen Kunga Zangpo were both involved. The Drukpa Kagyu tradition is also represented, although the community today is primarily Sakya.

name_variants: Zilung; tudeng saiduojin si; seduojian si, gzi lung; pan gser mdog can, 土登赛朵金寺; 色多坚寺
description: Serdokchen is a Sakya monastery near Shigatse in Tsang that was founded by Panchen Donyo Pel, also known as Donyo Drubpa or Amoghasiddhi, in 1475. Donyo Pel passed the monastery down to his student Panchen Śākya Chokden who renamed it Serdokchen and spent much of his life there. It was formerly called Zilung.
Chokhor Tse was in existence by at least 1531 when Kunga Pelzang received Lamdre teachings here from Paṇchen Dorje Gyeltsen. It seems to have been in U.

name_variants: Thubten Dargye Ling; Tudengdajilin si, 土登达吉林寺; 加桑卡乡土登达吉林寺
description: Tupten Dargye Ling is a Geluk monastery located in Kham that was in existence since at least the fifteenth century when the Third Ngor Khenchen, Jamyang Sherab Gyatso lived and taught there.
Puntsok Samten Ling, a Sakya monastery in Mustang, was in existence by at least the 16th century when Kunga Pelzang was installed on the monastic seat there in 1541.

Changlung Choding was a Jonang monastery in central Tibet that was in operation by at least 1531, when the twenty-fifth Abbot of Jonang Monastery, Kunga Pelzang, met the master Zhonnu Chodrub and received transmissions from him.

name_variants: Takten Damcho Ling Ngedon Gaway Tshal; Takten Phuntsok Ling; Ganden Phuntsok Ling, rtag brtan dam chos gling nges don dga' ba'i tshal; rtag brtan phun tshogs gling; dga' ldan phun tshogs gling ,
description: Takten Puntsok Ling was established by the Jonang master Tāranātha with support from kings of Tsang in 1619. It was the center of Jonang activity in Tibet until Tāranātha's death. It was converted to Geluk by order of the Tibetan government in 1650 and renamed Ganden Puntsok Ling. Within several years Jonang teachings were officially banned. As a Geluk institution it was affiliated with Tashilhunpo during the time of Seventh Dalai Lama.

name_variants: Tolung Chubzang Tupten Dargye Ling, stod lung chu bzang dgon thub bstan dar rgyas gling ,
description: Chubzang is a Geluk monastery that was founded in mid-fifteenth century in Tolung near Lhasa. The Thirty-Ninth Ganden Tripa, Konchok Chozang was possibly ordained there.

Kyangdur was a Sakya establishement in Tsang that was in existence by at least the thirteenth century, though likely an ancient establishment.  Sakya Paṇḍita Kunga Gyeltsen travelled to Kyangdur in 1204 to give funeral offerings for his recently deceased father.

name_variants: Pel Riwoche; Ewam Gakyil, gcung ri bo che dgon; e waM dga' 'khyil; dpal ri bo che dgon e waM dga' 'khyil ,
description: Chung Riwoche, a Nyingma monastery in central Tibet, was founded as a Shangpa Kagyu monastery in 1386. It was Tangtong Gyelpo's monastery and the seat of the Chaksampa incarnation lineage. It is the site of Tangtong Gyelpo's famous Chung Riwoche Kumbum.
Mending Monastery was founded in the sixteenth century by the Jonang Kālacakra master Lochen Ratnabhadra in the Jang district of U.

Menchu was founded by Ngok Lekpai Sherab in the eleventh century in Taktse, near Lhasa. Originally a Kadam hermitage, in the fourteenth century it was the seat of Menchukhawa Lodro Gyeltsen, a close disciple of Dolpopa. It was later converted to the Geluk tradition.

Cholung Jangtse was a Jonang monastery that was in existence by at least the middle of the sixteenth century when Kunga Drolchok was abbot there. Tāranātha was brought there to be formally recognized as Kunga Drolchok's reincarnation. One of the largest Jonang monasteries of central Tibet, it was converted to Geluk in the mid-seventeenth century.

name_variants: naining si, gnas snying dgon pa ,
description: Nenying is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet. It was first established in the eighth century, and converted to the Shangpa Kagyu tradition in the eleventh century, and ultimately to the Geluk tradition in the seventeenth century. The Seventh Ganden Tripa Lodro Tenpa received his monastic vows at Nenying.
Tolung Namgyel is a Jonang monastery in central Tibet which was in existence by at least the fourteenth century when Rinchen Tsultrim resided there.

Sabzang Ganden, a Sakya monastery near Sakya in central Tibet, was in existence from at least the fourtenth century when Lodro Gyeltsen taught there. It is the seat of the Sabzang Pakpa and Sabzang Mati Panchen incarnation lineages.

name_variants: , gtsang dpal steng dgon pa ,
description: Pelteng is a Jonang monastery in Tsang. It was in existence by the early fourteenth century when the local lord, Lhawangpa, gave it to Shangton Gyawo Sonam Drakpa, a disciple of Dolpopa.
Tselmin, a Jonang monastery, was in existence by the fifteenth century when Nyakpuwa Sonam Zangpo retired there.

name_variants: Tagong; Lhagong, dpal lha sgang dgon; mi nyag lha sgang dgon; lha sgang dgon mthong grol bsam grub gling chos sde, 塔公寺
description: Lhagang Monastery, known as Tagong in Chinese, is said to have been established in the seventh century by Princess Wencheng, when one of two statues of Śākyamuni she was transporting to Lhasa asked to remain there. It was converted to Karma Kagyu in the eleventh century, and then to Sakya in the thirteenth century.

name_variants: nalantuo si; nalanzha si, dpal nA len dra; 'phan po nAlen+dra; 'phan yul nA len+dra, 那烂扎寺; 那烂陀寺
description: Nalendra, a monastery located north of Lhasa in Penyul, was founded in 1436 by Rongton Sheja Kunrik, who was born into a Bon family and studied at Kadam monasteries. The monastery was absorbed into the Sakya tradition and Rongton came to be considered  one of the six jewels of the Sakya tradition. There are extensive ruins at the site, along with a renovated assembly hall containing murals. Khenpo Tsultrim Gyelsten is credited with initiating the renovation of the site.
Lhatel RInchen Ling is a Drigung Kagyu monastery near Chamdo in Kham. It was founded by Nyo Gyelwa Lhanangpa Sanggye Rinchen in the early thirteenth century.

name_variants: Yabzang Gon, dga' ldan bsam gtan gling, 亚桑寺
description: Yabzang, a Yabzang Kagyu monastery located in central Tibet, was founded by Yabzang Choje Chokyi Monlam in 1206. Currently, the site is largely in ruins.

name_variants: Nyangto Kodrak, myang stod ko brag ,
description: Kodrak is a hermitage in Upper Nyang (Nyangto in the Tibetan Autonomous Region) that was established in the thirteenth century by Kodrakpa Sonam Gyeltsen.
Choding Monastery, also known as Chumdo, was founded by Gar Dampa Chodingpa in around 1215 at Lungsho. It was converted to Geluk from Drigung Kagyu in the fifteenth century.

name_variants: Rinchenling; rennqinglin si; rennqinlin si, mal gro gung dkar rin chen gling dgon, 仁钦林寺
description: Rinchen Ling is a monastery near Lhasa in Meldro Gunkar that was founded in 1481 by Jangsem Gendun Rinchen. Originally a Kagyu monastery, it was later converted to the Geluk tradition.

name_variants: , theg chen chos 'khor gling; byang chen theg chen chos 'khor gling ,
description: Jangchen is a Geluk monastery that was founded by the Third Dalai Lama, Sonam Gyatso with the patronage of Altan Khan in 1579. The monastery was in the Khalkha lands, in Mongolia.

name_variants: Litang Monastery; Litang Chode; Ganden Tubchen Chokorling; litang si; changqing chunke-er si, li thang chos sde; dga ldan thub chen chos 'khor gling, 理塘寺; 长青春科尔寺
description: Litang Chokhor Ling is a major Geluk monastery that was founded in 1580 by the Third Dalai Lama, Sonam Gyatso on his return to Tibet from Mongolia.

name_variants: ali zhacang si, on mda' mnga' ris grwa tshang, 阿里扎仓寺
description: Ngari Dratsang is a Geluk monastery in Nedong that was founded in 1541 by the Second Dalai Lama.

name_variants: Ganden Dudjom Ling; , dga' ldan bdud 'joms gling ,
description: Kharchu Dudjom Ling, a Nyingma monastery in Lhodrak, sits on a site associated with Padmasambhava and numerous other Nyingma saints. It was first developed as a sacred site in the thirteenth century by Melong Dorje and then later founded as a monastery in the sixteenth century by the Fourth Drukchen, Pema Karpo. Under the Fifth Dalai Lama it was expanded and became the seat of the Namkhai Nyingpo incarnations.

Tangkya Lhakhang is a small Geluk institution in Meldro region to the northeast of Lhasa. If all sources can be believed, it was established during the Tibetan Imperial period, possibly by Songtsen Gampo. It was revitalized in the tenth century by Lume Sherab Tsultrim, briefly associated with the Jonang tradition, converted to the Kadam tradition in 1281 by Geshe Chenngawa Tsultrim Bar, and to the Geluk tradition in the fifteenth century by Sempa Lodro Gyeltsen.

name_variants: Derge Druk Gonpa; Okmin Jampa Chokhor Ling,
description: Druk Gon is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Derge that was founded by Aga Tokten Kharmar Konchok Gyatso in the late thirteenth or early fourteenth century. It is now a branch monastery of Khampa Gar.
Uri Monastery was a Drukpa Kagyu monastery founded in 1234 in southern Tibet by Lorepa Wangchuk Tsondru.
Gotsang Repa meditated here during the thirteenth century in a cave near the Nepalese border.
Powo Samling is a Nyingma monastery in Powo.

name_variants: Parphu Monastery; bapu si, par phu dgon, 巴普寺
description: Parpu is a Kagyu monastery that was founded by Parpuwa Lodro Sengge in the twelfth century in Tolung.
Kharak was a hermitage established by Kharakpa Dulwa O in either 1181 or 1193.

name_variants: Gonlung; Gonlung Jampaling; youning si, dgon lung byams pa gling ,
description: Gonlung Jampa Ling is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1604 by Gelse Donyo Chokyi Gyatso. The site was visited by the Third Dalai Lama and Fourth Dalai Lama prior to its founding. Regarded as one of the four great monasteries of the north, it is the seat of the Changkya and Tukwan incarnations. The monastery now houses monks of Tu (Monguor), Tibetan and Mongolian origin. Though destroyed in 1724 during the reign of Lhazang Khan, it was rebuilt in 1732. It was partially destroyed during the Cultural Revolution. Reconstruction began in 1980. Today it is well-known for its new year's festival as well as masked dance ceremonies that are held throughout the year.

name_variants: Shar Yelphug Gonpa
description: Shar Yelpuk is a Yelpa Kagyu monastery in Kham founded by Yelpa Yeshe Tsek in 1171.

name_variants: Sengge Namdzong; Tana Sengge Namdzong; Ling Monastery; dana si, rta rna seng+ge'i gnam rdzong, 达那,
description:
Jang Tana is a Yelpa Kagyu monastery that was founded by Yelpa Yeshe Tsek, a major disciple of the Kagyu master Pakmodrupa, in 1068 in Nangchen, Kham. Yelpa Yeshe Tsek converted an existing Bon monastery. A stūpa there is said to contain Pakmodrupa's relics. It is currently a branch monastery of Tsurpu, the seat of the Karma Kagyu tradition. 

Andreas Gruschke writes that Gesar Lhakhang chapel at Jang Tana contained consecrated relics attributed to King Gesar of Ling and his retinue, which were lost during the Cultural Revolution. These included two swords, the Tapa Lenme sword (ral gri btab pa lan med) of Gesar himself and Yasi Karten (ya zi skar phran) of his brother Gyatsa. These were kept sealed in a box that could only be jointly opened by the Nangchen king and the Tana Abbot. 

Coordinants kindly contributed by Ged Manush, Naldjor Institute.

name_variants: Dordzong
traditions: Drigung Kagyu, Karma Kagyu, Yelpa Kagyu
description: Dodzong is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Kham, and is considered a branch monastery of Khampa Gar. Dodzong was orignally a Yelpa Kagyu monastery that was founded by Yelpa Yeshe Tsek, in 1192. It is the seat of the Dodzong incarnation line. Currently a Drukpa Kagyu monastery, it was rebuilt in the 1980's in a new location after having been destroyed in the 1950's.

name_variants: , shog dgon ,
description: Sho Monastery, belonging to the Martsang Kagyu tradition, located in Kham, was founded in 1167 by Marpa Sherab Yeshe. At one point it is said that 10,000 monks resided there. While many area monasteries were being converted to Geluk, the Marstangpas fled to Pelyul, a major Nyingma Monastery, where their tradition was absorbed. A Drukpa Kagyu monastery took its place for a time, housing monks and nuns into the 1940s. It was destroyed during the Cultural Revolution and at present the site is largely in ruins.

name_variants: Surmang; Zurmang Dutsithil; Surmang Dütsi Thil; Zurmang Dustetil, smar khams bdud rtsi mthil, 苏莽德子堤寺
description: Zurmang Dutsitil is a Karma Kagyu monastery in Yushu, Kham. It was founded in 1423 the First Zurmang Trungpa, Kunga Gyelten, and has been the seat of the Trungpa incarnations ever since.

name_variants: Tharlam; Tarlam Sabzang Namgyaling; tanglong si, 唐隆寺; 汤陇寺
description: Tarlam is a Sakya monastery located near Jyekundo in Kham. It was founded in 1436 by Ga Rabjampa Kunga Yeshe and is affiliated with Ngor in Tsang; monks from Tarlam received ordination and teachings there, and belonged to the Denma residential house (khamsten). Gaton Ngawang Lekpa founded a Shedra at Tarlam modeled after Dzongsar in the 1930s. In 1981, Dezhung Rinpoche founded Tharlam Monastery in exile located in Boudha, Kathmandu, Nepal.

name_variants: sde gzhung grwa tshang bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling,
description: Dezhung Dratsang Shedrub Dargye Ling is a Sakya monastery in Litang, Kham. It was the seat of Dezhung Lungrik Nyima. It was a branch of Nalendra Monastery.

name_variants: Dzongsar Tashi Lhatse; Derge Dzongsar Gon Shedrub Dargye Ling; zongsa si; dege zongsa si, rdzong gsar; sde dge rdzong sar dgon bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling, 宗萨寺; 德格宗萨寺
description: Dzongsar was founded as a Sakya monastery in Derge, Kham, in 1253 by Drogon Chogyel Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen. There was previously a Bon religious community at the site. In 1918 Dzongsar Khamshe College was constructed there by Dzongsar Khyentse Chokyi Lodro, the reincarnation of Jamyang Khyentse Wangpo. It is the seat of the Dzongsar Khyentse incarnation line.

wylie_name: klong thang sgrol ma lha khang
name_variants: Langtang Dolma; Dolma Lhakhang,
description: Longtang Drolma Lhakhang, in Denma, north of Derge, is said to have been first established in 638, one of King Songtsen Gampo's "demon taming temples," representing the supine demoness' right hand. The central image, a statue of Tārā, is said to have been installed by Princess Wenchung. It currently belongs to the Geluk tradition.

name_variants: Ngurmik Drolma Lhakhang,
description: Rong Ngurmik was monastery in Rong in existence from at least the eleventh century when it was established by students of Tongstun Sherab Sengge. Local history holds that a Vairocana temple at Ngurmik existed since the imperial era.  Sachen Kunga Nyingpo studied Abhidharmakośa at the age of twelve under Darma Nyingpo. In the twelfth century it was the largest monastic complex in the area, a college having been established by Che Duldzin (gtsang rong pa lce 'dul 'dzin). It later became a branch of Rong Jamchen. The Tara statue for which it is named was moved to Tashilunpo by the Fourth Panchen Lama. In 1969 the complex was destroyed though a stupa and ruins remain

name_variants: Ensa; Wen; Uding; Lower Wesna; Wensa Monastery
description: Wensa Monastery, founded in the fifteenth century by Sonam Chokyi Langpo, is an important Geluk hermitage in the Tsang region. It is noted as the source of the Wensa Nyengyu teachings of the Paṇchen Lama incarnation lineage.
Chokhor Uding was in existence by around 1514 when the Third Panchen, Wensapa Lobzang Dondrub, was ordained as a novice monk there.

Lharitse appears to have been a small temple in Tsang, possibly Geluk or Kadam. A lama from the monastery, Drakpa Dondrub, participated in the ordination of the Third Paṇchen Lama, Wensapa Lobzang Dondrub.

Garmo Chodzong is a hermitage to the west of Shigatse, near Wensa. It was at this hermitage that the Third Paṇchen Lama, Wensapa Lobzang Dondrub  received the full transmission of the Lamrim and the Ganden Oral tradition from Chokyi Dorje.
Lekdrub Dratsang was a Geluk educational community in Nyangto. It was in existence by the early sixteenth century when Sanggye Yeshe studied there under Jamyang Gendun Lobzang.

name_variants: Gyume College; Gyurme; Pelden Gyume Dratsang; Lower Tantric College; xia miyuan, 下密院
description: Gyume, the Lower Tantric College, is one of the two main Geluk tantric colleges in central Tibet. It was established in 1433 by the heir of Tsongkhapa's tantric teachings, Sherab Sengge (b.1383 - d.1445), in the southern district of Lhasa known as Nordzin Gyeltsen (nor 'dzin rgyal mtshan). Later Gyume was moved to the Changlochen district in the northern section of the city. The main study at Gyume is of the tantric systems of the Akshobhya form of Guhyasamaja (gsang ‘dus mi skyod pa), the Luipa tradition of Chakrasamvara (bde mchog lu’i pa), and Thirteen-Couple Vajrabhairava (‘jigs byed lha bcugsum). The tantric colleges at Sera and Drepung have a historical relationship with Gyume.
Riwo Gepel is a Geluk monastery in Namling that was founded in the fourteenth century by Shangpa Kunkhyen Sherab Pelzang.

name_variants: Kangchen Chopel
description: Gangchen Chopel is a Geluk monastery that was founded by Panchen Zangpo Tashi (1410-1478/79) in the fifteenth century, during the time he was serving as abbot of Tashilhunpo Monastery.

name_variants: , bsam grub ling ,
description: Samdrub Ling, a Nyingma monastery, was in existence by at least the early sixteenth century, Ngari Paṇchen Pema Wanggyel, when took his ordination vows there.

name_variants: Thangpoche; Solnak Thang; Solnak Tangpoche; tangboqi si, sol nag thang po che, 唐波齐寺
description: Tangpoche, originally a Kadampa monastery located in central Tibet, was founded in 1017 by a group of the Eastern Vinaya monk Lume Sherab Tsultrim's students known as "seven and a half monks." It is famous for having been visited by Atiśa at the invitation of Khuton Tsondru Yungdrung. Tsongkhapa visited the monastery in the fourteenth century and thereafter it became a Geluk monastery.

name_variants: Zhang Zhang Dorjeden; Zhangzhong Gon; xiongxiong si; xiangxiong jingangzuo, 雄雄寺; 香雄金刚座
description: Zhangzhung Dorjeden is a Shangpa Kagyu monastery that was founded by Khyungpo Neljor in 1121. It is located in the Shang valley of Tsang. Khyungpo Neljor's remains were interred here. It was later converted to the Geluk tradition, and the Shangpa teachings were restored by Kalu Rinpoche in the 1940s.

name_variants: Chagar Monastery;, chad dkar chos sde; 'chad dkar bkra shis rab brtan dgon; rong cha dkar chos sde; 'chad dkar chos sde, 恰嘎曲德寺
description: Chekar Chode, a Geluk monastery located in Rong in Zangri county, was founded in 1577 by the Third Dalai Lama, who was assisted by the King of Lhagyari, Sonam Rabten.

name_variants: langtang si
description: Langtang is a monastery in Penyul that was founded in  the 11th century by Langri Tangpa Dorje Sengge. Originally Kadam, it was later taken over by the Sakya tradition.
Darnga is a mountain retreat in Amdo where in the 1930s, Ngawang Lodro Drakpa sat in retreat under the guidance of Dzamno Dorje Kunga Ngawang.

name_variants: , ra shug ri khrod ,
description: Rashuk is a Jonang hermitage. It was in existence from at least the early twentieth century when Ngawang Tsoknyi Gyatso stayed at Rashuk, a mountain hermitage, for a considerable period of time.

name_variants: Dzamtang chode chenpo; Great Dzamtang Lamasery
description: Dzamtang is a monastic city in southern Amdo. It is the common name for the three adjoining Jonang monasteries of Tsangwa, Choje and Tsechu. Of these,Tsangwa is the main monastery of the Dzamtang area and the home institution of the Jonang order. The oldest monastery of the complex is Choje, which was established in 1425 by Rinchen Pel.

name_variants: Derge Gonchen; Lhundrupteng, dgon chen; lhun grub steng,
description: Lhundrubteng is a Sakya monastery in Derge. It was founded in the fifteenth century by Jampa Puntsok on the site of earlier royal temples. Starting in the seventeenth century it enjoyed close ties with Ngor Monastery in Tsang, and is sometimes considered a branch of that monastery. The monastery includes the famous Derge Printing House. It is popularly known as Gonchen, although this term is also used for the entire city of Derge.

name_variants: zebuji si, dpal 'dzam thang tshe bcu pho brang bsam 'grub nor bu'i gling, 泽布基寺
description: Tsechu is a Jonang monastery that was founded in 1462 in Amdo. Together with the adjoining monasteries of Tsangwa and Choje, they make up Dzamtang monastery complex in the Dzamtang area in eastern Tibet.

name_variants: Pelden Shedrub Norbu Chopel Ling; Ali Choje; qiuji si, chos rje dgon dpal ldan bshad sgrub nor bu chos 'phel gling; a li chos rje dgon  , 求吉寺
description: Choje is a Jonang monastery that was founded in 1425 by Rinchen Pel in Dzamtang in Ngawa. Together with the adjoining monasteries of Tsangwa and Tsechu, they make up the Dzamtang monastery complex in the Dzamtang area in eastern Tibet. Choje is the oldest monastery of the complex while Tsangwa is the main monastery and the home institution of the Jonang order.

name_variants: Dzamthang Tsangwa, gtsang pa; shar 'dzam thang bsam 'grub nor bu'i gling; 'dzam thang gtsang ba dgon bsam 'grub nor bu'i gling, 藏哇寺; 中壤塘寺
description: Tsangwa Monastery, located in Amdo, is an important Jonang monastery that was founded in 1717 by Lodro Namgyel. It is one of three monasteries, the other two being  Choje and Tsechu, that comprise the Dzamtang monastic complex. It is divided into Tsangchung and Tsangchen Monasteries.

name_variants: , d+hi tsha dgon rnying ,
description: Old Ditsa is a Geluk monastery that was founded in 1393 in Amdo. It is a sister institution to Ditsa Tashi Choding.

name_variants: naincuo bagan si
description: Ba is a Geluk monastery in Chumarleb county in eastern Tibet. The region was more or less uninhabited until the late nineteenth century. In 1924, the first fifteen pastoral households moved to the region from Golok. Before 1948 four hundred monks lived in Ba Monastery.

name_variants: Okmin Karma Gon; Karma Densa; gama si, og min karma dgon; lho karma dgon; 'og min karma dgon; chab mdo karma dgon; 'og min thub bstan chos 'khor gling, 嘎玛寺
description: Karma Gon was the original seat of the Karmapa incarnation line. It was founded in 1147 by the First Karmpapa, Dusum Khyenpa, in northeastern Kham. It was the seat of the Tai Situ incarnation line until the Eighth Situ, Chokyi Jungne moved his seat to Pelpung Monastery in Derge in the early eighteenth century.

name_variants: Gyal Lhakang; jiedui si; jie lakang, 杰堆寺; 杰拉康
description: Gyel Lhakhang is an ancient Kadampa monastery in Penyul ('phen yul) in central Tibet. It was founded in 1012 by Zhang Nanam Dorje Wangchuk, a student of Lume. The Fifth Dalai Lama once took refuge here when war broke out in Lhasa in 1636.
Dakpo Draka, a monastery in U-tsang, was in existence by mid-twelveth century when the First Karmapa, Dusum Khyenpa, received teachings here from Gomtsul and Sharawa Yonten Drak.

name_variants: , ri wo che gtsug lha khang khra 'jigs ma; khams ri bo che ,
description: Riwoche, a major Taklung Kagyu monastery in Kham, was founded in 1276 by Sanggye Won, considered an incarnation of Gampopa. The large three story temple is supported by wooden columns and contains impressive stone walls, and has been described as fortress-like. At one time 2,000-2,500 monks resided at Riwoche, making it one of the largest monasteries in the region.

name_variants: Yangon
description: Riwoche Yanggon, founded in the seventeenth century by the Second Riwoche Jedrung, Drakpa Gyeltsen, is a branch of Riwoche, a major Taklung Kagyu monastery in Kham.

name_variants: boduo si, 波多寺
description: Poto is a Kadampa monastery that was founded in the mid-eleventh century in Penyul by Potowa Rinchen Sel.

name_variants: Rachung Phuk; reqiong dong
description: Rechung Puk in Nedong is a Kagyu monastery that was the meditation hermitage of Rechungpa. Tsangnyon Heruka composed his biography of Milarepa at the hermitage.
Puchung, a Kadam monastery in Penyul near Poto Monastery, was built by Puchungwa Zhonnnu Gyeltsen in the twefth century.

name_variants: Penyul Gyachak Ri
description: Gyachak Ri monastery in Penyul (Penpo in central Tibet) seems to have existed from at least 1104. In 1104, Gampopa Sonam Rinchen was ordained either here in Penyul at Gyachak Ri or in Dakpo.

name_variants: sewalong si, se ra lung dgon ,
description: Sewalung is a Drigung Kagyu monastery in central Tibet that was founded by a man named Tenpa Rabgye in the fifteenth century.

name_variants: Zur Sangkaling; Ugpalung; Ukpa Lung; Upelung; Upalung
description: Zur Ukpalung was an important Nyingma monastery in Tsang founded by Zurchen Shakya Jungne in the eleventh century. Zurchen's student Shakya Sengge led the monastery subsequently. At its height it was well-known for as a center for scholarship of Nyingma tantra.

name_variants: Dechenteng
description: Dechen Teng is a hermitage or a monastery built by the Third Karmapa, Rangjung Dorje in the early fourteenth century.

name_variants: Hemis Jangchub Choling, he mi byang chub chos gling; he mi grwa tshang,
description: Hemis Monastery is a Drukpa Kagyu monaster in Ladakh. It was founded in the eleventh century and restored in 1630s by Taktsang Repa Ngawang Gyatso, a key figure in the religious tradition of Ladakh, under the patronage of King Sengge Namgyel.
Hanle was the first of the Drukpa Kagyu monasteries that Taktsang Repa Ngawang Gyatso founded in Ladakh with the patronage of King Sengge Namgyel in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Chemre; Chemdey; Chemdey,
description: Chemrey is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery located outside of Leh in Ladakh. It was built by Taktsang Repa Ngawang Gyatso as a memorial following King Sengge Namgyel's death. Construction began in March 1644 and was completed in 1645 or 1646.

name_variants: Chukyer
description: Chukyer Gonsar is a monastery near Mt. Kulakhari in Lhodrak, southern Tibet. It was the seat of Dorje Lingpa.

name_variants: Tsunmotsal; zunmucai si, 尊木采寺
description: Tsunmo Tsel is a Geluk monastery that was founded by Duldzin Drakpa Gyeltsen in 1420 in central Tibet.

name_variants: Chamdo Monastery; Chamdo Jampaling; Jampaling; Kelden Jampa Ling; Chokhor Kelden Jampa Ling
description: Chamdo Chokhor Kelden Jampa Ling is an important Geluk monastery that was founded by Jangsem Sherab Zangpo, a disciple of Tsongkhapa's, in 1437 in Chamdo, Kham. The monastery, the largest Geluk monastery in Kham, is the seat of the Pakpa Lha and Zhiwa Lha incarnations. It has several monastic colleges, including Lingto.

wylie_name: spa tshang dgon g.yung drung rab brtan gling
name_variants: bacang si, 巴仓寺
description: Patsang Gon, a Bon monastery of the Pa (spa) lineage, is located in Drachen county. It was founded by Paton Yungdrung Namzang in 1847.

name_variants: luopo si; lupu si; luba si, g.yung drung bde chen gling; gshen bstan g.yung drung bde chen gling, 罗坡寺; 鲁普寺; 鲁巴寺
description: Lupuk Gonpa is a Bon monastery that was initially established in 1626 as a Bon and Drigung site called Karmar Labrang. It was reconsecrated in 1827 as a Bon monastery by Nyima Tendzin, the twenty-third abbot of Menri Monastery.

name_variants: longge si, dga' ldan chos 'phel gling; lung dkar dgon bsam grub bde ldan gling, 龙格寺; 隆格寺
description: Lungkar is a Geluk monastery that was founded by Achok Lobzang Yeshe in 1785 in Golok, Amdo near Mount Nyenpo Yurtse. It is a branch of Ragya.

name_variants: Menri Gon; meiri si, thob rgyal sman ri dgon; bkra shis sman ri, 梅日寺; 门日寺
description: Menri, the main Bon monastery located in Namling county in central Tibet, was founded in 1404 or 1405 by Nyamme Sherab Gyeltsen. At one time it housed 350 monks, four colleges, a school of dialectics, and an assembly hall. It was largely destroyed during the cultural revolution, and although some restoration has occured, the site still has extensive ruins and only a small cohort of monks.

name_variants: Yeru Ensakha, 叶如恩萨喀寺
description: Yeru Wensakha, a Bon monastery in central Tibet, was the first Bon monastery founded by Dru Jetsun Yungdrung Lama in 1072. In 1386 it was destroyed by floods and rebuilt.

name_variants: Joden; juedan si
description: Joden is a Kadampa monastery that was founded in mid eleventh century in central Tibet just outside of Lhasa.

wylie_name: dpal me theg chen e vaM dga' tshal gling
name_variants: bami si, dpal me dgon; theg chen e waM dga' tshal gling, 巴米寺
description: Pelme Tekchen Evaṁ Gatsel Ling is a Drigung Kagyu monastery in Nangchen, Kham. It was founded in 1640. Chokgyur Lingpa was a monk there when he began revealing treasures.

name_variants: gari si, mgar dgon; nyang chen byang chub chos gling; mgar nyang chen byang chub chos gling, 嘎日寺
description: Nangchen Gar is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in the capital city of Nangchen. Chokgyur Lingpa was a student at this monastery during the nineteenth century.

name_variants: , mus gling dga' bde ba can ,
description: Lingga Dewachen is a Sakya monastery in Lato that was founded in the 1437 by Muchen Sempa Chenpo.
Musu Yama, a Sakya monastery in the Mu valley of Lato, was founded in 1459 by Muchen Sempa Chenpo Konchok Gyeltsen.
Dingma was a Kadam monastery that was established in the eleventh century in central Tibet in present-day Namling county. It was founded by Ram Dingma Deshek Jungne.

name_variants: Chonggye Pelri Tekchok Ling; Pelri Osel Tekchen Ling; Pelri Monastery, dpal ri 'od gsal theg chen gling; dpal ri dgon,
description: Pelri Tekchenling is a Nyingma monastery in Chonggye that was initially established by Terton Sherab Wozer under the patronage of Sonam Tobgyel in the sixteenth century. A branch of Katok, it was the birthplace and childhood monastery of Jigme Lingpa. Pelri is the seat of the Pelri incarnation line.

name_variants: Tsering jong; cirenjiong si; dongga nigu si, pad+ma 'od gsal theg mchog gling, 次仁炯寺; 东嘎尼姑庙
description: Tseringjong, located in central Tibet, is a Nyingma monastery that was founded by Jigme Lingpa as a hermitage in 1762. It has functioned as an active nunnery since the nineteenth century.

name_variants: Namgyel Pelbar; biru si;, rnam rgyal dpal 'bar gling; rnam rgyal dpal 'bar , 比如寺
description: Driru Monastery, Namgyel Pelbar is a Geluk monastery in Naksho that was founded in 1440 by Zhangzhung Chowang Drakpa.
Den Chokhor in Kham was in existence by the mid-fifteenth century when Kunga Pelden served as its abbot.

name_variants: Kham Sinmo Dzong, khams srin mo rdzong ,
description: Sinmo Dzong is a hermitage in Naksho, Kham. It was the seat of Nyima Drakpa who engaged in retreat there between 1671 and 1674.

Khyungpak Tsang was a Bon monastery that was in existence by the thirteenth century, when Donggom Zhikpo, the fifth lineage holder of the Nyengyu Rigpa Chertong tradition of Bon Dzogchen, studied there. It was at Khyungpak Tsang that Donggom received ordi­nation from Khyungpak Gyelbu Lama (khyung 'phags rgyal bu bla ma).
Zhertsa Chode was in exsitence by at least the sixteenth century when Jedrung Sherab Wangpo served as abbot there.

name_variants: Kandze Dargye; Tashi Dargye; Tewo Tashi Dargye, dkar mdzes dar rgyas dgon; bkra shis dar rgyas dgon; tre bo bkra shis dar rgyas dgon ,
description: Dargye is a Geluk monastery that was founded in 1642 by Jedrung Sherab Wangpo outside of Kandze, Kham. It is the largest of the so-called Hor monasteries in the region, which were established by the Mongolian patrons of the Geluk tradition.
Potima, a small Geluk community in Kham, was established in 1536 by Jedrung Sherab Wangpo.

name_variants: Serling Gonpa, gser gling dgon pa ,
description: Tanak Serling, a Sakya monastery in central Tibet, was founded in 1466 by Gorampa Sonam Sengge.

wylie_name: rta nag thub bstan rnam rgyal
name_variants: Thubten Namgyal; Tubtan; Tupten Namgyel, 达那土旦寺; 吐丹朗杰寺
description: Tanak Tubten Namgyel is a Sakya monastery in central Tibet in present day Zhentongmong county. It was founded by Gorampa Sonam Sengge in 1473.

wylie_name: bya phug mdo sngags dar rgyas gling
name_variants: Dongak Dargye Ling; Do-ngak Dargye Ling; Japuk Dongak Dargyeling, bu phug mdo sngags dar rgyas gling ,
description: Japuk Dongak Dargye Ling was likely a Kadam monastery in Lhorong in Chamdo, Kham. In the fourteen century, Lobpon Galeb and Takleb Jangchup Gyeltsen joined this monastery. It is now a Geluk monastery connected with the Tatsak or Kundeling estate. Japuk was established in 1469 by Tanak Khenchen.
Sakya Drakshar monastery was in existence by at least the 1430s when the Fourth Ngor Khenchen, Kunga Wangchuk, took novice vows here.

name_variants: , la dwags shel mkhar pho brang; la dwags shel thub chen dgon ,
description: The Shey Palace and Monastery is an ancient royal residence of the Namgyel dynasty which reigned over Ladakh from the fifteenth to the nineteenth centuries. The heart of the whole Shey complex is formed by the main temple, the Tsuklakhang, built in the late 1640s under King Sengge Namgyel. Shey is located just outside of Leh city on a crest overlooking the Indus Valley.
Azha Yarpung is a Geluk monastery that was founded in 1829 in Amdo.

name_variants: Dreyul Kyemotsel,
description: Dreyul Kyetsel is a Sakya monastery that was founded by Jamchen Rapjampa Sanggye Pel in 1449 with the patronage of the Rinpunpa. After the Rinpungpa lost power, monks from Dreyul Kyetsel studied at Ngor and Sakya.

name_variants: Nyanyo Chagoshong; nianyu si, bya rgod gshongs dgon pa, 年玉寺
description: Nyenyo Jagoshong is a Sakya monastery in Tashigang, Tsang. It was founded by Paṇchen Bumdrak Sumpa in 1490.
Chokhor Lhunpo is a Sakya monastery near the main monastery of Sakya that was established by Panchen Ngodrup Pelwar.
Tashi Pende, a Geluk monastery located in Kongpo in Southern Tibet, was established in the sixteenth century by the Second Pakpa Lha, Pakpa Sanggye Pel.
Demola Monastery, a Geluk institution in Kongpo, was founded in the fifteenth century by the First Pakpa Lha, Pakpa Dechen Dorje.

name_variants: Derge Chakra Gon; Chakra Monastery; Changra, sde dge lcags ra dgon; lcangs ra,
description: Chakra, also known as Changra, is a Sakya monastery in Derge, Kham. It was originally founded as a Drigung Kagyu monastery in 1125 or 1135, and in the thirteenth century it was converted to Sakya. The monastery is near the ruins of the summer palace of the Derge royal family.

name_variants: baiya si, dpe war dgon; sde dge dpe war dgon, 白雅寺; 白垭寺
description: Pewar is a small Sakya monastery in Derge. It was initially a Drigung Kagyu community dating to the early-thirteenth century, founded by Pelden Jangchub Lingpa, but was soon converted in the wake of the Drigung-Sakya conflict at the end of the century.

name_variants: Nyangpo Tashi Cholung, nyang po bkra shis chos lung ,
description: Tashi Cholung, a Geluk monastery in Nyangpo, was founded by the First Pakpa Lha, Pakpa Dechen Dorje in the fifteenth century.

Lho Chotritang was a Geluk monastery in Lhorong that was founded by the First Pakpa Lha, Pakpa Dechen Dorje in the fifteenth century under the patronage of Rongpo Chungtsang. It continued to operate in close connection to Chamdo Monastery, and in 1698 was said to have about fifty monks. It is famous for a large statue of Maitreya.

name_variants: Tseten Gon Ganden Shedrubling, tshe tan dgon dga' ldan bshad sgrub gling; she tan dgon, 才旦寺
description: Tseten is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was found in 1623. It is the seat of the Tseten Zhabdrung incarnation lineage. It is also the mother monastery of the six Garwaka monasteries.

Tak Monastery was the seat of the Tseten Zhabdrung incarnations, who also had a seat at the six Garwaka monasteries. We are not certain of the former location of Tak but in the early 1990s the monastery was moved to Dajiayan near the village of Shidacang to the east of the Hualong County seat of Bayan.

name_variants: tuwacang si, mthu ba dgon bkra shis chos sde; dan tig mthu ba dgon, 土哇寺
description: Tuwa, a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1640, was historically a retreat center and later became a small printing house under the leadership of Tseten Zhabdrung Jigme Rigpai Lodro. It is one of the Six Garwaka monasteries under the tutelage of Tsetan Zhabdrung.

name_variants: Dentik Shelgyi Yang Gon, dan tig shel gyi yang dgon ,
description: Dentik is a Geluk monastery in Amdo. It was first founded in the tenth century and converted to Geluk in the early seventeenth century. Revered as a foremost power-place associated with the Buddha-mind through Kham and Amdo, Dentik is also closely associated with the second propagation of Buddhism in Tibet. It was at Dentik that the three Tibetan hermits Mar Śākyamuni, Tsang Rabsel and Yo Gejung accepted Gongpa Rabsel, who became one of the most important figures of the revival, as their student. Legend has it that the ten men of Utsang who were to bring Buddhism back to central Tibet were ordained here by Gongpa Rabsel. Lhalung Pelgyi Dorje is said to have stayed at Dentik toward the end of his life.

name_variants: nezur; naisu si
description: Neuzur is a Kadampa monastery in central Tibet that was founded in the twelfth century by Neuzurpa Yeshe Bar.

name_variants: , stod lung thag ma dgon ,
description: Tolung Takma is a Kadampa monastery in central Tibet that was in existence by at least the twelfth century when Duldzinpa Takmapa Kawa Darseng settled there.

Drowa Gon, a Kadam monastery, was located in Lhodrak. It was in existence by the twelfth century, when Shupu Namkha Sengge served as its abbot. It was one of the early seats of the Shupu lineage of the Kadam teachings.

name_variants: Purchok; Purbuchog Ritro Jangchubling; Phurbuchok; pubujue si; pujue si, phur bu lcog ri khrod; byang chub gling; phur bu lcog ri khrod byang chub gling, 普布觉寺; 普觉寺
description: Purbuchok is one of the largest hermitages above Sera Monastery. Said to be built on the site of a Padmasambhava meditation cave, it was first developed by the Tselpa Kagyu founder Lama Zhang Yudrakpa in the twelfth century, and converted to the Geluk tradition by the First Purchok, Ngawang Jampa in the eighteenth century.

name_variants: Ngulchu Chodzong; ouqu si, dngul chu ri khrod; dngul chu chos rdzong ,
description: Ngulchu is a Geluk hermitage -- orginally a Kadam hermitage -- in western Tsang. Gyelse Tokme Zangpo resided there in retreat for twenty years in the mid-fourteenth century.

wylie_name: se kyA bkra shis dge 'phel gling
name_variants: , 色尔加寺
description: Sekya Tashi Gepel Ling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in the early nineteenth century.

wylie_name: gsang sngags theg chen chos gling
description: Sang Ngak Tekchen Choling is a Bon monastery in southern Tibet that was founded by Lama Jowo Yungdrung Kyi.

name_variants: Namrab Dakpo Dratsang; Dakpo Ganden Shedrub Ling, rnam rab dwags po grwa tshang; dwags po dga' ldan bshad sgrub gling; bshad sgrub bstan pa'i 'byung gnas mthong smon dwags po grwa tshang ,
description: Dakpo Dratsang was founded by the Seventh Ganden Tripa, Lodro Tenpa, in the mid-fifteenth century. It became one of the largest monasteries in southern Tibet.

name_variants: Rawa To; Rawa Me; Nyetang Dewachen; redui si, ra ba stod; rwa ba stod; ra ba smad; mnyes thang bde ba can, 热堆寺
description: Rato is a Geluk monastery in Chushur that was founded by the Kadam master Gyachang Ruba in 1205, apparently originally under the name Rawa. In the fifteenth century Kunkhyen Yonten Gyatso taught there, strongly advocating the teachings of Tsongkhapa, and the community split into Rawa To (Upper Rawa), which followed the Geluk tradition, and Rawa Me (Lower Rawa), which followed Sakya.

wylie_name: mnyes thang klong rdol ri khrod
description: Nyetang Longdol Hermitage in Nyetang that was originally established by Tsangpa Gyare in the twelfth century. It was converted to the Geluk tradition from Drukpa Kagyu around the eighteenth century when Longdol Ngawang Lobzang resided there for an extensive period of time.

name_variants: Chakri; Chagri; Chakri Dorjeden
description: Cheri Monastery, also known as Chakri Dorjeden, is a hermitage and monastery in the Upper Thimphu valley in Bhutan. It was built in 1619 by Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel as his first monastery in Bhutan, where he established the first monastic body.

name_variants: Tamgo, rta mgo chos dbyings rdzong ,
description:
In the thirteenth century, Phajo Drugom Zhigpo established a meditation hermitage near the present Tango Shedra in Bhutan, formerly known as Tango Choying Dzong. By the late sixteenth century, Mipam Tsewang Tendzin, who was the grandson of Drukpa Kunle and also considered a reincarnation of Phajo Drugom Zhigpo, controlled the site.  In 1616, the Drukpa Kagyu master Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel arrived in Bhutan, having left Ralung Monastery in Tibet. Mipham Tshewang Tenzin offered him Tango Choying Dzong as a place to stay, in part because Mipham Tshewang Tenzin had received his ordination vows from the Zhabdrung’s grandfather, Mipham Chogyal.

Mipham Tshewang Tenzin also gave the Zhabdrung a consort named Damcho Tenzin, in the hopes he would produce an heir. However, it was not to be and Zhabdrung returned her to Mipham Tshewang Tenzin. The two went on to have a son, Tendzin Rabgye, who would later serve as the Fourth Druk Desi, and who would renovate and expand Tango as well as Paro Taktsang. Tango was completed in 1688, and Second Je Khenpo Sonam Ozer assisted with the consecration ceremony.  Later, the Thirteenth Je Khenpo Yonten Taye performed additional ceremonies at the site in 1780. In 1987, the Tango monastic institute became a shedra. Today it functions as both a center of learning and meditation.
Bangri Jokpo was a Nyingma monastic community in Kongpo established in the early seventeenth century by Jatson Nyingpo.
Dar Chode in Tsang was a Geluk institution that was in existence at least by the first half of the fifteenth century when the Eleventh Ganden Tripa, Lobzang Drakpa, studied here as a novice monk.

Ladring Chode was apparently a community in southern Tibet, possibly Kadam or Geluk, existing certainly by the middle of the fifteenth century, when the Twelfth Ganden Tripa, Lekpai Lodro, received his novice vows there.

name_variants: nimatang si, 尼玛汤寺
description: Nyima Tang is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet that was founded by Nyelgo Rinchen Samdrub, a disciple of Tsongkhapa. In the fifteenth century is was a teaching college affiliated with Sangpu Monastery. It was originally founded in the seventh century and was converted to Kadampa by the eleventh century. It is currently in ruins.

name_variants: kaduo si, 卡多寺
description: Khardo, one of the hermitages above Sera Monastery, was founded in 1706 by the First Khardo, Zopa Gyatso. It's one of the ten hermitages belonging to Sera Je College.

wylie_name: dga' ldan byang rtse drwa tshang
name_variants: Jangtse Dratsang
description: Ganden Jangtse is one of the two teaching colleges of Ganden Monastery in central Tibet. It was founded by Namkha Pelzangpo, a disciple of Tsongkhapa.

name_variants: Gyuto College; Gyuto Monastery; Uto Jampel Ling, dpal ldan stod rgyud stod grwa tshang; dbus stod ‘jam dpal gling ,
description: Gyuto, the Upper Tantric College, is one of the two main Geluk tantric colleges of central Tibet. It was established in 1474 or 1475 by Kunga Dondrub, the disciple of Gyume's founder Sherab Sengge. In 1485 Kunga Dondrub was credited with saving Lhasa from a flood and granted perpetual ownership of Ramoche Tsuklakhang in Lhasa, said to have been built to house the Buddha statue brought to Tibet by King Songtsen Gampo's Chinese queen Wencheng, after which Kunga Dondrub moved Gyuto into the Ramoche complex. The main study at Gyuto is of the tantric systems of the Akṣobhya form of Guhyasamāja, the Luipa tradition of Cakrasaṃvara, and Thirteen-couple Vajrabhairava.

name_variants: Takphu; Takpu; dapu si, stag phu rin chen sding dgon; dbus stod stag phu chos sde; stag phu dgon pa, 达普寺
description: Takpu Chode is an important Geluk monastery in central Tibet that was founded as a Kadam institution by Rinchen Nyingpo, a student of Atisha, in either the late eleventh or early twelfth century.

name_variants: Kargya Gon, dkar rgya dgon ,
description: Meldro Chakar Gon was a Geluk monastery in Meldro Gungkar. It appears to have been abandoned in the sixteenth century when Drigung forces attacked.

wylie_name: dga' ldan shar rtse grwa tshang
name_variants: Shartse Dratsang
description: Ganden Shartse is one of the two teaching colleges of Ganden Monastery. There are eleven residential houses in the college.

name_variants: Rakadrak Ritro; rekazha si, se ra byes kyi rag kha brag ri khrod, 热喀扎寺
description: Rakhadrak is a hermitage above Sera Monastery. It was established in the seventeenth century either by Drubkhang Gelek Gyatso or Rakhadrak Azhu Sonam. It is renowned for being the site where Tsongkhapa composed The Essence of Eloquence that Distinguishes Between the Provisional and Definitive Meaning of the Scriptures, and where he received a delegation from China requesting his presence at the Imperial court.

name_variants: Drubkhang Hermitage; Sera Utse Ritro; Sera Tse; Sera Peak, se ra dbu rtse ri khrod ,
description: Sera Utse, also known as Drubkhang hermitage, is a hermitage located to the north above Sera Monastery, a major Geluk monastery in central Tibet. It was founded in 1705 by Drubkhang Gelek Gyatso in a location where Tsongkhapa is said to have engaged in retreat.

name_variants: Kongpo Drula Gon
description: Drula was founded by Dawa Zangpo in the fifteenth or sixteenth century. Dawa Zangpo was a disciple of the First Dalai Lama, Gendun Drub. It is affiliated with Sera Me College.

Taktse Rinchen Gang is the monastery founded in 1119 by the famous Kadampa master Gyergom Zhonnu Drakpa (1090-1171). It seems that it was still a Kadampa monastery in 1346, the year that Drubchen Namkha Gyeltsen took ordination there. It later became a Geluk monastery. Sera Jetsun Chokyi Gyeltsen (1469-1544/1546) became abbot of Rinchen Gang in 1522. The twenty-fourth  Ganden Tripa Jampa Gyatso (1516-1590) studied there as a child and later became its abbot, but was forced to flee when the monastery was attacked by the Pakmodrupa army.

name_variants: juemolong si, 觉摩隆寺
description: Kyormolung Monastery, in Tolung, was founded in the twelfth century by the Kadam master Balti Wangchuk Tsultrim, and converted to the Geluk tradition in the fourteenth century.
Drakwar is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet. Originally a Kagyu monastery that was founded by Tromzher Ozer Sengge, it was converted in the sixteenth century by Khedrub Tendar.

name_variants: rezhen si, byang rwa sgreng; rwa bsgrengs; rgyal ba'i dben gnas; rwa sgreng rgyal ba'i dben gnas, 热振寺
description: Reting, in Jang, was founded in 1057 by Dromtonpa as the seat of the Kadampa school. The Seventh Dalai Lama gave Reting to Trichen Ngawang Chokden, the Fifty-first Ganden Tripa, upon his retirement.  Reting became the seat of the Reting incarnation line, which began in the eighteenth century when the Second Reting, Lobzang Yeshe Tenpa Rabgye was recognized as the reincarnation of Ngawang Chokden. The Reting tulkus were one of only a few high-ranking incarnation lines empowered to become regent of Tibet during the absence or minority of the Dalai Lamas.

name_variants: nailang si; nainang si, stod lung gnas nang dgon, 乃朗寺; 乃囊寺; 奈囊寺
description: Nenang is a Karma Kagyu monastery in central Tibet that was founded by the First Zhamarpa, Drakpa Sengge in 1333. The monastery was given to the Fifth Pawo by the Fifth Dalai Lama after its confiscation from the Zhamar line in 1673 or 1674, and since then monastery has been the seat of the Pawo incarnation lineage.

name_variants: Jang Namring; angren qude si, ngoms ring chos sde, 昂仁曲德寺; 曲德寺
description: Ngamring is a Geluk monastery that served as the seat of the Lato Jang rulers. It was originally founded as a Sakya monastery in the early thirteenth century, and was converted to Geluk in the seventeenth century. Khedrubje Gelek Pelzang studied at Ngamring Chode with Bodong Panchen Jikdrel Chokle Namgyel.
Riwo Dechen is a Geluk monastery in Chonggye that was founded in the fifteenth century by Lowo Pelzang, a student of Khedrubje Gelek Pelzang.

name_variants: Dre Rinchen Drak, spras rin chen brag ,
description: Rinchen Drak, a Geluk monastery in Penyul, was founded by a Śākya Gyeltsen, a disciple of Tsongkhapa.

name_variants: Tethung Gonchen
description: Tetung was established as a Geluk monastery in 1619 on the site of former Kagyu and Sakya institutions. It was one of the two most influential monasteries in the northern part of Amdo located within the Pari region of Gansu province. The First Tukwan, Lobzang Rabten, served as abbot of Tetung Monastery.

Tangring is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1619 by the Thirty-seventh Ganden Tripa, Tangringpa Gedun Rinchen Gyaltsen. The monastery includes an institute for philosophical studies as well as a tantric college, which was founded in 1732. The temple was rebuilt in 1986.

name_variants: Amdo Chubzang; Chubzang Gon Ganden Migyur Ling; Chubzang Gon Tubten Rabgye Ling, chu bzang dgon dga' ldan mi 'gyur gling; chu bzang dgon thub bstan rab rgyas gling ,
description: Chubzang Monastery is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1649 by Chubzang Namgyel Peljor. It was destroyed in 1724, rebuilt in 1765, and refurbished in 1887. At one time it was the wealthiest monastery in the Tsongkha region of Amdo.

name_variants: Gomang Dratsang; Drepung Gomang College
description: Gomang, the earliest of Drepung Monastery's colleges, was established in the early fifteenth century by Drakpa Rinchen, a disciple of Drepung founder Jamyang Choje Tashi Pelden. It quickly grew into one of the largest colleges, ultimately absorbing the Vinaya college.

name_variants: Sangngak Khar, gsang sngags mkhar ,
description: Dechen Sangngak Khar is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet that was founded in 1419 by Tsongkhapa.

wylie_name: bkra shis lhun po shar rtse grwa tshang
description: Tashilhunpo Shartse Dratsang, a monastic college of Tashilhunpo, teaches general subjects.

name_variants: Ganden Rinchenling; baobei si, 宝贝寺,
description: Ganden Rinchen Ling is a Geluk monastery in Serkhok, Amdo, and it is a branch of Gonlung Monastery. It was in existence by at least the eighteenth century when Sumpa Khenpo Yeshe Peljor (b.1704 - d.1788) gave empowerments there.

wylie_name: dpa' ri bkra shis chos gling
name_variants: dpa' ris stong shag bkra shis chos gling,
description: Pari Tashi Choling, founded in the 17th century in Amdo in the place of an earlier Kagyu monastery, is located in Drotsang County. Sumpa Khenpo Yeshe Peljor gave teachings there. It is a branch of Gonlung.
Serlung is a Kagyu monastery in central Tibet.

name_variants: Sera Je College; Sera Je Dratsang; Sera Jey; Seraje Dratsang, ser byes; byes grwa tshang ,
description: Sera Je was founded by Lodro Rinchen Sengge, a disciple of Tsongkhapa, in the fifteenth century. It is one of three colleges of Sera Monastery, a major Geluk monastery in central Tibet. It is one of two philosophical colleges, though the two colleges, Sera Me and Je, consolidated their curricula and administration in the 1990s. Sera Je is the largest college of Sera and traditionally housed monks from eastern Tibet and Mongolia. It is famous for its debate courtyard, as well as a for its assembly hall, which contains an altar to Hayagrīva that is popular with pilgrims.

name_variants: Sera Me Dratsang; Sera Me Tratsang
description: Sera Me, built in 1419, is one of three monastic colleges of Sera Monastery, a major Geluk monastery in central Tibet. A monk named Kunkhyen Jangchub Bumpa is regarded as the founder. Most activities of Sera Me and Sera Je, the other of the philosophical colleges of Sera, were consolidated in the 1990's.
Dromda, a Geluk monastery in central Tibet, was in existence by at least the seventeenth century when the Forty-sixth Ganden Tripa, Jinpa Gyatso served as its abbot.

name_variants: Kham Dab Yangteng; Yangteng Monastery, ldab yang steng dgon; khams 'dabs yang steng dgon; yang steng  ,
description: Dab Yangteng is a monastery in Kham that was in existence by at least the mid-seventeenth century. The Forty-Seventh Ganden Tripa, Lobzang Chopel, was admitted to Dab Yangteng at a young age and took his novice vows here.

name_variants: Ngari Toding, mnga' ris mtho lding ,
description: Toling Monastery in Ngari was founded by Rinchen Zangpo around 996 under the patronage of Lha Lama Yeshe O. It was later converted to the Geluk tradition and affiliated with Sera Monastery.

name_variants: Jayul Gon
description: Jayul was originally a Kadam monastery, later Geluk, that was in existence by at least the eighteenth century when the Forty-Eighth Ganden Tripa, Dondrub Gyatso lived there.

wylie_name: co ne dga' ldan bshad sgrub gling
name_variants: Chone; Chone Gonchen; Tingdzin Dargye Ling, ting 'dzin dar rgyas gling ,
description: Chone Ganden Shedrub Ling is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo. It was originally a Sakya monastery that was founded in 1269 by Pakpa under the patronage of Khubilai Khan, and it was converted to Geluk in 1459 by Choje Rinchen Lhunpo.

wylie_name: bras spungs blo gsal gling grwa tshang
name_variants: Loseling Dratsang
description: Drepung Loseling, the college of diatectics, is the largest of the four remaining colleges of Drepung Monastery. The assembly hall contains stupas with relics of various masters as well as images of Dalai Lamas and other Geluk masters.

wylie_name: dge ldan chos 'phel gling chos sde
description: Genden Chopeling Monastery is a monastery in Shok Druk (shog drug), Kham. The monastery was established by Depa Solpon (sde pa gsol dpon) in the seventeenth century. The Fifty-Sixth Ganden Tripa, Lobzang Drime studied here at a young age in the late seventeenth century.
Pakmo Chode is a Geluk monastery in Taktse. It was founded by Sempa Lodro Gyeltsen in the fifteenth century. It was adminstered by nearby Lo Monastery (lo dgon pa).

name_variants: Amdo Jakhyung; Jakhyung Tekchen Yonten Dargye Ling; xiaqong si; xiaqun si; xiachong si; shachong si, theg chen yon tan dar rgyas gling , 夏琼寺; 夏群寺; 夏冲寺; 沙冲寺
description: Jakhyung is a major Geluk monastery in Bayan Khar in Amdo. It was established in 1349 by Choje Dondrub Rinchen, the first teacher of Tsongkhapa, on the site of an institution established by the Second Karmapa, Karma Pakshi in the twelfth century. In 1363, it was here to Jakhyung that Choje brought the seven-year-old Tsongkhapa and gave him his novice vows. Along with Serkhok, Chubzang and Gonlung, Jakhyung was considered one of the 'four great monasteries of the north,' meaning the oldest and most important Geluk institutions of Amdo.

Rablo Monastery seems to have been a Geluk monastery in the Tsawarong region of Kham. It was in existence by the early eighteenth century, when the Sixtieth Ganden Tripa, Jangtse Lobzang Tenpa took novice ordination there.

name_variants: Tshador Gon; chadao-er si; zhaxi xianba nanjielin, tsha rdor dgon bkra shis byams pa rnam rgyal gling, 岔道尔寺; 扎西贤巴南杰林
description: Tsador is a Geluk monastery in Amdo. Originally a Sakya monastery that was founded in 1260, it was converted to Geluk in the mid eighteenth century.

name_variants: dga' ldan bshad sgrub chos 'khor gling, 西仓新寺; 嘎丹谢珠曲科林,
description: Shitsang Ganden Chokhor Ling is a Geluk monastery near Labrang in Amdo. The present monastery evolved on the grounds of smaller forerunners, either temples or monasteries. In 1839, the Third Detri Jamyang Tubten Nyima started to develop the monastery as a branch of Labrang. It is the seat of the Detri incarnation line.

name_variants: ola niantao si, dga' ldan dam chos kun rgyas gling; gnyan thog dgon dga' ldan dam chos kun rgyas gling; dngul rwa gnyan thog dgon; dga' ldan dam chos kun rgyas gling, 欧拉念涛寺
description: Ngulra is a Geluk monasery in the Machu region of Amdo. There is also a Nyingma monastery by the same name in Gojo, a branch of Pelyul Monastery.

wylie_name: dga' ldan bshad sgrub pad dkar grol ba'i gling
name_variants: Taktsang Lhamo Ganden Shedrub Pekar Ling; Serchen Gompa; Sertri; Sertang
description: Ganden Shedrub Pekar Drolwai Ling, also known as Serchen, Sertri, and Sertang, is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1748 by Gyeltsen Sengge, the 53rd throne-holder of Ganden. This is one of two monasteries in the town of Taktsang Lhamo, which is located on the border of Gansu and Sichuan provinces. The other monastery is Taktsang Lhamo Kirti, which is adjacent to Serchen. Because of their close proximity, they are sometimes confused as one monastery.

wylie_name: gtsos dgon dge ldan chos gling
name_variants: Tso Gon Genden Choling, gtsos dgon pa, 合作寺; 黑错寺
description: Tso Gon Ganden Choling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1650 by Sherab Chokdan. It is famous for its impressive nine-story structure.

wylie_name: rmog ru dgon dga' ldan byams 'phel gling
name_variants: mengru si; mengru si gedan xiangpeilin, 蒙茹寺; 蒙茹寺格丹祥培林
description: Mokru Ganden Jampeling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1720.

name_variants: mao-ergai si, dmu dge dgon, 毛尔盖寺; 毛儿盖寺
