description: Muge Tashi Khorlo is a Geluk monastery located in Ngawa, Amdo. It was founded by Tsakho Ngawang Drakpa, a major disciple of Tsongkhapa, in 1397.

name_variants: Ngayul Gomang; Ge mo si, rnga yul sgo mang; sgo mang sgar; bshad sgrub 'phel rgyas gling, 各莫寺; 格莫寺,
description: Ngawa Gomang, a branch of Labrang Monastery, is Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in either 1776 or 1791 by the Second Jamyang Zhepa, Konchok Jigme Wangpo. As of 1996, it housed over 600 monks, of which eleven were incarnate lamas.

name_variants: Gyaltang; Gyeltang Sungtseling; Gyeltang Sumtsenling; Gyeltang Sumtseling; Ganden Sumtsen Ling; Gedan Songzanlin, dga' ldan sum rtsen gling ,
description: Gyeltang Monastery, also known as Ganden Sumtsen Ling or Sungtseling, was a major Geluk monastery in Kham that was founded in 1679 or 1681 on the advice of the Fifth Dalai Lama. It originally contained eight colleges, of which seven still exist. As of 2009, 600-700 monks were housed at the monastery.

name_variants: Medro Gongkar Evam
description: Evaṃ Monastery was founded in 1359 by Yakde Paṇchen Tsondru Dargye in Medro Gongkar county in central Tibet. Also known as Ayang Monastery, it is not to be confused with Ngor Evam Choden. It shares affiliation with both the Sakya and Geluk traditions.

wylie_name: pad tshal gling byang chub dpal ri dgon pa
name_variants: Pedtsheling Goenpa
description: Petseling Jangchub Pelri Gon is a Nyingma monastery in Bhutan. It founded by the First Petseling, Namgyel Lhundrub in 1769 and remains the seat of the incarnation lineage.

wylie_name: rdo sbis dge ldan 'phel rgyas gling
name_variants: Gori Dratsang; Dowi Gori Dratsang, dgo ri grwa tshang; rdo sbis dgo ri grwa tshang, 瞿昙寺
description: Dobi Ganden Pelgye Ling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo. It was established in the thirteenth century by a Lama Samten Rinchen, and converted to Geluk in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Drotsang Lhakhang Gautamde; Qutan Si; Gautama, gro tshang lha khang go tam sde ,
description: Drotsang Gon is a Geluk monastery in Tsongkha, Amdo, that was founded in 1392 by Samlo Lama Sanggye Tashi under his patron, the Ming Hongwu Emperor. It was built on the site of a Karma Kagyu monastery. It is famous for its symmetrical complex of temples in sino-Tibetan style.

wylie_name: rong bo thos bsam rnam rgyal gling
name_variants: Rongpo; Rongpo Monastery; Rongwo Tosam Namgyel Ling; Rongpo Gonchen Tosam Namgyaling; longwu si, 隆务寺; 隆务大乐法轮洲
description: Rongwo Tosam Namgyel Ling, in the Rebkong region of Amdo, was founded in 1301 by the Sakya master Samten Rinchen who was the eldest son of Dodebum (mdo sde 'bum), the ruler of Rebkong. Originally a Sakya monastery, it was converted to the Geluk tradition in 1630 by Shar Kelden Gyatso. It has three colleges: the Kālacakra College, the Tantric College, and the Dialectic College.

wylie_name: d+hi tsha bkra shis chos sding
name_variants: Ditsa; Genden Tashi Choding, ldi tsha bkra shis chos sdings ,
description: Ditsa Tashi Choding is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1903 by the Fourth Amdo Zhamar, Gendun Tenzin Gyatso. It is a sister institution to Old Ditsa Monastery, located nearby.

name_variants: Wangduephodrang Dzong; Wangdu Podrang Dzong; Wangdiphodrang
description:
Wangdue Phodrang Dzong was in Wangdue Phodrang town in Central Bhutan. Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel laid the foundation stone of Wangdue Phodrang Dzong in 1638, and for the next year and a half, Ponlop Nyama Kukye oversaw the construction process. The four storied tower was attributed to Zhabdrung himself, whereas in 1683, Dzongpon (regional governor) Dedun Chophel extended the upper dzong and the shabkor.  A cantilever bridge built in 1685 to span the Puna Tsang Chu.  In 1667, the Seventh Wangdue Dzongpon Sonam Lhundrub extended the dzong to provide a new entrance to the Jowo Lhakhang.  Over time the complex grew to house over thirteen shrines and three courtyards in the complex. An image of Mahakala that was brought from Druk Lhamoche in Ralung occupies the gonkhang.

Wangdue Phodrang Dzong was impacted by a fire in 1837 and an earthquake in 1897; it was completely razed by a fire on June 24, 2012.
Talang, a monastery in Bhutan, was in existence from at least the eighteenth century when the Sixteenth Je Khenpo, Sherab Sengge, served as the Talang Lama there.

wylie_name: thub bstan bya rgod phung po
description: Tubten Jago Pungpo, a hermitage in Bhutan, was founded by the Ninth Je Khenpo, Shākya Rinchen in 1749.

wylie_name: rta log gsang sngags chos gling
name_variants: Talok Sangngak Choling; Talo Monastery
description: Talo Sangngak Choling is an important Drukpa Kagyu monastery located near Punakha in Bhutan. It was in existence by at least the nineteenth century when the Fourth Zhabdrung, Jigme Norbu had his seat there.

wylie_name: spyi to kha phun tshogs rab brtan gling
name_variants: Chitokha; Puntsok Rabten Ling
description: Chitokha, also known as Shar Chitog Khar, one of the oldest monasteries in Bhutan, is near Wangdi Phodrang in eastern Bhutan. The foundations were laid by Tangtong Gyelpo when he built a temple here in the fifteenth century. Around 1682, the Second Gangteng, Tendzin Lekpai Dondrub, founded his winter residence here.

name_variants: Gangtey; Gangte
description: Gangteng Gon is a Nyingma monastery established by The First Gangteng Tulku, Gyelse Pema Trinle, in Bhutan in 1613. He was a grandson of terton Pema Lingpa, and holder of the "activity" line of his lineage. Gangteng is the biggest Nyingma monastery in Bhutan, and the seat of the Gangteng incarnation line.

name_variants: Prakhar Goemba; Prakhar Ngatshang
description: Trakar Lhakhang, also known as Prakhar Goemba is a Nyingma monastery in the Chume valley, Bhutan. It was founded in the sixteenth or seventeenth century by the First Gangteng Tulku, Peling Gyelse Pema Trinle, whose monastic disciplines of Lingto and Lingme were followed there.
Paro Lateng, a Drukpa Kagyu Monastery in Bhutan, was in existence by the middle of the eighteenth century, when the Thirteenth Je Khenpo served as resident teacher.

Tsamdrak, the seat of the Tsamdrak incarnation lineage, is a Nyingma monastery in Bhutan. It was in existence by at least the eighteenth century when the First Petseling Tulku, Drubtob Namgyel Lhundrub, went to live there.

name_variants: Tashichho Dzong; Dechen Phodrang; Tashichodzong; Thimphu Dzong, bkra shis chos rdzong; thim phu dzong ,
description:
Tashichoedzong, known also as Thimpu Dzong, is located in Bhutan. The site's earliest structure was founded in 1216 by Drigungpa Nyo Gyelwa Lhanangpa Sanggye Rinchen as Do Ngon Dzong, which lies in ruins near the current fortress. Shortly after its founding, Pajo Drukgom Zhikpo of the Drukpa Kagyu took control of the fortress. In 1631 the new dzong, named Tashichoedzong, was completed under the direction of Shabdrung Ngawang Nyamgyel. The Fourth Desi Tendzin Rabgye built a new monastic assembly hall at Tashichoedzong. Shortly thereafter, there was a fire during the reign of the Fifth Desi Gendun Chophel, who oversaw the rebuilding process until its completion in 1698. Additional fires happened in 1760 and 1869, and general reconstructions took place in 1772 and 1777.

In 1962, the Third King of Bhutan Jigme Dorji Wangchuck ordered that Tashichoedzong be extended and renovated in order to accommodate governmental offices in the complex, the consecration for which took place in 1969. Tashichoedzong serves as the Central Monastic body’s summer residence and also houses the offices of the king and cabinet ministers.
Lhundrub Deyang is a Nyingma monastery in Trakar, Chume, Bhutan. It was founded in the sixteenth century by Dawa Gyeltsen, the First Peling Tukse.

wylie_name: dgongs stod gser gyi lha khang
description: Gongto Sergyi Lhakhang is a monastery in Bhutan established in the 16th century by the First Peling Tukse, Dawa Gyeltsen (b.1499 - d.1587), the son of terton Pema Lingpa. The monastery is at Tali in Kheng (rta li mkheng).
Lhadzong Tashigang is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Bhutan. It was founded around 1767 by the Twelfth Je Khenpo, Kunga Gyatso.

wylie_name: go ri na sku snang 'od gsal gling
name_variants: Gorina; Gorina Kunnang Osel; Gorinang Kunnang Osel, go ri nang kun snang 'od gsal ,
description: Kunang Osel Ling, often just called Gorina, is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Paro, western Bhutan, that was established in the early ninteenth century by the Twenty-fifth Je Khenpo, Sherab Gyeltsen.

name_variants: Kyerchu Lhakhang; xiguan si , skyer chu ,
description: Kyichu Lhakhang is in Paro, western Bhutan. Kyichu Lhakhang is considered one of the oldest temples in the Buddhist Himalayas. According to tradition, the first temple at Kyichu Lhakhang was built by the Tibetan Buddhist King Songtsen Gampo in the seventh century. A giant demonness lay across the whole of Tibet and the Himalayas. To subdue her, Songtsen Gampo built 108 temples among which was Kyichu Lhakhang, built on the demoness' left foot. In 1839, the temple was restored on the orders of the Twenty Fifth Je Khenpo, Sherab Gyeltsen. In 1968, H.M. Ashi Kesang arranged for a second temple to be built alongside the first.
Sechang was a monastery a in existence by at least the nineteenth century when a young Alak Lokho Jigme Trinle Gyatso visited with his teacher.

name_variants: Dechen Chokyi Podrang; Shelgon Tashi Dzong, 西关寺
description: Shel is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1630.

wylie_name: mdzod dge dgon sar dga' ldan rab rgyas gling
name_variants: Taktsa; Dzoge Gonsar Ganden Rabgye Ling, stag tsha dgon pa ,
description: Dzoge Gonsar Ganden Rabgye Ling was founded in Dzoge in Amdo in 1798, the site having been offered by Mewa chieftain Konchok Rabten. It is the best known Geluk monastery of Dzoge county.

name_variants: Bimdo; Bindo; Bido Tashi Tosam Chokhor Ling, bkra shis thos bsam chos 'khor gling; bis mdo dgon chen bkra shis thos bsam chos 'khor gling ,
description: Bido Gonchen is a major Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1402 by Lama Kazhiwa Sherab Gyeltsen, a student of Tsongkhapa, on the site of an earlier Sakya monastery.

wylie_name: sge sting dga ldan chos gling
description: Geting Ganden Choling is a monastery in Amdo. It was in existence by at least the late 18th century when Bipa Mipam Dawa studied there.

wylie_name: gtam zhing lhun grub chos gling
name_variants: Tamzhing Lhakhang; Tamzhing Lhundrup Choling
description: Tamshing Lhakhang, a major Nyingma monastery located in central Bhutan, was founded in 1501 by Pema Lingpa and completed in 1505. It is famous for its collections of paintings which exemplify the region's style. Its mother monastery is Lhalung in central Tibet. It is one of the few institutions continuing the teachings of Pema Lingpa.

name_variants: deqian si, 德千寺
description: Lamo Dechen is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1682 by the Third Zhabdrung Karpo Ngawang Lobzang Tenpei Gyeltsen.
Taktsang Rawato was a monastery in existence by at least the eighteenth century when the First Setsang, Ngawang Tashi studied there.

Shardzong was a Geluk monastery located in Amdo that was in existence by at least the eighteenth century when Taktsang Lobzang Rabten resided there. It was later considered a branch monastery of Taktsang.

name_variants: Drugu Tang Drubde; Trugu; Zhugusi, tho gru gu dgon; gru gu thang sgrub sde, 朱古寺,
description: Drugu is a Geluk monastery in Kham, it is a branch of the nearby Chamdo Jampa Ling Monastery. It was founded in 1622 by the First Gyara Tulku, Sherab Puntsok. It became the summer residence of the Pakpa Lha incarnation line, whose seat is at Chamdo Jampa Ling.

name_variants: Puntang Dewachen; Punakha, spu na kha ,
description: Punakha Dzong is located at the confluence of the Po Chu and Mo Chu, and is the winter residence of the Je Khenpo and the Central Monastic Body, who move there from Thimphu on the first day of the tenth lunar month.  Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel laid the foundation stone in 1637. The dzong was intended to look similar to Ralung Monastery in Tibet, where Zhabdrung had previously resided. Gyelse Tendzin Rabgye expanded Punakha Dzong in 1680 when he extended the dukhang to accommodate growing numbers of monks. The complex contains seventeen shrines and temples, and houses the Ranjung Kharsapani, a vertebrae of Tsangpa Gyare Yeshe Dorje, as well as the Machen of Zhabdrung Ngawang Namgyel.

name_variants: Choekhor Rabtentse Dzong; Chökhor Raptse Dzong, krong gsar chos 'khor rab brtan ,
description: Trongsa Dzong is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery-fortress in central Bhutan. Around 1357, Longchen Rabjampa built a monastery called Mandue Sherubling at the site. Renamed as Trongsa Dzong in 1543 by Ngaki Wangchuk, grandfather of Zhabdrung Ngawang Nyamgyel, it significantly expanded over time, a monastic community was established there in 1765 under Tronsa Penlop Zhidar. Due to its strategic location, the Dzong's governors controlled eastern and central Bhutan in the nineteenth century, and it functioned as a defacto capital. It is also known for its printery, which produced religious texts in the traditional Bhutanese method.

name_variants: , dben gnas byams pa gling, 嘎尔清寺; 在 宗教史要 中无相应的寺名
description: Karchen is a monastery in Ngawa, Amdo, that was founded in 1340. Although it may have originally been Nyingma, it appears to have been converted to Geluk by the eighteenth century, when the Second Amchok, Konchok Tenpai Gyeltsen, was enthroned there.

wylie_name: jam dbyangs smra ba'i seng ge gling
description: Jamyang Mawai Sengge Ling was founded in Ngawa in Amdo by The Second Amchok, Konchok Tenpai Gyeltsen, in 1823 at the command of The Third Gungtang Konchok Tenpai Dronme. It is said that during construction a worker found a statue of a lion, giving the monastery its name, Jamyang Mawai Sengge Ling, "sengge" meaning "lion."

name_variants: Chepa Gyakhar; jianghe si, chas pa rgya mkhar dgon; bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling, 江河寺
description: Gyakhar is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1424. It is the seat of the Gyakhar incarnation line.

wylie_name: urge grwa tshang gsang sngags smin rgyas gling
name_variants: Urge Dratsang Sang Ngak Mingye Ling; Chogar Tashi Chodzong,
description: Urge Dratsang Sangngak Mingye Ling, a branch monastery of Labrang Tashikyil located in Amdo, was in existence by at least the eighteenth century when the First Lingtrul, Dondrub Gyatso served as abbot there. Though called Dratsang, it was a small institution that mainly promoted the long-life rituals for the lineage of Junang Ponpo, a descendent of Gushri Khan. The monastery name was later changed to Chogar Tashi Chodzong.

name_variants: donggu si, khams stong 'khor dgon; gsang chen mi 'gyur rdo rje gling bkra shis lhun po, 东谷寺; 东古寺
description: Tongkhor Tashilhunpo is a Geluk monastery in Kham that was founded in the sixteenth century by the First Tongkhor, Dawa Gyeltsen. It is the seat of the one branch of the Tongkhor incarnation line.

name_variants: Derge Printing House; Dege Yinjing Yuan, sde dge par khang chos mdzod chen mo bkra shis sgo mang, 德格印经院
description: The Derge Parkhang was established in 1729 by King Tenpa Tsering. It houses printing blocks for the Derge edition of the Kangyur, edited by Situ Paṅchen Chokyi Jungne, and Tengyur, edited by Zhuchen Tsultrim Rinchen, under the patronage of King Lhachen Puntsok Tenpa, as well as a vast collection of other texts from every religious tradition of Tibet.

name_variants: Kirti; Kalari Kirti, kA la ri sde; bkra shis lhun grub; kA la ri dgon sde bkra shis lhun grub ,
description: Kīrti Monastery also known as Kālari Kīrti, was established by Gendun Gyeltsen, who later became known as the First Kīrti, in 1412 in Ngawa, Amdo. It was the seat of the Kirti incarnations until the Fifth Kīrti moved the seat to Kīrti Namgyel Dechen Ling.

name_variants: Phajoding
description: Pajoding is a major Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Bhutan. Founded in the thirteenth century by Pajo Drukgom Zhikpo, it was greately expanded in the eighteenth century by the Ninth Je Khenpo, Shakya Rinchen.

name_variants: Luchung, klu chung stag tshang dgon; dga' ldan phun tshogs gling ,
description: Luchung Takstang Gon is Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1688 by the Tenth Ponpo of Chone, Lobzang Dondrub, and Detang Khanpo Tsangyang. It was built on the foundation of a Bon monastery that dated back to the twelfth century.
Drangjekha monastery in Bhutan was the seat of the Twenty Fifth Je Khenpo Barawa Sherab Gyeltsen (b.1772 - d.1848), and the winter residence of the Taktsang lamas.

Sang Chokhor, a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Paro, Bhutan, was founded by Second Zhabdrung Sungtrul, Shakya Tendzin in the eighteenth century with patronage of the Paro Ponlob.  It is a seat of the Zhabdrung Sungtrul line.
Tasho Pomdrak was a Karma Kagyu monastery that was taken over and renovated by Pomdrakpa Sonam Dorje in either the twelfth or thirteenth century.

name_variants: yangrigang si; yangmari si; aimari si, 羊日岗寺; 艾玛日寺
description: Yangri Gar, a Drigung Kagyu monastery in central Tibet, was in existence by at least the sixteenth when Rinchen Puntsok established his seat there.

name_variants: Getse Dralak; Dralak Shedrub Dongak Ling; zhala si, bkra lag dgon; gra lag dgon; grwa lag dgon; gra ra ring brag dkar dgon; bkra legs sgrub sde, 扎拉寺,
description: Getse Dralek is a Nyingma monastery in Kham that was founded in the eighteenth century by Getse Paṇchen Gyurme Tsewang Chokdrub. It is a branch of Katok Monastery, and is in the Golok area of Kandze county.

name_variants: Sershul Gemang; Dzagyu Gemang; Gemang Gon Lhundup Dechen Ling; Drama Barmi Gonlung; gemeng si, bra ma bar mi dgon; bra ma'i sgrub sde; bra ma dgon; rdza yul dge mang dgon dpal lhun grub bde chen gling bshad sgrub nor bu'i dga' tshal, 格蒙寺
description: Gemang, a Nyingma monastery, was established in Sershul Dzachukha in Kham by Gyelse Zhenpen Taye Ozer in the nineteenth century, on a site where Gemang Lama Dongak Tendzin first built a hermitage called Drama Barmi Gonlung in 1684. It is a seat of the Gemang incarnation line.

Pabongkha is one of the largest of the hermitages above Sera Monastery north of Lhasa. In the seventh century it was the site of a fort, and later, during the initial spread of Buddhism to Tibet in the eighth century, a small monastery. During the twelfth century it was taken over by the Kadam tradition, and in the fourteenth century Tsongkhapa resided there.

name_variants: , e ri sgo bslab gsum chosde; rigo chode ,
description: E Rigo Chode, a monastery in the E region in central Tibet, present day Chusum county, was in existence by at least the sixteenth century when Peljor Lhundrub (b.1561 - d.1637) served there in an administrative capacity.
Lhetak Gon was a Geluk monastery in central Tibet. It was in existence by the middle of the sixteenth century when Khonton Peljor Lhundrub studied there under a lama named Chennga Chopel Zangpo.

name_variants: Sindzong Osel Drubde
description: Chakri Nyidrak, also known as Sindzong Osel Drubde, is a Nyingma monastery in Kham that was founded in 1703 by Terchen Rigzin Nyima Drakpa, the First Chakri Nyidrak. It is the seat of the Nyitrul or Chakri Nyidrak line.

wylie_name: stag mo sgang skal bzang phun tshogs gling
name_variants: Dzin Takmo Gon, dzin stag mo dgon ,
description: Takmogang Kelzang Puntsok Ling is a Nyingma monastery in Kham that was founded in 1693 by Terton Nyima Drakpa.

wylie_name: rak chab seng ri rdo rje g.yu rdzong
description: Rakchab Sengri Dorje Yudzong was a retreat hermitage of Drime Osel Lingpa, a late-ninteenth and early-twentieth century treasure revealer associated with Katok Monastery.

wylie_name: rgyal rong rtag brtan rnam par rgyal ba'i gling
name_variants: Gyarong; Derge Gyarong; Gyarong Takten Namper Gyalwai Ling; jiarong si, sde dge rgyal rong dgon, 加绒寺
description: Gyarong Takten Nampar Gyelwai Ling is a Nyingma monastery in Gyarong in Derge territory, Kham, that was founded in 1742 by Drubwang Pema Kundrol Namgyel Zangpo, who was the fourth abbot of Dzogchen Monastery.

name_variants: gulu si, 古鲁寺
description: Magur Namgyel Ling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1646 by the Second Zhabdrung Karpo, Lodro Gyatso.

name_variants: Cheka
description: Chekha Monastery was founded in 1141 or 1142 by Chekhawa Yeshe Dorje, a Kadam teacher and the principal disciple of Sharawa Yonten Drak.

wylie_name: rkang tsha dga' ldan chos 'phel gling
name_variants: Kangtsa; Kangtsa Gonchen; Ganden Chopel Ling; gangca si; gangcha dasi, rkang tsha dgon chen mi 'gyur dga' ldan chos 'phel gling, 岗察寺; 刚察大寺,
description: Kangtsa Ganden Chopel Ling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded as a tented encampment in 1915 by Kangtsa Chieftain Neten Wanggyel. It is a branch of Ditsa Monastery.

name_variants: Shrisimha college; Dzogchen Sengge Ri College; Sengge Ri Shedra; sri singha; shree singha; shree simha; sri simha; sri singha; shri singha; shri shimha; sri shimha, seng+ge ri bshad grwa ,
description: Śrī Siṃha College is a Nyingma monastic college that was founded by Gyelse Zhenpen Taye in 1848 at Dzogchen Monastery in Kham.

name_variants: dongke'er si, 东科尔寺; 洞阔寺
description: Tongkhor Ganden Chokholing is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1648 by the Fourth Tongkhor, Dogyu Gyatso. The monastery was built to commemorate the visit of the Third Dalai Lama, and it is an important monastery for the Mongolian tribes of the Kokonor region. It is known for its high level of Tantric study and practice. It is the seat of one of the branches of the Tongkhor line.

wylie_name: mchod rten thang bkra shis dar rgyas gling
name_variants: Chortentang Tashi Dargyeling; tiantang si, 天堂寺
description: Chorten Tang Tashi Dargye Ling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo. It was originally a Bon monastery with the name of Chorten Tang that was founded in 820 and then converted to Kagyu in 1360. In 1647, the Fourth Tongkhor, Dogyu Gyatso, converted the site to Geluk, and built the current monastery. The Assembly Hall, Shakyamuni and Kalachakra Temples have been restored recently, and a tall tower was also added to the complex. Tibetans and Tu (Monguor) have traditionally supported and worshipped at the Tashi Dargye Ling.

wylie_name: chu nag bkra shis chos gling
name_variants: Chunak; qunaihai si, 曲乃亥寺; 曲乃海寺
description: Chunak Tashi Choling is a Geluk monastery in Trika, southern Amdo. It was founded in 1766 by the Sixth Tongkor, Ngawang Jamyang Tendzin Gyatso.

name_variants: Chakpori; Chakri, lcags po ri gso rig slob grwa, 药王山
description: Chakpori Monastery was first extablished in the twelfth century as a Kadampa monastery and converted to Sakya in the thirteenth century. The hill by that name, opposite the Potala in Lhasa, is considered sacred to Vajrapāṇi, and the slopes of Chakpori contain more than 5,000 rock-carvings. In 1695, Desi Sanggye Gyatso and Nyingto Yonten Gonpo built Chakpori Medical College on the site. The Medical College was destroyed in 1959 during the Chinese invasion of Lhasa. In 1992, it was rebuilt in exile in Darjeeling under the guidance of the Fourteenth Dalai Lama.

name_variants: gegong si, 格贡寺
description: Gegong is a Nyingma monastery in Kham Dzachuka that was founded in the early seventeenth century.

name_variants: Dzongsar Khamshe, rdzong sar khams bye grwa tshang ,
description: Khamshe Dargye Ling is the monastic college of Dzongsar Monastery in Derge. It was established in 1918 by Zhenpen Chokyi Nangwa, under the encouragement of Khyentse Chokyi Lodro, and is famous for its ecumenical educational system. There are variant lists of the first nine abbots. Following Jackson, we take that of Lodro Puntsok to be correct.

name_variants: Tarpa Ling; tabalin si, 塔巴林寺
description: Tarpa Ling is a monastery in the Nyang Valley in Tsang just south of Zhalu. Originally associated with the Chel (dpyal) lineage and was a seat of the Chel Sarmapa masters. It was formally founded by Tarpa Lotsāwa Nyima Gyeltsen in the fourteenth century, later becoming a Geluk institution in the mid seventeenth century. Buton Rinchen Drub studied Sanskrit poetry and grammar here for about four years with Tarpa Lotsāwa.

name_variants: Lang Nak; Langna Gon; nongla si; langnai si, glang nag; thub bstan bsam grub mthong grol gling; tre hor glang sna dgon; dkar mdzes glang sna dgon; glang nag dgon pa, 弄拉寺; 郎乃寺
description: Langna is a Sakya monastery in Kandze, Kham. It is said to have been founded in the early eighteenth century by the Tenth Chogye Trichen of Nalendra Monastery, Khyentse Rabten who passed through Kandze on his way to China. It takes its name from the ridge on which it sits, which is said to resemble an elephant's trunk. Some sources assert that it was first established by Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen in 1276.

name_variants: Dabpa dzong drango gon; Drakgo
description: Drango is a Taklung Kagyu monastery in southern Kham that was founded in the late thirteenth century.

wylie_name: lcags mdud o rgyan gling dgon
name_variants: Chagdud; Nyarong Chagdud Gon, nyag rong lcags mdud dgon ,
description: Chagdud, the seat of the Chagdud Tulku incarnation line, is a Nyingma monastery in Nyarong that was founded in 1431 by the First Chagdud Tulku, Sherab Gyeltsen, who built it on the ruins of a thirteenth-century monastery. According to legend, Sherab Gyeltsen was given jurisdiction over Nyarong from a Ming or Mongolian emperor together with the title Chagdud, meaning "Iron Knot," because of his alleged ability to tie iron bars into knots.  Khawa Lungri, an important power-place associated with Padmasambhava, is located above the monastery.

wylie_name: bskal bzang sangs rgyas chos gling dgon
name_variants: Gyelwa Kelzang Gon; Nyarong Shar Gyelwa Kelzang Gon, rgyal ba skal bzang dgon; nyag rong shar rgyal ba skal bzang dgon,
description: Kelzang Sanggye Choling is a Nyingma monastery in Nyarong that was established in 1860 by Nyakla Pema Dudul, a teasure revealer and a prominent master who specialized in Dzogchen.
Sangngak Dechen Ling, a Sakya monastery, was founded in the sixteenth century by the Twenty-Third Sakya Tridzin, Ngawang Kunga Rinchen.

name_variants: jiazi juemu si, ja bzi jo mo dgon; jo mo bde chen mtsho rgyal dgon; nyag rong ja bzi jo mo dgon, 甲孜觉母寺
description: Tsogyel Jomo is a Nyingma nunnery in Kham that was founded in 1866 by Nyakla Pema Dudul.

name_variants: Mangkhar Tubten Gepel; Thubden Gepel, 土丹根培林
description: Tubten Gepel is a Sakya monastery in central Tibet. It was established near the site of a palace associated with the family of Sakya Pandita's mother, Machik Buma Nyitri Lhacham. There may have also been a significant monastery there in those times, as well as a famous hot spring. In the early 16th century, Tsarchen Losel Gyatso restored the monastery. It was destroyed during the cultural revolution; a new temple was built in the 1980s.

wylie_name: dga' ldan bkra shis chos gling
description: A Geluk monastery in Dzakhok (rdza khog), eastern Tibet, where Amdo Geshe Jampel Rolpai Lodro (1888–1936) established a teaching center in the early twentieth century.

wylie_name: dpal snyan mo ri rnam rgyal
name_variants: Nyenmo
description: Pel Nyenmo Ri Namgyel, located in Golok, was established in 1919 by Amdo Geshe Jampel Rolpai Lodro.

name_variants: Kagyame
description: Khagya Me Monastery is a Geluk monastery in western Amdo. It is the seat of the Gyingen incarnation lineage.

name_variants: Drakar
description: Drakkar Gyelmo was a Geluk monastery in eastern Tibet. It was in existence by at least the early eighteenth century when Ngawang Trinle resided there.

wylie_name: gtsang dgon don grub rab brtan gling
name_variants: Dondrub Rabtenling
description: Tsanggon, Dondrub Rabten Ling, is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1765 by the Second Tsang Paṇdita Tenpa Gytatso.

name_variants: Sangngak Mingye Ling; Khecho Evam Gakyil Ling; Ganjia Baishian Si; Gangya Drakkar; Ganjia Baishian Si, gsang sngags smin rgyas gling; mkha' spyod e waM dga' 'khyil gling, 甘加白石崖寺; 甘加白石洞
description: Sangngak Mingye Ling is a Geluk monastery in Sangchu County, Amdo, near Labrang Monastery, with which it is affiliated. It was founded in 1644 and is the seat of the Konseng and Gungri Khandro incarnations. The complex foundations have been associated with Shar Kelden Gyatso.

name_variants: Chokhor Gyel Metok Tang; Chokhorgyal; qukejie si; qiongguojie si; quguojie si; qingkeji si, 曲科杰寺; 琼果杰寺; 曲果杰寺; 青稞吉
description: Chokhor Gyel is a Geluk monastery near Lhamo Lhatso lake. Its foundation dates from 1509 when the Second Dalai Lama, Gendun Gyatso had a hermitage and meditation cave here. Chokhor Gyel came to be known as the personal monastery of the Dalai Lama incarnations.

name_variants: , tsha gan pe shing dga' ldan rab rgyas gling ,
description: Tsagen Peshing is a Geluk monastery in Amdo affiliated with Labrang Monastery. It was in existence by at least the eighteenth century when the Third Detri, Jamyang Tubten Nyima, served as abbot there.

wylie_name: rwa rgya dga' ldan bkra shis 'byung gnas
name_variants: Ragya; Tashi Kundeling; Ragya Ganden Tashi Jungne; Ragya Gon Tashi Kundeling; lajia si; jiaxiang si, bkra shis kun bde gling; rwa rgya dgon bkra shis 'byung gnas bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling, 拉加寺; 嘉祥寺
description: Ragya Monastery is an important Geluk monastery in Golok that was founded in 1769 by Arik Geshe Jampa Gelek Gyeltsen, a Mongolian from Kokonor, for the Seventh Dalai Lama. In 1792 or 1793, Arik Geshe transferred the abbacy of Ragya to the Second Shingza, Lobsang Dargye, whose reincarnations have since presided over the monastery.

name_variants: sexu si, 色须寺
description: Sershul is a major Geluk monastery in northern Kham that was founded in 1760 by a monk from Tashilhunpo named Rabjampa Tenpa Dargye under the patronage of the family of Yidlun Lhari in Derge. It was originally founded as a branch of Chunkor Monastery.

wylie_name: ju mo hor gsang sngags chos gling
description: Jumohor Sangngak Choling, in the Derge region of Kham, is a branch of the Nyingma monastery of Zhechen (zhe chen) and connected with the lineage of Mindroling (smin grol gling). In the mid nineteenth century, the famous scholar Ju Mipam Gyatso entered this monastery as a novice monk.

name_variants: Ju, ju ri khrod ,
description: The hermitage in Junyung where Mipham Gyatso meditated and lived in the mid-nineteenth century. Junyung is likely the same hermitage as Nakchung hermitage in Derge region.

name_variants: babang si, dpal spungs chos 'khor gling; sde dge dpal spungs dgon pa; thub bstan chos 'khor gling; dpal spungs thub bstan chos 'khor gling, 八帮寺; 八蚌寺
description: Pelpung is a major Karma Kagyu monastery in Derge, Kham. It was established in 1727 by the Eighth Tai Situ, Chokyi Jungne, on the site of an earlier Drigung Kagyu monastery. It was the seat of Jamgon Kongtrul, and remains the seat of the Situ incarnations.

name_variants: Lengu Gon, chab mdo kam po gnas nang dgon,
description: Kaṁpo Nenang is a Karma Kamtsang monastery in Kham that was founded in 1164 by the First Karmapa, Dusum Khyenpa. It is a branch of Tsurpu Monastery.

name_variants: Ngawa Gar Jangchub Ling; Ngagar; awa si; angwa si, rnga ba sgar, 阿哇寺; 昂哇寺
description: Ngagar Jangchub Ling is a Geluk monastery in Chentsa, Amdo, that was founded in the fourteenth century. Originally a Sakya monastery, it was converted to Geluk in the sixteenth century when it was given to the First Zhabdrung Karpo by the Tumed Mongol leader Holochi.
Oso is a Geluk Monastery in Amdo. It was in existence at least by the early nineteenth century, when the Third Amdo Zhamar, Ngawang Tendzin Gyatso, served as abbot.

name_variants: Gartar Jampa Ling; huiyuan si; gada xiangbalin, ga' thar chos sde; mgar thar dgon byams pa gling, 慧远寺; 嘎达向巴林
description: Gartar monastery was built in the first half of the eighteenth century by the Qianlong Emperor for the Seventh Dalai Lama, Kelsang Gyatso, who spent seven years in exile here while Polhane ruled central Tibet. Gartar is in Kham Minyak, in far eastern Tibet.

wylie_name: gter lung yid dga chos 'dzin gling
name_variants: Terlung Gon; Shagou Si; duilong si, 堆隆寺
description: Terlung Yiga Chodzin Ling is a Geluk monastery near Labrang in Amdo that was founded in 1725 on the former site of a Drigung Kagyu monastery. It is the seat of the Setsang incarnation lineage. It was rebuilt in 1981.

name_variants: Amchok Gon Ganden Chokhor Ling; Amchok Demotang Ganden Chokhor Ling, dga ldan chos 'khor 'phel rgyas gling; a mchog bde mo thang dga' ldan chos 'khor gling,
description: Amchok Demotang Ganden Chokhor Ling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1760 by the Second Jamyang Zhepa. It is a branch of Labrang Monastery.

wylie_name: gar rtse thub bstan chos 'khor gling
name_variants: Gartse
description: Gartse is a Geluk monastery in Amdo and known as one of the eight foremost sacred places in Rebkong. The Second Setsang, Ngawang Jamyang Tashi (b.1739 - d.1813) supervised the educational system and monastic rule here.

wylie_name: mar thang ob bstan dgon pa
name_variants: shantang aodan si, mar thang bsam 'phel dar rgyas gling ,
description: Martang Obten is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in the early nineteenth century by the Second Setsang, Ngwang Jamyang Tashi.

wylie_name: kIrti rnam rgyal bde chen gling
name_variants: geerdeng si, rnam rgyal bde chen gling; ki rti dgon pa; ki rti dgon gsar dge ldan legs bshad gli ,
description: Kīrti Namgyel Dechen Ling, or Kālari Kīrti, and locally known as Gerda, is an important Geluk monastery in the Ngawa region of Amdo. It was founded in the eighteenth century by the Fifth Kīrti, Lobzang Tenpai Gyeltsen, after which it served as the seat of the Kīrti incarnation line. The site was associated with Padmasambhava and was a hermitage before the site was established as a monastery.

name_variants: Tsetang Monastery; Cethang; Ngacho Dratsang, rtse thang; rtsed thang lnga mchod grwa tshang, 阿曲扎仓,
description: Tsetang is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet. It was first founded as a Kagyu monastery in 1350 by Tai Situ Jangchub Gyeltsen as a branch of Densatil. It was later converted to a Geluk monastery in the eighteenth century during the time of the Seventh Dalai Lama.
Sangsang Dungkar is a monastery in existence by at least the twentieth century when Lobzang Dongak Chokyi Gyatso taught there.
Lhogyu Sera was apparently a Geluk monastery in Amdo, possibly Golok. It was in existence by the early twentieth century, when Dongak Chokyi Gyatso taught there.

name_variants: Wangda Gon Tubten Chokorling; Wangda Gon Shedrub Tashikhyil, thang dkar ma'i dgon pa; dbang mda' dgon bshad sgrub bkra shis g.yas 'khyil,
description: Wangda was founded as a branch of Katok Nyingma monastery in 1493 by Golok Lama Chobum. It was converted to Karma Kagyu by the Tenth Karmapa and later converted back to Nyingma.
Denang is a monastery in Golok where Lobzang Dongak Chokyi Gyatso taught.

name_variants: Tongkyap
description: Tongkyab is a Geluk monastery in Golok, Amdo. It was in existence by at least the mid-nineteenth century when Lobzang Dongak Chokyi Gyatso taught there.
Dori was a Geluk hermitage in Golok, Amdo.
Lhundrub Dzong was a retreat hermitage in Amdo. It was in existence by the mid-seventeenth century when Samten Gyatso, the third abbot of Rongwo Monastery, spent time in retreat there.
Yugu Tongtse was a retreat center which was in existence by at least the seventeenth century when it was visited by Samten Gyatso, third throne holder of Rongwo Monastery.
Wenne Tashikhyil, a Geluk hermitage, was in existence from at least the seventeenth century when Samten Gyatso engaged in retreat there.

wylie_name: dben gnas bsam grub bde ldan gling
description: Wenne Samdrub Deden Ling, a Geluk hermitage, was in existence from at least the seventeenth century when Samten Gyatso engaged in retreat there.

name_variants: Darzhing Dedzom Gon; Darzhing Dedzom Gatsel; Darzhing Gon Dedzom Gatsel, dar zhing bde 'dzoms dga' tshal ,
description: Dedzom Gatsel, a Geluk monastery in Shukshar in Amdo, was founded as a hermitage in the year 1666 by Samten Gyatso. An alternate date of founding is 1610.

wylie_name: rdzong dkar bka' gdams pho brang bkra shis gling
name_variants: Dzongkar Kadam Podrang Tashi Ling
description: Kadam Podrang Tashi Ling is a Geluk monastery in the Rebkong region of Amdo that was founded in 1683 by Maṇipa Sherab Tashi. Dzongkar is a seat of the Dzongkar and Dzongkar Chungwa incarnation lines. The monastery has an upper an lower complex and as of 2013, there were 90 monks at Dzongkar.
Takdo was a Geluk hermitage, likely in Amdo, founded by Sherab Tashi in either the late seventeenth or early eighteenth century.

name_variants: Dopuk Hermitage, rdo phug ri khrod,
description: Dopuk is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1865. It is a branch of Bido Monastery.
Tsikyang was a hermitage founded by Sherab Tashi in the late seventeenth or early eighteenth century.

name_variants: Agang
description: Angang is a Geluk hermitage in Dobi, Amdo founded by Sherab Tashi.
Chorten Kyak is a monastery in Ngawa in Amdo founded by Sherab Tashi.
Namkyak, a Geluk monastery in Ngawa, was founded in the seventeenth century by Maṇipa Sherab Tashi.

wylie_name: ka ring bkra shis dar rgyas gling
name_variants: Karing; Garing; galeng si, kwa ring dgon, 尕楞寺; 尕楞寺
description: Karing Tashi Dargye Ling is a Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1683 by Maṇipa Sherab Tashi. The monastery was destroyed in the twentieth century and it has not been restored.
Rongwo Tashikhyil is a hermitage associated with Rongwo Monastery in Rebkong. The Second Dzongkar Chungwa Tendzin Trinle engaged in retreat at Rongwo Tashikhyil upon his retirement.
Tsagyel, a Geluk hermitage in Amdo, was in existence by at least the eighteenth century when Tenzin Trinle engaged in retreat there.

name_variants: , pho ldang dgon; karma thub bstan bkra shis chos 'khor gling ,
description: Tashi Chokhor Ling, a Nyingma monastery located in the Yumchen Tang plain, was founded in 1984 by Khenpo Munsel. The course of study is based on the traditional curriculum of Katok monastery,

name_variants: Gomme Oselthang, sgom med 'od gsal thang chos sgar ,
description: Gome Oseltang is a Nyingma dharma center in the Nyikhok region of Kham. It was founded in the 1980s by Khenpo Munsel who remained here until his death in 1994.
Nakchung Ritro was a hermitage in Junyung, Kham, where Ju Mipam spent about a year an a half in retreat when he was fifteen or sixteen.

name_variants: Nyide
description: Ga Nyide, a local monastery in Ga (sga) in northwestern Kham, was in existence by at least the early fifteenth century when Ga Rabjampa Kunga Yeshe (b.1397 - d.1470) entered this monastery.

wylie_name: skye dgu mdo don grub gling
name_variants: Kyegu Dondrub Ling; jiegu si, skye rgu dgon; skye rgu'i don 'grub gling, 结古寺; 结古义成洲
description: Jyeku Dondrub Ling, a major Sakya monastery in Jyekundo, Kham, was built on the site of earlier Bon and Kagyu monasteries. The Sakya presence was first established by Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen, and then expanded into a formal monastery in the fifteenth century by Dakchen Sherab Gyaltsen.

name_variants: Riwo Trazang; Gyel Trazang, 扎桑寺; 日吾扎桑寺
description: Se Trazang is a Nyingma monastery and one-time seat of the Northern Treasures tradition. It is located in the Lato region of Tsang in western Tibet. It was founded as early as 1366 by Rigdzin Godemchen. It is the seat of the Seton incarnation lineage. According to tradition, Padmasambhava passed through the area on his way out of Tibet.

Sang Ngak Tekchokling, a Nyingma monastery, was founded in the sixteenth century by Jangdak Tashi Tobgyel of the prominent Jangpa clan that traced their ancestry to Tri Songdetsen. Many important Nyingma figures taught at the monastery, which specialized in Nyingma tantras, specifically the Guhyagarbha Tantra.

wylie_name: gu ru padma e waM lchog sgar
name_variants: Guru Pema Ewam Chokgar; Guru Pema Evam Choggar
description: Guru Pema Evam Chokgar was a tantric community north of the Brahmaputra river established by Tashi Tobgyel in the late 16th century. The community maintained the Jangter (Northern Treasures) tradition. Later the location was developed and expanded by his Tashi Tobgyel's son the Third Dorje Drak Rigdzin, Ngakgi Wangpo into Dorje Drak monastery, which became the main center for the Jangter tradition and at one point had over fifty branch monasteries.
Tashi Samten Ling, a Geluk monastery located in Amdo, was founded in 1822 by the Seventh Kirti, Kunga Chopak Tubten Nyima.

name_variants: Nyarong Jazi Gon; Jazi Gon Sangngak Dechen Choling; jiazi si, gya bzi dgon; gya dgon; ja bzi dgon gsang sngags bde chen chos gling, 甲孜寺
description: Jazi is a Nyingma monastery in Nyarong, Kham that was founded in 1866. Located in Kandze district in Sichuan province, it was the seat of Jazi Amnye Drodul Pema Garwang Lingpa.

name_variants: changgen si, 昌根寺,
description: Tromge Gon is a Nyingma monastery in Kham that was founded in 1275. It is a branch of Katok Monastery.

name_variants: Horkor Shedrub Dargye Ling, hor skor dgon bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling ,
description: Horkor Gon is a Nyingma monastery on the Mato grasslands in Golok, Amdo. It was built in 1927 when Tubten Chogye of Dzogchen Monastery in Kham came to teach. The monks gathered into a tent camp monastery and subsequently built the first structure.

name_variants: Gegyel Natsang, dge rgyal nag tshang dgon ,
description: Gegyel is a Nyingma monastery in the Dzato region of Kham. A branch of Dzogchen monastery, Pema Tsewang Gyatso (b.1902 - d.1959), the twenty-eighth abbot of Śrī Siṃha College, came here when it was newly established and taught and helped establish its traditions.

name_variants: Namseling Shamar Gonsar, rnam sras gling zhwa dmar dgon gsar ,
description: Monkhar Namseling is a Karma Kagyu manor house and monastery in Dranang, the seat of the Namseling Zhamar incarnation line, which branched off from the main line after the death of the Eighth Zhamar. It was controlled by the Namseling family.

wylie_name: yang chos gsang chos padma lhun sdings
name_variants: , g.yang chos dgon ,
description: Yangcho Sangcho Pema Lhunding, a Nyingma monastery in central Tibet, was founded in the seventeenth century by treasure revealer Nyida Longsel, the father of Chowang Dorje Dzinpa, who is believed to have resided there. It is associated with Ngari Terton Garwang Dorje and his incarnation lineage.

name_variants: luo ruo si, 洛若寺,
description: Nubzur Gon is a Nyingma monastery in Serta, southern Amdo that was founded in 1484, and later became considered a branch of Pelyul Monastery.

name_variants: Samten Dargye Ling; Dzato Changma Gar Samten Dargye Ling, rdza stod lcang ma sgar bsam gtan dar rgyas gling ,
description: Changma Gar is a monastic college of Dzato Changmai Monastery, near Jyekundo. It was founded by Tubten Chopel in the twentieth century.

name_variants: Serta Larung Five Sciences Buddhist Academy; Larung Gar English Centre for the Five Traditional Sciences and Higher Buddhist Studies; seda wuming foxueyuan, bla rung slob gling; gser thang lnga rig nang bstan slob gling; gser rta bla rung lnga rig nang bstan slob gling; gser ljongs bla ma rung gi sgar chen, 色达五明佛学院
description:
Larung Gar is a major Nyingma monastery in Serta that was founded initially in 1880 by Dudjom Lingpa, the prolific treasure revealer from Golok. Starting in 1980, it was rebuilt and greatly expanded by Khenpo Jigme Puntsok, one of the most influential and charismatic Nyingma lamas of the twentieth century. At first Khenpo Jigme Puntsok maintained the site as a Tibetan Buddhist encampment (chos sgar), a mobile community traditionally inhabited by followers and devotees gathered around a particular teacher. Then he built a small seminary college (bshad grwa) and a retreat center (sgrub grwa).

As Larung Gar began to attract large numbers of devotees, eventually the curriculum expanded to include grammar, philology, epistemology, reasoning, monastic discipline, Madhyamaka philosophy, mind-training, tantric textual commentaries, Dzogchen and pith instructions. 

The Tenth Panchen Lama Chokyi Gyeltsen blessed Larung Gar and bestowed its official name of Serta Larung Ngarik Nangten Lobling or Serta Larung Five Sciences Buddhist Academy. As Larung Gar became one of the most popular centers of Buddhist learning in twentieth-century Tibet, its example inspired several other Nyingma encampments to develop across Eastern Tibet. It is the largest Buddhist institute in the world.

name_variants: Lhalung Tekchokling; lalong si, 拉隆寺
description: Lhalung Gon is said to have been first established by Lhalung Pelgyi Dorje, the eighth-century assassin of King Langdarma. In 1154, the First Karmapa, Dusum Khyenpa, developed the site into a monastery, and in the sixteenth century it was taken as a seat by the Second Pawo, Tsuklak Trengwa. It served as the seat of the Pawo lineage until 1673 or 1674, when the Fifth Pawo, Trinle Gyatso, moved his seat to Nenang Monastery. Currently a Nyingma monastery, it was given to the Third Peling Sungtrul by the Fifth Dalai Lama and is the seat of that line of incarnations, as well as the Peling Tukse line, two of the three primary lines of Pema Lingpa.

wylie_name: dga' ldan mi pham chos gling
name_variants: Gedrub Ling; Alashan; Alaksha, dge sgrub gling, 广宗寺
description: Ganden Mipam Choling is a monastery in Inner Mongolia. It was in existence by at least the late eighteenth century when Ngawang Tendar, a Mongolian lama, settled there.

name_variants: , bkra shis lung ,
description: Tashilung is a hermitage that was in existence by at least the thirteenth century when Sanggye Gompa Sengge went into retreat there.

name_variants: Serkhok, gser khog dgon; dga' ldan dam chos gling, 赞布寺; 赛柯合寺; 郭莽寺; 广惠寺
description: Tsenpo Gon, also known as Serkhok, is an important Geluk monastery in Amdo that was founded in 1649/1650 by Tsenpo Dondru Gyatso. It is the seat of the Mindrol, or Tsenpo Nominhan incarnation linegage. It was destroyed in 1724 by Chinese forces because it had supported the Mongolian rebellion of Lobsang Tendzin, but the restoration was completed within the next decade.

name_variants: Martsangdrag Gonpa; White Horse Temple; baima si, 白马寺
description: Martsang Drak Gon is a monastery in Amdo that is said to have been founded by Lachen Gongpa Rabsel in the tenth century. It was converted to the Geluk tradition in 1584.

Serkyi Gyelgo is a Nyingma hermitage above Lhagong in Kham which was in existence by at least the twentieth century when Sanggye Tsepel engaged in retreat there. He later established a community of nuns near the hermitage.

name_variants: Basu si, 八宿寺; 同卡寺; 循努巴雪桑珠林
description: Pasho Gon is a Geluk monastery in the Pasho region of Kham that was founded in 1473 by Lhopa Gyeltsen Sengge, a disciple of Tsongkhapa. It was the seat of the Tatsak Jedrung incarnations, one of the lineages empowered to act as regents during the minority of the Dalai Lamas. The regency temple, Kundeling, in Lhasa, was founded in 1794.

name_variants: Kunde Ling; gongdelin si, 功德林寺
description: Kundeling is one of the five regency seats. A Geluk temple in Lhasa near the Potala Palace, it was established by the Qing Emperor in 1794 and offered to the Eighth Tatsak, Yeshe Lobzang Tenpai Gonpo, then the Regent of Tibet, in celebration of the success of the Gurkha war. Since then, it has served as the seat of the Tatsak Jedrung line, now also known as the Kundeling line. The Tenth Tatsak Jedrung, Ngawang Pelden Chokyi Yeshe, also served as Regent of Tibet during the infancy of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama.
Lampar Gon was apparently a small Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Tolung. It housed a large silver reliquary stupa containing relics of Drukpa Kunle.

name_variants: Drinlay Gon; chawu si; zhaguo si; nie chawu si, brug dre'u lhas gser gyi chos 'khor, 查乌寺; 扎果寺; 涅·查乌寺
description: Nyel Drewule Gon is a Drukpa Kagyu in central Tibet that was founded in the fourteenth century.

wylie_name: rta tshag lhun grub bde chen
name_variants: Tashak Lhundrub Dechen; Baso Lhundrub Dechen Gon; Tobgyel Baso Lhundrub Dechen Gon, ba so lhun grub bde chen dgon; thob rgyal ba so lhun grub bde chen dgon ,
description: Tatsak Lhundrub Dechen, located in Tsang, central Tibet, is a Geluk monastery that was either founded or taken over by Baso Chokyi Gyeltsen, who was posthumously recognized as the first of the Tatsak Jedrung incarnations.

name_variants: Shedrub Ling; Kato Gon, ka mtho dgon ,
description: Ganden Shedrub Ling was established by The Fifth Tatsak Jedrung, Ngawang Chokyi Wangchuk in 1643. It's in Kham.
Drepung Zurkhang was in existence by at least the fifteenth century when Lodro Rinchen Sengge taught there.

name_variants: Gingtang Gon Ganden Shedrub Peljor Ling; gentang si; gentang si gandan xiezhu banjuelin, gying thang dgon, 跟塘寺,根塘寺甘丹协珠班觉林,
description: Gingtang Monastery is a Geluk monastery in Chamdo and a branch of Chamdo Jampaling.

name_variants: Dratsang Monastery; chazang si, 查藏旗磨热嘎曲丁寺; 查藏寺
description: Zhe Dratsang is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet that was founded in fifteenth century, either as a Nyingma or Sakya institution. It was converted in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Tubten Nyinje Gatsel Ling; kalong si, thub bstan nyin byed dga' tshal gling; dkar mdzes kha non dgon, 卡龙寺
description: Khanon Gon, a Sakya monastery in Kham, was was founded in 1257 by Kunga Drakpa.
Gyere is a Geluk monastery in central Tibet that was founded in the fifteenth century by Kazhi Rinchen Gyeltsen, a disciple of Tsongkhapa.

name_variants: Mawachok; mowujue si, smra ba cog; smra bo lcog; smra bo lcogs ,
description: Mawochok, an ancient Nyingma pilgrimage site connected to Padmasambhava, was the seat of Nyangrel Nyima Ozer. Initially a hermitage, it developed into a monastery under the direction of Namkha Pel, Nyangrel Nyima Ozer's son and in turn was expanded by Namkha Pel's son, Ngadak Loden Sherab.
Guru Lhakhang in Lhodrak was founded by the First Peling Sungtrul, Tendzin Drakpa, and is the seat of the Peling Sungtrul line, the incarnation line of treasure revealer Pema Lingpa.
Dregon Sar was a Nyingma monastery in Dreyul in Tsang, central Tibet where  Nyima Drakpa met Pema Rigdzin.

name_variants: Rikhu; riku si, dpal ldan bsam 'grub chos dar gling, 日库寺
description: Rikhu is a Sakya monastery in Minyak, near Dartsedo. It was founded in 1240.

name_variants: Dekyiling
description: Dekyi Ling monastery was founded by terton Nyima Drakpa in Sin Dzong, southern Tibet, in the early eighteenth century.

wylie_name: spo rong dpal mo chos sdings
name_variants: Pema Choling, pad ma chos gling; spo rong bde chen dpal mo chos sdings; bde chen dpal mo chos lding, 白玛曲林寺
description: Pelmo Choding is a small Bodong monastery in southwestern Tibet. It was founded in the mid-fourteenth century by Bodong Chokle Namgyel.

name_variants: Shelkhar Chode; xiege-er qude si, shel dkar chos sde dga' ldan legs bshad gling, 协格尔曲德寺
description: Shelkar, an important Geluk monastery in Dingri county, Western Tibet, was founded in 1385 by Lotsāwa Drakpa Gyeltsen under the patronage of the lord of Lato Lho, Situ Chokyi Rinchen. It was converted to Geluk in the seventeenth century and a branch currently exists in Nepal.

name_variants: Tshechu Drubde; cijiu zhude si; cijiu zhudan si, tshe chu sgrub sde; lcags zam bla brang; gu ru'i sgrub phug nam mkha' lding; lcags zam chu bo ri tshe chu sgrub sde, 次久珠德寺; 次久珠丹寺
description: Chakzam Chuwori Tse monastery was established as a Nyingma hermitage in the eight century and converted to a Geluk monastery in seventeenth century at a the site where Tangtong Gyelpo built a famous iron chain bridge over the Tsangpo River.

name_variants: Yardrok Samding; Pel Khandro Duwei Tine Samdrub Chokyi De, dpal mkha' 'gro 'du ba'i bsti gnas bsam grub chos kyi sde ,
description: Samding Monastery is the seat of the Dorje Pakmo incarnation line, one of the few female incarnation lines in Tibet. It was established as a hermitage at the edge of Yamdrok Lake by the Second Samding Dorje Pakmo, Kunga Zangmo, with the support of the local rulers of Yardrok who were her patrons. Samding was built on the site of a pre-existing institution that was founded in the twelfth century by Khetsun Zhonnu Drub and has been a bastion of the Bodong school since the fourteenth century.

name_variants: Yama Trashikyil; Yarma Tashikyil; yama zhaxiqi si, reb kong bkra shis 'khyil, 雅玛扎西其寺
description: Yama Tashikhyil is an important Nyingma monastery and hermitage located in Rebkong, Amdo.  It was the hermitage of the nineteenth-century yogin-poet Zhabkar Tsokdruk Rangdrol, and later of twentieth-century philosopher-artist-historian Gendun Chopel.

name_variants: Yonghe Gong Ganden Jinchak Ling; Lama Temple; yonghe gong; yung ha kun, g.yung hwa dgon, 雍和宫
description: Yonghegong, or Ganden Jinchak Ling, was built in 1694 as an imperial palace in Beijing. Following the Emperor Qianlong's 1744 edict, it was fully converted to a Geluk monastery by the Third Changkya, Rolpai Dorje.

Dartang Monastery in Golok is a branch of Pelyul Monastery, although historically it was much larger than Pelyul. The Second Karma Kuchen, Karma Gyurme Ngedon Tendzin founded it in 1882 (some sources say 1857).
Dongtre Samten Ling was founded in the fifteenth century the Guru Tsokye Dorje. It was one of twenty-one Sakya monasteries in Denma whose monks went to Ngor for ordination.

name_variants: Peljor Gon; Derge Peljor Gon, sde dge dpal 'byor dgon; dpal 'byor dgon ,
description: Alo Peljor Gang is a Karma Kagyu monastery founded in 1472 by the Seventh Karmapa, Chodrak Gyatso, in the Alo region of Derge.

name_variants: Choding Khang; Sera Choding Ritro
description: Sera Choding is a hermitage located above Sera Monastery. Sera Choding was a primary hermitage site of Tsongkhapa, as well as of his close disciples, who meditated in nearby caves. It is said that Tsongkhapa composed his famous work entitled Ocean of Reasoning there. Sera Choding Hermitage was administered by Gyume Dratsang.

name_variants: Segyued Monastery; Segyu Gaden Phodrang Monastery
description: Segyu Dratsang, founded in 1432, was a tantric college located in central Tibet that was founded by Sherab Sengge and Pelden Zangpo. It was the first institution that focused on the tantric practices of the new Geluk lineage.

name_variants: Shabto Lhunpotse Chode, shab stod lhun po rtse'i chos sde,
description: Lhunpo Tse was a Geluk monastery in the Sakya region. In 1432 Sherab Sengge, a close disciple of Tsongkhapa, established Segyu college there, the first institution that focused on the tantric practices of the new Geluk tradition. It is considered a branch of Tashilhunpo.
Jangchen, a monastery in central Tibet, was in existence by at least the 1430s when Gendun Drub, the First Dalai Lama, built a residence there.

name_variants: Padruk Lhagong Monastery, pha drug lha gdong dgon ,
description: Lhadong Gon is a small Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Gungtang. It was in existence by at least the twelfth century when Yanggonpa Gyeltsen Pel was educated there.
Senmo, a Bon monastery in central Tibet, was founded by Dampa Lodro Gyeltsen in the seventeenth century. It is located within the great religious sanctuary of Kongpo Bonri.

wylie_name: gto lung yang dben dpal dgon
description: Yangwen Pelgon is a Bon monastery in Tolung region of Amdo. It was founded by in the seventeenth century by Gyelrong Yungdrung Yeshe.
Drakkar Gepel Ling is a hermitage in Kham. Japa Dongak Gyatso resided there for twelve years in the late nineteenth century.

name_variants: Chakha, chad kha dgon; 'jog mda' 'chad kha dgon; 'phan yul 'chad kha dgon ,
description: Chakar Monastery was established in 1121 in Penyul by Khyungpo Neljor, the originator of the Shangpa Kagyu tradition. According to legend it was one of one hundred and eight monasteries that he founded, although only the names of Chakar and Zhangzhong Dorjeden are known.

Samling, a Kagyu monastery, was founded in the thirteenth century by Zang Samlingpa in the Lower Nyang valley in the general vicinity of the city of Gyantse. It is considered a branch of Tsurpu Monastery.
Yanggon, a hermitage where Yanngonpa Gyeltsen Pel completed his first Vajravārāhī retreat, was in existence from at least the thirteenth century.
Pel Zangden was a monastery was located in Lato Jang. It was founded in the fourteenth century by Kunpang Chodrak Pelzangpo, a disciple of Dolpopa.
Chukha was a monastery in Lato Jang that was founded in the fourteenth century by Kunpang Chodrak Pelzangpo, a disciple of Dolpopa. Buddhaśrī was head teacher ('chad nyan) there.

name_variants: yangbajing si, byang yangs pa can dgon pa, 羊八井寺
description: Yangpachen is a Geluk monastery near Lhasa. Originally a Karma Kagyu monastery, it was founded around 1503 by the Fourth Zhamar, Chodrak Yeshe. Following the Nepal wars of the late eighteenth century, in which the the Tenth Zhamarpa was found guilty of plotting with the Gorkha army, Yangpachen was confiscated by the Tibetan government and converted to the Geluk tradition. In recent years it was been reconverted to Karma Kagyu.

name_variants: Sakya Gonchen; sajia si, sa skya dgon chen ,
description: Sakya Monastery, a major monastery in central Tibet, is the seat of the Sakya tradition. Its first temple was founded in 1073 by Khon Konchok Gyelpo. His descendents of the Khon family, the patriarchs of the Sakya tradition, greatly expanded the complex over the centuries. During the Yuan Dynasty it was the seat of political power in Tibet. The monastery continues to be led by Khon family in the person of the Sakya Tridzin. In the fourteenth century four sons of the Eleventh Sakya Tridzin, Zangpo Pel, established four labrang, or dynastic houses at Sakya: the Zhitok, the Rinchen Gang, the Lhakhang and the Ducho. The Ducho is the sole remaining labrang at Sakya. It was divided in the eighteenth century into two palaces by two sons the Thirty-second Sakya Tridzin, Wangdu Nyingpo: the Drolma Podrang, established by Pema Dudul Wangchuk, and the Puntsok Podrang, established by Kunga Rinchen.
Bodong E was founded in 1049 by Geshe Mudrapa Chenpo in Nyingtri in central Tibet. It was the residence of Bodong Panchen Chokle Namgyel and gave rise to the Bodong tradition.

name_variants: Gongkar; Gongkar Dorjeden; Dorje Den; Gangkar Dorjeden; gongga qude si, gong dkar rdo rje gdan; gangs dkar rdo rje gdan, 贡嘎曲德寺
description: Gongkar Chode, also known as Dorje Den, is a Sakya monastery in central Tibet. It was founded in 1447 or 1465 by Dorjedenpa Kunga Namgyel.
Yarlung Namgyel was a Sakya monastery in central Tibet. Sharchen Yeshe Gyeltsen took ordination there in 1379.
Yarlung Samten Ling is a Sakya monastery in U. It was in existence at least by the middle of the fourteenth century; Sharchen Yeshe Gyeltsen met Lochen Jangchub Tsemo there in the late 1370s.
Sekharchung is a small monastery that was established in 1064 as a Kadam establishment, and converted in the fourteenth century to the Bodong tradition.

name_variants: geshize si; zemgmuda si, 格什则寺; 增木达寺,
description: Getse Monastery is a branch of Pelyul Monastery that was founded by the Nyingma master Lama Sanglo in 1880 in Amdo. Getse monastery is in Golok prefecture, Qinghai province.

name_variants: Tengchen; dingqing si, g.yung drung bstan rgyas gling; khyung dkar g.yung drung bstan rgyas gling; steng chen dgon g.yung drung bstan rgyas gling, 丁青寺; 邛波丁青寺
description: Khyungpo Tengchen is a Bon monastery in western Kham that was founded in 1061 by Khyungpo Sherab Gyeltsen. It was destroyed during the cultural revolution with restoration beginning in 1987.

name_variants: Ribuk Ritro; ribu si, ri sbug ri khrod; ri phug chos kyi dga' tshal; zhwa lu ri sbug, 日布寺; 日浦寺
description: Ripuk was an important hermitage above Zhalu Monastery. It was a center for the transmission of that Zhalu tradition of the Kālacakra.

name_variants: Tradruk; Tradrug; Trandrug; Trangdruk; Trhandruk; Trangdruk; Traduk; changzhu si, g.yo ru khra 'brug bkra shis byams snyoms lha khang, 昌珠寺
description: The Trandruk temple, founded by Songsten Gampo  in the seventh century, is possibly Tibet's earliest geomantic temple, which suppresses the left shoulder of the supine demoness of Tibetan mythology. While the Jokhang may predate Trandruk, there is no clear consensus as to which site is the oldest.  Later, Trandruk was revered as one of Trisong Detsen's three royal temples together with Samye and Jokhang. It is part of the Yarlung pilgrimage circuit known as "three sanctuaries, three chortens." During the period following the collapse of the Tibetan Empire, it is likely that religious activity may have quietly continued in the area, and toward the end of the eleventh century Trandruk was revitalized. Since around that time, it has been associated with the powerful Gyer clan, of which the Negu, Begu and Khangsar families form branches.  It was converted to a Geluk institution in the seventeenth century and eventually grew to have twenty-one temples.

name_variants: Khangsar Monastery; Kang sa si       , khang gsar dgon; khang gsar nyin pa dgon; bshad sgrub nor bu'i gling, 康萨寺
description: Khangsar is a Geluk monastery in the Ngawa region of Amdo. It was founded in 1640.

name_variants: Er ju si; Er cha si, 二居寺二查寺 (可能性大）
description: Gyu is a Bon monastery that was founded in the mid thirteenth century in Amdo.

name_variants: Tsedong Gon; zidong si, srid gsum rnam rgyal gsang chen smra ba'i gling, 孜东寺
description: Tsedong, located in the Shang Valley of Tsang in present-day Namling County, is a Sakya monastery that was founded in 1489.

name_variants: pulong si, pho lung dgon; spo bo pho lung dgon; phu lung dgon 'og min byang chub gling; phu lung chos lding; rin chen spungs gdan sa 'og min byang chub gling, 普龙寺,
description: Pulung Rinchen Ling, a Kagyu monastery in Powo, was founded by Gar Dampa Zhonnu Dorje in 1240. His disciple Pa Rinpoche, served as its first abbot. It is considered a branch of Tsurpu monastery in central Tibet.

Namdroling was established in 1963 in Bylakuppe, India, by the Third Penor Rinpoche. Tubten Tsondru was the first Abbot of Namdroling. It is one of the largest Buddhist monasteries in the world, home to nearly 5000 monks. It includes a monastic college, Dongak Rikpai Jungne Ling, founded in 1978, and popularly known as the Ngagyur Nyingma Institute, and two practice centers: Ngagyur Samten Wosel Ling, built in 1985, and Namdak Trimkhang Ling. An associated nunnary is Tsogyel Shedrub Dargye Ling. A publishing house was established in 1991.
Tsimda Monastery in Markhok is a branch of Katok Monastery. It was founded in 1925 by Apang Terchen.

name_variants: nianlong si, 年龙寺,
description: Nyenlung, a Nyingma monastery in Serta county in Kham, was founded in 1797 by Lama Sangngak. It is considered a branch of Katok monastery and is famous for having been revived by the twentieth century treasure revealer and teacher Namtrul Jigme Puntsok and his consort Tare Lhamo.
Zhuchen Monastery is a branch of Katok Monastery in Serta.

name_variants: Sibda Dzogchen
description: Simda Dzogchen Monastery is a small Nyingma monastery in Markham that was built by Orgyen Samten, a disciple of Pema Rigdzin, in 1678.

wylie_name: sgang sngon bkra shis chos rdzong
name_variants: Gangngon
description: One of two Drigung monasteries in Ladakh. It was founded by Denma Kunga Drakpa with the patronage of King Tashi Namgyal in the second half of the sixteenth century. The monastery is 15 kilometers from Leh.

Zurmang Namgyeltse, a Karma Kagyu monastery in Yushu, Kham, was established in the fifteenth century by Drung Mase, who was posthumously titled the First Garwang. A branch monastery, Zurmang Dutsitil, was established soon after by Drung Mase's disciple, the First Zurmang Trungpa.

name_variants: Kham Gyok; kangjue si, 康觉寺
description: A Drigung Kagyu monastery in Jyekundo, founded by Chennga Namtsowa, a disciple of Jikten Gonpo Rinchen Pel, in the thirteenth century. It is also known as Kham Gyok Monastery (khams mgyogs dgon).
Tashi Gang was a Drigung monastery in Jyekundo. It was founded by Chenggna Namtsowa in the thirteenth century.
Sharkyo Ganden is a Drigung monastery in Kham that was established by Lobpon Tsangpa Jamseng in the fourteenth century.
Lho Ganden Monastery, a Drigung Kagyu monastery presumably located in central Tibet, was founded around the twelfth or thirteenth centuries by a nephew and a disciple of Lobpon Tsangpa Jamseng.
Dingri Langkhor was founded by Padampa Sanggye in 1097. It was the site where he first taught Machik Labdron.

name_variants: Nyemdo; ningduo si, snying sde dgon; snying rdo dgon, 宁多寺
traditions: Kal?cakra, Marpa Kagyu, Nyingma, Zhije and Chod
description: Nyedo, a Nyingma monasery in Dranang, was founded in the twelfth century by Nyedo Kunga Zangpo. Kagyu, Kālacakra and Zhije traditions were also observed there.

name_variants: Tosam Yonten Dargyeling, brag dkar sprel rdzong thos bsam yon tan dar rgyas gling, 扎嘎者宗托桑云丹达吉林; 赛宗寺
description: Drakkar Treldzong Gon, also known as Tosam Yonten Dargyeling, is a Geluk monastery located at one of the eighteen sacred sites along the pilgrimage circuit around Drakkar Treldzong, or White Monkey Fortress. It is one of the three of the most important relgious sites in Amdo. It was built in 1923 by Arik Tsang.

Pabongkha Labrang was the former Lhasa residence of the abbot of Pabongkha monastery. The Lhasa Atlas mentions that it was built in 1954 although it may have been built in the early 20th century. It is a three-story stone building in Lhasa's Kirey neighborhood and after 1959 it was converted into public housing. The Tibet Heritage Fund noted that the building contained excellent details such as ornate carvings and paintings.

name_variants: chali si, dpal ldan smra ba'i seng+ge gling, 查里寺; 查理寺
description: Amchok Tsenyi, an important Geluk monastery located in southeastern Ngawa, Amdo, was founded in 1823 (there is a different Amchok Gon in Gansu), was founded in 1823. The people in the region were Bon practitioners until the eighteenth century when a Ganden educated monk by the name of Sonam Chopel began to convert people to Buddhism. His reincarnations are known as the Amchok Rinpoche, and are based at the monastery.

name_variants: , ta pho dgon; spi ti ta dgon; spi ti ta dgon theg chen chos gling; spyi ti ta po'i dpal bkra shis bde gnas gtsug lag khang ,
description: Tabo is an important monastery located in the Spiti Valley of Northern India. It is considered the oldest continuously operating Buddhist enclave in India and the Himalaya, having been founded in 996. Lha Lama Yeshe O is said to have sponsored the building of the monastery, and Rinchen Zangpo is said to have conceived of the idea. During the tenth and eleventh centuries, Tibetan monks and Indian scholars translated vast amounts of Buddhist texts at Tabo. The site is home to significant works of Buddhist art. Currently, it operates as a Geluk institution, housing monks and nuns, as well offering a school for young children.

name_variants: Khampagar; Kangba si, sga nyag khams pa sgar; thub bstan phun tshogs gling; 'brug dgon khams pa sgar, 康巴寺
description: Khampa Gar, seat of the Khamtrul incarnation line, is an important Drukpa Kagyu monastery located in Chamdo County, Kham. It was founded in the 18th century by the Fourth Khamtrul Chokyi Nyima, apparently inspired by the his teacher, the Third Khamtrul Ngawang Kunga Tendzin. At one point the monastery had over 300 monks, along with two temples. Hundreds of affliated monasteries were located throughout Kham. A college was founded by the Eighth Khamtrul Dongyud Nyima who also founded a Khampa Gar in exile in India.

name_variants: longka si; longga si, ye tha lung dkar dgon gshen bstan rin chen gling, 龙卡寺; 龙嘎寺
description: Yeta Lungkar Gon Shenten Rinchen Ling, a Bon monastery located in Drachen county (Kham), was preexisted by Sog Yungdrungling,  a Bon institution in existence by at least the twelfth century. After the Jungars sacked Sog Yungdrungling, a hermitage was founded at the site in 1715. In 1808, it was reorganized as a monastery by the name of Yulung. In 1925, leaders and local people began to restore the monastery, which had been destroyed in an avalanche in 1868. As of the late 1990's, there were about forty monks at the monastery.

name_variants: Old Meru;  jiu muru si
description:
Meru Nyingpa, Old Meru, situated behind the Jokhang temple inside the Lhasa Barkor, was one of the six temples built in the 9th century during the reign of King Relpachen by Nyang Shami Gocha. Restoration and renovation of the Jokhang, also called the Lhasa Tsuklakhang, had by then become an important activity for Songtsen Gampo's successors.

Destroyed by Langdarma, the temple was subsequently said to be rebuilt by Atisha and later became Geluk under the Third Dalai Lama Sonam Gyatso. It was damaged during the cultural revolution and restoration began in 1984. 

There is a different complex from Meru Dratsang, called Meru Sarpa.

Tengyeling, the seat of the Demo or Tengyeling incarnation line, was founded by the Sixth Demo Ngawang Jampel Delek Gyatso sometime between 1762 and 1763. It was one of the most important of the regency seats in Lhasa, providing three regents of Tibet. Tengyeling's regency status was stripped in the early twentieth century by the Tibetan government after the Ninth Demo was discovered to have taken part in a plot to kill the Thirteenth Dalai Lama. Closed in 1959, the monastery's compound was converted to housing. In 1983, restoration of the Tseumar Chapel began; it is affiliated with Samye. Historically, Tengyeling also maintained links with Drepung Monastery.

name_variants: Tsomonling; Tsemoling; cemenlin si, mtsho smon gling, 策门林寺
description: Tsemonling, a regency seat in Lhasa, was established in the 1770s by Ngawang Tsultrim after he was appointed Regent of Tibet by the Qianlong Emperor. It became the seat of the Tsemonling incarnation line, of which Ngawang Tsultrim (also the Sixty First Ganden Tripa) was the first. Tsemonling was a branch of Sera Me. After being confiscated in 1959, buildings were housed a dance troupe, carpentry workshop and also public housing. In 1985 monastic activity was reestablished.

wylie_name: dga ldan byang chub chos 'phel gling
name_variants: Lungzang Ritro; Lungzang Hermitage; Tewo Ganden Jangchub Chopel Ling, lung bzang ri khrod ,
description: A Geluk monastery in Ngawa founded by the First Tewo Lungzang, Nangwa Lobzang Samten, and the seat of the Tewo Lungzang incarnation line.

name_variants: arou dasi; alike dasi, a rig dgon dga' ldan chos 'phel gling, 阿力克大寺; 阿柔大寺
description: Arik Gonchen, a Geluk monastery located in Amdo, was built by Arik Mongols in the seventeenth century as a memorial to the Third Dalai and the Fifth Dalai Lama, both of whom had stayed at the site. The monastery contains art in the Rebkong style.

name_variants: xiazong si, shwa rdzong sgrub sde, 夏宗寺
description: Shadzong Ritro, a Geluk hermitage located in the Tsongkha region of Amdo and situated on a slope of Amnye Chi Ri, is one of four major meditation sites in Amdo. It was founded in the twelfth century. Legend states that Faxian (337-422) stayed at the location while traveling to India. The Fourth Karmapa stayed at the site and is said to have prophesied the birth of Tsongkhapa, who took his novice vows here at the age of three. The hermitage was expanded over time and in 1383, a temple hall and stupa were built to commemorate the Fourth Karmapa. The site was partially destroyed during the cultural revolution. As of 1999, there were four monks at the hermitage. At some point, relics of Fa Xian were located at Shadzong.

name_variants: Thrangu; Gato Tragu Gon Tashi Choling; changu si; chuanggu si, sga stod khra 'gu dgon bkra shis chos gling, 创古寺; 禅古寺
description: Trangu (also spelled Thrangu) is an important Kagyu monastery south of Jyekundo in Kham. The First Karmapa is credited with its founding in the twelfth century, though some sources suggest that it was in existence earlier. It consists of an upper and lower monastery containing well-preserved murals in the Rebkong style. At its height, Trangu was home to around 500 monks. In 2010, an earthquake devastated the monastery. Trangu is is the seat of the Trangu incarnation line; the current Thrangu Rinpoche oversees the monastery from Sikkim, where he lives is in exile at Rumtek Monastery.

name_variants: Rigyal Gon; rijia si; tading rijia, rtse re rgyal dgon; khri brtan nor bu rtse; gshen gyi gdan sa rtse re rgyal dgon; khri brtan nor bu rtse; dar sdings ri rgyal dgon, 日嘉寺; 日加寺; 塔定日嘉
description: Rigyel Gon Triten Norbutse, a Bon monastery in the Tibetan Autonomous Region, was founded in 1360 by Mushen Nyima Gyeltsen as a family monastery for the Shen clan. Though badly damaged during the cultural revolution, reconstruction began in 1982 and as of 2011 there were 20 monks living at Rigyel Gon.

name_variants: sangpi si, phyag 'phreng bsam 'phel gling, 桑皮寺
description: Chatreng Sampel Ling, a Geluk monastery in Kham, was founded in the mid-seventeenth century by a local chieftan named Pon Khandro. It was built on the site of a Kagyu monastery that had been destroyed by the army of Gushri Khan. It was the seat of the Third Trijang, tutor to the Fourteenth Dalai Lama.

name_variants: kangning si; dingning si, ba' thang chos sde dga' ldan phan bde gling; khams ling si, 康宁寺; 丁宁寺
description: Batang Chode Ganden Pende Ling, a Geluk monastery in Batang, Kham, was founded in 1659 by the Fifth Dalai Lama, who wrote the monastic code of regulations for the monastery.

name_variants: kuoting lakang, mkho mthing rnam snang lha khang; mkho mthing lha khang, 阔庭拉康
description: Khoting Lhakhang, a temple located in Lhodrak near the border of Bhutan, was founded by Emperor Songsten Gampo in the seventh century. It is one of the border-supressing temples that tames the mythic supine ogress, mother of the Tibetan people. It was from within the massive Vairocana statue in Khoting Lhakhang that Nyangrel Nyima Ozer revealed The Eight Instructions: Gatheringof the Ones Gone to Bliss (bka' brgyad bde gshegs 'dus pa) on fierce deity yoga.

name_variants: xianmi si; xianming si, dga' ldan dar rgyas gling; sems nyid dgon dga' ldan dar rgyas gling, 仙米寺; 显明寺
description: Semnyi Gon, a Geluk monastery in the Pari region of Amdo, may have been established as early as 1540. Other sources indicate that the Third Dalai Lama was responsible for its founding around 1584 when he visited the area. Yet another source cites Lhari Khenchen Tseten Dondrub as the founder, with construction beginning in 1623. Over time it was expanded and came to be the largest Geluk monastery to the north of Lake Kokonor and Tsongkha. Though it was partially destroyed in 1723, it was restored in 1725. The head of this monastery was known as Achung Rinpoche, who also maintained significant political power in the region. As of 2010, there were eighteen monks at Semnyi Gon.

name_variants: , shwa pa mdo dgon ,
description: Shopamdo, a monastery located in Lhorong county in Kham, was originally the seat of the Martsang Kagyu tradition but was later converted to a Geluk institution and absorbed by Chamdo Jampaling. At its height, the monastery contained twelve chapels and housed around three hundred monks.

name_variants: Pelwar; Pelber; Pembar; Bianba si; Ranmatang si;, 边坝寺; 然玛塘寺
description: Pelbar monastery, located in Kham, was initially a Sakya institution that may have been founded by Sakya Pandita in the thirteenth century, while some sources state the founder was a Ngakpa. It was an important adminstrative seat for the region during the time of the Yuan dynasty. It was converted to a Geluk monastery by the Fifth Dalai Lama while he was travelling though the region. Famous for its older murals which managed to survive the Cultural Revolution, Pelbar is also important because of its proximity to retreat caves, sacred mountains and lakes. It is the seat of the Pelbar Tulku line.

name_variants: Tang Shu Cave, thang hru'u brag phug, 唐述窟
description: Jampa Bumling, an extensive Geluk establishment located in Amdo, is comprised of an upper and lower monastery, as well as a retreat site. Rinchen Gyatso founded the monastery in the sixteenth century adjacent to an existing Maitreya temple.

name_variants: Chumig Gyatsa; Mukti Kshetra
description: Muktinath, known locally as Chumik Gyatso, is a pilgrimage site for both Hindus and Buddhists. It is one of the most important religious sites in the Himalayas of Nepal and is situated along an important pilgrimage route. Muktinath is famous for its waters as well as for having been a stopping point for Padmasambhava during his journey to Tibet. Traditionally, the caretakers of Muktinath are a line of hereditary Nyingma lamas.
Khacho was a Sakya monastery in Lato Jang. It was in existence by the 14th century.
A Sakya hermitage established in 1377 in the Dok valley of Lato Jang by the Sakya master Buddhaśrī.

wylie_name: bla ma g.yung drung dgon pa
name_variants: Yuru
description: Lamayuru, a Drigung Kagyu monastery in Ladakh, is one of the region's oldest and largest monasteries. It may have been preexisted by a Bon monastery. According to Drigung history, the scholar Naropa caused a lake to dry up at the site, which was then turned into a monastery. Rinchen Zangpo, who is credited with founding 108 monasteries in the region, is also considered the founder of the oldest structure at Lamayuru. Famous for masked-dance festivals, it is currently home to around 150 monks.

name_variants: , bri gung gter sgrom dgon; gter sgro dgon; gzho stod ti sgro, 德仲寺
description: Terdrom, also known as Zhoto Tidro, is a Drigung Kagyu cave site and hermitage located near Drigung Til in the Medro Gungkar county in U, famous for its hot springs and active nunnery. According to legend Tri Songdetsen, Yeshe Tsogyel, and Padmasambhava once took refuge there from hostile Bonpo priests, during which time Padmasambhava concealed treasure. Although a Kadampa hermitage was likely the first edifice there, and Dorje Lingpa is said to have revelealed treasure there, it was developed as a formal meditation site in the sixteenth century by Rinchen Puntsok Chokyi Gyelpo, the seventeenth abbot of Drigung Til.

name_variants: gadong si, dga' ba gdong dgon, 嘎东寺
description: Gadong Monastery is a Geluk monastery founded in the eleventh century by Zingpo Sherapa and located in Tolung Dechen county in near Lhasa. Tsongkhapa is also believed to have meditated in a nearby cave. Gadong is also the seat of the famous Gadong oracle, a medium for one of the protector deities of Tibet called Pehar Gyelpo. The Gadong oracle lineage, unlike the Nechung oracles who are monks, is passed from father to son.

name_variants: Jangra Gon; jiangre si, myang stod lcang ra dpal 'bar gyi dgon, 江热寺,
description: Changra is a Geluk monastery located south of Gyantse. It was founded in the eleventh century as a Kadam monastery and was converted to Geluk in 1413 by Khedrubje Gelek Pelzang.

name_variants: , mang mkha mu gu lung ,
description: Mugulung, the hermitage of Drokmi Lotsāwa Śākya Yeshe, was later restored by Lochen Ratnabhadra. Marpa Chokyi Lodro and Khon Konchok Gyelpo both studied there under Drokmi.
Nyingon is a Nyingma monastery in Pelyul County, in Kham. It is the seat of the Nyingon Choktrul line of incarnations.

name_variants: Tarpaling; Tarpa Ling, 塔巴林寺,
