Ganden Mamo was a small Karma Kagyu monastery in Kongpo, on the Tsari pilgrimage circuit, that was founded by the Second Zhamar, Khacho Wangpo in 1386.
Gojo Banak appears to have been a branch monastery of Pelyul. It was established by the Second Penor Rinpoche in the early twentieth century.
Dago was a Nyingma monastery in Derge, modern Pelyul County, Sichuan. It burned in the early twentieth century and was rebuilt by the Second Penor Rinpoche as a center of Nyingtik practice.
Zingpa Taggo was a Nyingma hermitage in Pelyul founded by Tashi Jungne, a main disciples of Longchenpa. Sherab Ozer spent time there composing works.
Trengpo was a hermitage in southern Tibet, the seat of Sherab Ozer.
Tashi Tse was a small Geluk monastery in Pasho.

name_variants: Tubten Dechen Ling; Derge Dzari Ringu; Rigul; Ringul, thub bstan bde chen gling;  sde dge rdza ri mgul dgon,
description: Ringu Monastery in Derge was founded in 1475 by the Seventh Karmapa. It followed the Karma Kagyu and Shangpa Kagyu traditions.

name_variants: Chakyi Lhakang
description: Chakhyi Lhakang was a small temple in Kham known for transmitting the Vinaya. It existed by the twelfth century, when the young Pakmodrupa served there.

name_variants: Putang Chenye, phu thang spyan g.yas ,
description: Chenye Monastery in Chonggye was founded by Drapa Ngonshe in the eleventh century. It is said that Go Lotsāwa, who was born in the Chonggye region, studied at Chenye. It was later converted to Kagyu and then Geluk. According to tradition, the right eye of Śāriputra was installed in the temple as a relic, hence its name.

wylie_name: be ri dpal ldan 'gro phan gling
name_variants: baili si; bairi si, pad ri dgon; bon ru dgon; be ru dgon, 白日寺; 白利寺
description: Beri is a Geluk monastery located in the Kandze region of Kham. It was founded in 1649 and is the seat of the Getak Tulku lineage.
Labrang Shar was a residence palace at Sakya Monastery.

name_variants: gong jue si, go 'byams dgon, 贡觉寺
description: Gojam is a Nyingma monastery in the Nyarong region of Kham. It was founded in 1159 by Katokpa Drutsa Gangpa. In the nineteenth century Nyakla Pema Dudul taught at Gojam.

name_variants: quzha si,
description: Chodrak Gon is a Nyingma monastery in the Litang region of Kham. It was founded by Lama Tsondru Gyeltsen around the thirteenth or fourteenth century.

A Sakya monastery in the Drakkar territory outside Liangzhou, modern-day Wuwei. Nub Padmo De was one of four monasteries that Sakya Paṇḍita Kunga Gyeltsen (sa skya paN+Di ta kun dga' rgyal mtshan, 1182-1251) and Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen ('phags pa blo gros rgyal mtshan, 1235-1280) established in the region in the thirteenth century. The Third Changkya, Rolpai Dorje (lcang skya 03 rol pa'i rdo rje) was born in 1717 in the Drakkar territory of this monastery.

name_variants: Drepung Gomang Hardong
description: One of the four large regional houses of Drepung Gomang College of Drepung Monastery. The others were Samlo, Gungru and Drati. Prior to 1959, Drepung Gomang had sixteen regional houses or monastic dormitories, and monks coming to study at Drepung would stay at these houses based on their regional affiliation.

name_variants: Taklung Ling; Taklungdrak; dalongzha yingxiu yuan , stag lung gling, 达隆扎隐修院
description: This hermitage was founded by the Seventieth Ganden Tripa Ngawang Chopel, who was also the First Tadrak. The site was also the seat of Chopa Sanggye Puntshok. The hermitage is near Lhasa, in Tolung Dechen dzong. The complex may be on the site of imperial era structures.

name_variants: Lingwa Khamsten; Lingwa House
description: A residential house of Drepung Loseling College of Drepung Monastery.  Ling House, or Khamtsen, was established in the fifteenth century to house monks from the Derge Lingtsang area during their studies at Drepung Loseling.

name_variants: Benpa Chakdor Lhakhang, ban pa phyag rdor lha khang ,
description: Tikchi Monastery, also known as Benpa Chakdor Lhakhang, was founded in the thirteenth century as a Drukpa Kagyu monastery. It was converted to the Geluk tradition in the fourteenth century. It was famous for its image of Vajrapāṇi.
Khachar is a Sakya monastery in Purang. It existed at least by the fifteenth century.
Tubchen Dargye Ling is a royal monastery in Lo Montang that was founded in the late fifteenth century.

name_variants: jiangqulin si, se ba byang chub gling; 'brug byang chub chos gling; gnam 'brug se ba byang chub gling, 降曲林寺
description: Druk Monastery, located  in present-day Chushur county near Lhasa, was founded around the 12th century by Tsangpa Gyare. It was one the most important Drukpa Kagyu monasteries of Tibet, along with Ralung.

wylie_name: stag lung thar gling chos sde
name_variants: , lho stag lung; yar 'brog stag lung; stag lung gwa tshang zhol thar gling chos gter ,
description: Taklung Tarling Chode, also known as Lho Taklung, is a Sakya monastery on the southern shores of Lake Yamdrok Yutso. An ancient temple, it was expanded in the fifteenth century by Taktsang Lotsāwa.

name_variants: Wonton, dbon ston dgon ,
description: Wonto Monastery, originally a Bon and Nyingma institution, was converted to the Sakya tradition in the thirteenth century during the visit of  Chogyel Pakpa. It was expanded during the reign of the Derge king Jampa Puntsok. It was heavily damaged in the nineteenth century during the invasion of Derge by Gonpo Namgyel.

primary_name: Ya Nga Chamda Ganden Khacho Ling
wylie_name: ya nga bya mda' dga' ldan mkha' spyod gling
name_variants: Khacholing; Khachoedling; Ganden Kacho Ling; Jamda; Jada; Jhada, ya nga bya mda' btsun dgon dpal ldan mkha' spyod gling; lcam mda ,
description: Ya Nga Chamda Ganden Khacho Ling Nunnery, in the Driru region of Kham, was founded as a Kagyu monastery. Some sources state that it was established by Drungchen Sonam Dhondup, the son of Sonam Peldren, on the site of her death. The site was converted to the Geluk tradition in the 20th century by followers of Pabongkha. In in late 2015, nuns' residences were destroyed.
Khangmar Monastery in Kandze was established in the fifteenth century as a Karma Kagyu monastery. It was converted to the Geluk tradition some time in the late nineteenth or early twentieth century.
Khangmar is a Nyingma monastery in the Terlhung valley in southern Derge, Kham.

name_variants: , dbang ros dgon pa ,
description: Khemar is a Nyingma monastery of the Katok tradition founded by Terton Sogyal in 1904. It is located in Pema county in the Golok region, near Dodrubchen monastery. In 1989, the monastery was revitatilized, with a cohort of 20 monks approved, growing to about 40.

name_variants: Ara Khangtsen,
description: Ara Khamtsen is one of the regional houses of Sera Me containing two small chapels, one of which is dedicated to the sixteenth century scholar and practitioner Ara Drubtop Tarpe Gyeltsen.The site is a popular destination for pilgrims.

name_variants: Chirmiklung; 奇密隆寺, phyi mi lung, 奇密隆寺
description: Chimilung, is a Geluk monastery located in northwest of Lhasa in Tolung Dechen county. The original site was founded in 1040 as a Kadam center and later as a Geluk site around the mid 15th century. Tsongkhapa is said to have visited Chimilung, which derives its name from the fact that he made a prophesy while looking backward at the site. In recent times it has housed a cohort of nuns and is also known for holding practices carried out by monks from Gyume College. Ara Drubtob Tarpe Gyeltsen entered a strict retreat at Chimilung.

name_variants: Shadrang Puntsok Choling; xiapulang si, sha sbrang phun tshogs chos gling, 夏卜浪寺
description: Shadrang Puntsok Choling was founded in Rebkong in Amdo by Choje Dondrub Rinchen in 1346. Choje Dondrub Rinchen became prominent as the teacher of the young boy who would become Tsongkhapa Lobzang Drakpa, founder of the Geluk tradition. Local accounts maintain that an adjacent hill to Shadrang monastery assumed the new name of Dornyin, an eponymous acronym of Dondrub Rinchengyi Nyinchok Ritro, after Dondrub Rinchen had meditated there.
Changlung is a Bon monastery in southern Derge, now Pelyul County, Kham. It was founded in the seventeenth century by Namkha Lhundrub

name_variants: Drentang Kumbum; Drentang Hermitage, dran thang sku 'bum; dran thang ri khrod ,
description: Drentang Monastery, also known as Drentang Kumbum, was originally founded by Smṛtijñānakīrti in the eleventh century as a meditation hut not far from Langtang Dolma Lhakhang where he taught. It developed into a hermitage and then a monastery with the involvement of the Third Karmapa Rangjung Dorje.

name_variants: Nyel Zangpoche; Zangpoche; sangqing si, gnyal zang po che ,
description: Zangchen Gon, located in southern Tibet, was founded as a Nyingma monastery around the 12th century by Sonam Jungne. It was later converted to Kadam. Vinaya master and Lamrim lineage holder Tsonawa Sherab Zangpo began his studies at Zangchen; during his time there it became an active center for Vinaya studies.

name_variants: Tso Gyakhar Gar, gtsos rgya mkhar sgar ,
description: Gyakhar Gar is a Geluk Monastery in Tso (gtsos) in the Dzoge (mdzod dge) area of Amdo.
Dzogon is a Sakya monastery in Minyak, Kham. It was established in 1395.

wylie_name: gdung bsam ri bo bstan rgyas gling
name_variants: Yongla Goenpa; Dungsam Yongla
description: Dungsam Riwo Tengyeling, a Nyingma monastery in Bhutan commonly known as Yongla Monastery, was founded by Jigme Kundrol Namgyel around 1741. According to some sources, it was at Dungsam that Jigme Kundrol arranged texts of the Longchen Nyingtik teachings.

name_variants: Tashigang Dzong
description: Trashigang Dzong in Bhutan was built in 1659 under the orders of the Trongsa Ponlop Mingyur Tenpa. It functioned as both a fortress and religious institution where Drukpa Kagyu teachings were followed.
Penyul Drosa was a small Kadam monastery in Penyul known for the teaching of Abhidharma.

name_variants: , ra shel ,
description: Rashel is a Nyingma monastery in the Teu region of Minyak, Kham. It is a branch of Dzogchen Monastery.
Belo is a Nyingma hermitage in the Te'u region of Minyak, Kham.

name_variants: Tashi Choling
description: Gyelpak Tashi Choling is a Nyingma monastery in the Te'u section of Minyak, Kham. It is considered a branch of Dzogchen Monastery.
Kunub is a Nyingma monastery in the Te'u region of Minyak, Kham.

tibetan_name: khyung dgon mi 'gyur rdo rje gling
name_variants: Khyunggon Mingyur Dorje Ling
description: Khyunggon Mingyur Dorje Ling is a Nyingma monastery in Rebkong founded around 1810 by Changlung Pelchen Namkha Jigme.

This is the main Bonpo monastery and the seat of the Menri Trizin, the spiriual head of the Bonpos. Beginning in 1970, Lungtok Tenpai Nyima, the Thirty-Third Menri Trizin, buit the new Menri Monastery in Dolanji in northern India. Within a decade, it had become a flourishing monastery with over 300 monks students coming from central Tibet, Amdo, Kham, Ngari, Dolpo, Mongolia and the exile community in India. Menri Monastery. Menri, the original Bon monastery located in Namling county in central Tibet, was founded in 1404 or 1405 by Nyamme Sherab Gyeltsen. It was largely destroyed during the cultural revolution, and although some restoration has occured, the site still has extensive ruins and only a small cohort of monks.
Kyangtsang is a Bon monastery in the Sharkhok region of Amdo. It was founded in the twelfth century.

name_variants: Sera Je Drati House, ser byes sbra ti khang tshan ,
description: One among seventeen residential houses of Sera Je college of Sera Monastery.

name_variants: Dechen Puk; Dechenpuk Drubde, bde chen phug sgrub sde ,
description: A Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Bhutan that was the seat of Humrel Dung Dung Gyelchok, who was its fourth abbot in the fifteenth century.

name_variants: Bumthang Tarpeling
description: A Nyingma monastery in Bumthang, Bhutan, that was the seat of the fourteenth century Nyingma master Longchen Rabjam Drime Ozer. It was founded by Druk Geshe Tenpa Rinchen Chok.

wylie_name: spom mda' gsang sngags bde chen dgon
name_variants: Tsawa Pomda; Sangngak Dechen
description: A Geluk monastery founded by the Third Pakpa Lha Tongwa Donden as a branch of Chamdo Jampa Ling Monastery. He was assisted in its establishment by the Second Zhila Lha Sanggye Jungne.

name_variants: Amdo Zhamar; xiama si; nanchong si, 夏玛寺; 南冲寺; 南冲寺
description: Zhamar is a Geluk monastery in Amdo founded in 1644. Sumpa Khenpo Yeshe Peljor was Abbot in the 1700s.

wylie_name: sa skya gnas drug lha khang
description: The Nedruk Lhakhang is a temple contained within Sakya Monastery. Dharmapālarakṣita was born there.

name_variants: ewo si, dpal ldan zhi ba dgon; zhi ba lha thim dgon; nyag rong zhi ba dgon ,
description: Zhiwa Gon is a Nyingma monastery in the Nyarong region of Kham. A branch of Katok, it was founded in 1225.

name_variants: Gomne; Tsangto Tropu Shabme Gomne
description: A Nyingma monastery in the Shab area of Tibetan Autonomous Region.

Ganden Tegchenling is a major Geluk monastery in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia that has been actively revitatized since 1990. It emerged out of the many temples and monasteries of Khuree that were developed beginning in the 17th century. Gandan was part of the Baruun Khuree, or the western section of the monastic city.
A Kadam monastery in Penyul. It was founded in the 11th century and was the seat of Potowa Rinchen Sel.

name_variants: Pel Mingyur Ngedon Samdrub Ling
description: Drokge is a Jonang monastery in Ngawa founded by Drokge Kunga Pelzang in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Tikse, khri tshogs dgon pa ,
description: One of the most recognizable Geluk monasteries of Ladakh, which looks like a replica of the Potala Palace. Thikse was established during the period of Geluk expansion in Ladakh, probably about the middle of the fifteenth century. It was founded by Pelden Sherab, the nephew of Sherab Zangpo, and situated outside of Leh.

name_variants: , lcang mai' dgon ,
description: A Nyingma monastery near Jyekundo, founded by Tubten Chopel in the twentieth century.

name_variants: Zangpori
description: This is a Bonpo monastery in present day Nyemo, west of Lhasa. The monastery was founded in the eleventh century and belonged to the Meu clan. Though the original monastery is no longer standing, Meu descendants have built a new monastery in a nearby valley.

name_variants: Ganden Namgyel Lhatse
description: Tawang Monastery is in Arunachal Pradesh in India, quite close to the Tibetan and Bhutanese borders. Founded in the seventeenth century, Tawang is a Geluk monastery and has an association with Drepung Monastery in Lhasa.

name_variants: Nyel Kharteng; kading si, gnyal mkhar steng, 卡定寺
description: Founded in the eleventh century in Lhokha, this monastery was converted to Geluk in the fifteenth century. It's the seat of the Kharteng tulku line.

name_variants: quwa si, 曲瓦寺
description: Chuwar monastery was founded as a Kagyu site in the fifteenth century and converted to Geluk in the seventeenth century. The monastery is in Nyalam in southwestern Tibet.

name_variants: Logon; luopu si; luo si, 洛普寺; 洛寺
description: Lo monastery was a Kadam monastery founded in the eleventh century by Kadampa master Chennga Tsultrim Bar (spyan snga tshul khrims 'bar, 1038-1103). In the fifteenth century, it was adopted by the Geluk tradition and became the seat of the Geluk master Lo Sempa Chenpo Lodro Gyeltsen. The monastery is in the Upper Kyichu valley and maintains the Barkor Jampa Lhakhang which contains the reliquary stupa of Sempa Chenpo Lodro Gyeltsen.

name_variants: Dambadarjaalin; Dambadarjaa khiid; anba darjai keyid
description: One of the three major Khalkha Buddhist monasteries of Mongolia. Dambadarjaa was founded in the eighteenth century, and is in the northwest of Ulaanbaatar. The reliquary remains of the Second Khalkha Jetsundampa were interred here.

name_variants: Namtsibteng; Namtseding Chode, gnam rtsib steng ,
description: A Kadampa monastery from the eleventh century in central Tibet. Rendawa Zhonnu Lodro gave many teachings at Namtseding and Tsongkhapa also taught there.

name_variants: Taktsang Ritro; Tashi Choling, stag tshang ri khrod,
description: A Geluk monastery founded by Taktsang Lobzang Rabten in Amdo in 1713, and his primary seat. Lobzang Rabten founded Taktsang, at the age of thirty seven, at the command of The Fifth Panchen Lobzang Yeshe. One of its branches was Shardzong.

name_variants: Zhungpa Khangtsen
description: Khungpa Khamtsen is one of the sixteen residential houses of Sera Me Dratsang. It was founded by Jokpo Rinpoche. At its height Zhungpa Khamtsen was home to 400 monks from primarily the Amdo area; by 2002 less than two dozen were officially residing there.
Den Chokhor was a Geluk monastery in Kham.

name_variants: dimu si; demu si, kong po de mo, 第穆寺; 德穆寺; 德木寺
description: Demo monastery is a Geluk monastery in Kongpo. It was the seat of the Demo tulkus, who later had their seat at Tengyeling in Lhasa, where they were among the incarnations empowered to act as Regents of the Dalai Lamas.

Gangri Tokar is a mountain containing a hermitage comprised of numerous caves associated with Lonchenpa Drime Ozer, who resided there and wrote several of his major works while there. It is located above Shukseb Monastery to the south of Lhasa. The deity Dorje Pakmo (Vajravārāhī) is said to be visible from the mountain ridge itself.

Sani is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Sani Village in Zanskar, Ladakh. As it is said to predate the activites of Rinchen Zangpo, it is often considered the oldest religious site in Ladakh. The monastery was built around the famous Kanika Stupa and is named for the Kushan Emperor Kanishka. Sani is dedicated to Padmasambhava, who is said to have meditated at the site. There is an adjoining temple that is dedicated to Naropa, who is also said to have been at the site.
Taklung Drilung is a hermitage above Taklung Monastery.
Nyakla Gar is a Nyingma monastery in Gonjo, Kham.

Karchung Doring is a stone pillar within Karchung Monastery, founded by King Tride Songtsen, also known as Senalek, in the early ninth century. Along with the stone pillar, he erected stupas in each of the temple's four directions. The ruins of Karchung lay just outside Lhasa city.
Shukchung is a small monastery in Dzamtang, Amdo. It is connected to the Kagyu tradition, and the Northern Treasures tradition of the Nyingma.

name_variants: rongge si
description: Dzonggo was a royal religious center of the nearby kingdom of Ling, founded around the 19th century, and affiliated with the Nyingma tradition. It should not be confused with the Sakya Dzonggo Monastery in Yushu.
Lhopa Khamtsen is one of the seventeen residential houses of Sera Je Monastery. It is known for producing highly learned lamas, including Longdol Lama, who resided there in the 18th century.

name_variants: Khorlodong; Dechen Sangngak Khorlodong, khor lo gdong dgon; bde chen gsang snangs 'khor lo gdong ,
description: Khordong Monastery is a Nyingma monastery in Kham in the Trehor region, which is present day Kanze in Sichuan province. It was the seat of Terchen Nuden Dorje, an important master of the Jangter tradition in the Golok of his times as well as a prolific treasure revealer. Tradition holds that the monastery was founded by Nubchen Sanggye Yeshe, one of the five disciples of Padmasambhava, although Sanggye Yeshe lived in the ninth century and Khordong is said to have been founded in the twelfth century. The Khordong Monastery in Siliguri, India, was built by Khordong Terchen Tulku Chhimed Rigdzin Rinpoche.

Nyetang Mokchok is a Geluk monastery in Chushur county of central Tibet.  Founded in the twelfth century by Mokchok Rinchen Tsondru as a Shangpa Kagyu institution, it was convered to Geluk around the fifteenth century and was later considered a branch of Drepung Monastery. In 1959 it had 8 monks

name_variants: Golok Zhichen; Zhichen Kharmar Sangngak Tengyeling, mgo log gzhi chen dgon; gzhi chen mkhar dmar gsang sngags bstan rgyas gling ,
description: A Nyingma monastery in Golok founded by Lingzhak Orgyen Lhundrub. It is one of the eight main branch monasteries of Katok Monastery and the seat of the Zhichen Vairo line.
Shukjung is a small Nyingma Monastery in Golok. A branch of Khordong Monastery, it follows the Northern Treasures tradition.

wylie_name: baH gnas bsam gtan bshad sgrub bst
name_variants: Bahne, be zur dgon pa; dri so dgon pa ,
description: Baḥne is a small Nyingma monaster in Nyakchuka, Amdo. It was converted from a Kagyu monastery in the early eighteenth century.

name_variants: , ba' grub pa dgon o rgyan theg mchog gling ,
description: Batang Drubgon is a fifteenth-century Nyingma monastery in Batang. It follows the Northern Treasures tradition.

name_variants: , dar mdo rdo rje brag dgon ,
description: Do Dorje Drak is a Nyingma monastery in Dartsedo (Kangding), Kham. It was founded in 1564 as the house monastery of the Chakla family that ruled the region.

name_variants: , ol dga' sle lung dgon ,
description: Lelung Monastery, the seat of the Lelung Jedrung incarnations, is a small Geluk monastery to the east of Tsetang.

name_variants: Tsang Chumik Ringmo; qumi si, gtsang chu mig ring mo ,
description: Chumik is a Sakya monastery in Tsang founded in the eleventh century by students of Loton Dorje Wangchuk. It was the seat of the translator Jangchub Tsemo.

name_variants: Bakha Sangngak Choling
description: Bakha is a Nyingma monastery in Powo. It is the seat of the Bakha Tulkus, a lineage which is said to begin with the infant born to Princess Wencheng Kongjo and Gar Tongsten.

wylie_name: yang le shod kyi brag phug
description: Yanglesho is on of two caved in Pharping, Nepal, said to be where Padmasambhava engaged in Vajrakīla practices and subdued four troublesome Se goddesses. It is considered the "lower cave" of Pharping, in contrast to the Asura Cave, known as the "upper cave."

name_variants: Anjia si,
description: Anja is a Geluk hermitage founded in 1787. At some point it was damaged by a fire. In 1945 it was renovated by the local population. It was considered a branch of Kumbum although according to Stewart Smith's survey of Amdo monasteries, as of 2010 approximately 10 monks from Jyegu Dondrub Ling in Kham have been residing there.

wylie_name: ru dam yang dben gshin rje sgrub phug
description: The Yamāntaka Cave at Dzogchen monastery is where Dza Patrul Rinpoche composed Words of My Perfect Teacher. Pema Tekchok Loden spent decades in retreat after his term as the Twentieth Abbot of Śrī Siṃha College.

wylie_name: gtsang gi phung po ri bo che
description: Pungpo Riwoche is a Nyingma monastery near the Shang Valley in Tsang. It is located at one of the main sacred mountains of Central Tibet. Yungton Dorje Pel resided there. A monastery was formally established in the seventeenth century by the Fifth Dalai Lama at the long-standing sacred site.
Khardo is a Sakya monastery in Derge. It was originally a Nyingma monastery named Kharmarpo (mkhar dmar po) and converted in the fifteenth century.

Kyodrak is a Barom Kagyu monastery in Yushu. It was initially founded as a place of practice in 1361 by Langrepa Drakpa Gyeltsen, a disciple of Lha Repa Tsundru Pelwa. In 1785 Tsoknyi Wozer built an assembly hall, greatly expanding the monastery on instructions given to him by the Thirteenth Karmapa Dudul Dorje. It was destroyed during the Cultural Revolution but has been rebuilt.

name_variants: lanzhong si,
description: Lhadrang is a Nyingma monastery in Derge. It was founded in 1616 by Konchok Tendzin with support of the Derge king Jampa Puntsok.
Mendong is a small Karma Kagyu monastery in western Tibet in present-day Tsochen county. It was founded in 1808 by Mendongpa Karma Ngedon. It is a branch of Tsurpu.

name_variants: Ganden Namgyel Ling, dga' ldan rnam rgyal gling ,
description: Namgyel Ling is a small Karma Kagyu monastery in northern Derge. Zhuchen Tsultrim Rinchen wrote an inventory of the monastery in 1763.
Pangpuk is a Karma Kagyu monastery south of Litang.
Yamalung is a Padmasambhava site near Samye. It was an important treasure site of Terdak Lingpa.

wylie_name: nges don mdo snags chos 'khor gling
description: Ngedon Dongak Chokhor Ling was a hermitage in Serta founded by Khenchen Choying Khyabdel in 1979. On October 29, 2010 it was re-established as a permanent structure with the support of Tarthang Tulku.
Pemayangtse is a Nyingma monastery in Sikkim. It was founded in the seventeenth century by Lhatsun Namkha Jigme (1597-1650), who is said to have opened the beyul, or hidden land, of Sikkim.
Rinpung is a Bon monastery in Sharkhok, southern Amdo.

name_variants: , mda' chen g.yung drung bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling; shel phug skyang tshang ,
description: Dachen is a Bon monastery in the the Dzoge region of Amdo that is said to date to 1081. It is divided between an upper and lower lineage, with separate lists of masters. It was damaged and looted during the cultural revolution and officially reopened in 1982.
Samdrub is a Bon monastery in southern Amdo.

name_variants: , snang zhig lcags mdud bkra shis g.yung drung; snang zhig dgon ,
description: Nateng is a Bon monastery in Sharkhok, southern Amdo.
Gyarong Khamtsen is a monastic residence house at Drepung Losaling College, primarily for monks from the Gyarong region of Amdo.

Dranang Jampa Ling is a Geluk monastery in Dranang, central Tibet. It was established in the fifteenth century by Lhundrub Tashi, a descendent of Tonmi Sambhota. It was well known for a large stupa, which is said to have been the largest in Tibet. It contained murals by Jamyang Khyentse Wangchuk who established the Khyenri style of painting. Badly damaged in the 1960's in recent decades the complex has been reconstructed. It was affiliated with Drepung Gomang College.

name_variants: , KiH lung ,
description: Kilung Monastery in Sershul County was founded in the late 1780s by Jigme Ngotsar Gyatso, on the instruction of his teacher Jigme Lingpa, with the support of Derge queen Tsewang Lhamo.
Ney is a Geluk convent near Lhasa. It was established in the eleventh century as a Kadam monastery by Chennga Tsultrim Bar.
Wosel is a Geluk Monastery in Taktse, near Lhasa. It was established in the eleventh century by Chennga Tsultrim Bar.
Tsendro is a small Kadam monastery in Tolung. It was established in the eleventh century by Tolungpa Rinchen Nyingpo.

Zhok Gurmon is a Geluk monastery in Penpo near Lhasa that was founded in the late thirteenth century by Ga Lotsawa Namgyel Dorje, a master of Vajrabhairava. It was initially a Kagyu monastery and was converted to the Geluk tradition in the seventeenth century. It was managed by the Tse Yigtsang, the Ecclesiastical Office of the Potala.

Ngonga Choding is a Geluk Monastery in the Shang region of northern Tsang. It was initially a Nyingma monastery, founded some time in the early sixteenth century, and converted soon after, in the mid seventeenth century.
Tashi Lhapuk is a Geluk monastery in the Yushu region of Kham.

wylie_name: chab mdo sgrol ma lha khang
description: Chamdo Drolma Lhakhang is located in present day Lhorong county in Kham. According to Gyurme Dorje's Footprint Guide, it was established in 1193 by a student of the First Karmapa. Grushke notes that monastery foundations date to the eighteenth century. It was the seat of Akong Rinpoche, the close friend and collaborator of the Eleventh Trungpa Rinpoche.

name_variants: Dangkhar Tashi Chöling; Dhankar Monastery; Lagope, lags phel; lags spel; lags sgo spe; la mgo spe; la go pe; la go dpe; la go spe; la go spal; la mgo; la ’go; lags spe; legs sgo spe; legs sgo spel; legs spe; legs spel; brag mkhar bkra shis chos gling, , धनकर मोनेस्ट्री, ,
description:
Dangkhar Tashi Choling, previously known as Lagope Monastery, is a Gelukpa monastery in Dangkhar, the former capital of the Spiti Valley. A hermitage seems to have predated the enlargement and conversion of the complex into a Gelukpa monastery by the monk Sanggye Wozer, a native of Rangrik in Spiti, in 1617. Local archives attest that King Khri Namgyel Drakpa Zangpo De and the queen of Guge, together with the Fourth Panchen Lama Lobzang Chokyi Gyeltsen, laid down the economic basis of the new monastic community by granting ecclesiastical estates.

The monastic community of Lagope/Dangkhar Tashi Choling is traditionally comprised of four monastic congregations composed of monks from the villages of Lhalung, Upper Mane, Lower Mane, and Dangkhar. In 1655, a monk from Dangkhar named Pelden Gyeltsen was enthroned as the Fortieth Ganden Tripa.

Yannick Laurent

Samye Ling is a Karma Kagyu temple and dharma center in Dumfries, Scotland. It was initially a Theravadin Buddhist center, Johnstone House Contemplative Community, built around an old hunting lodge by a Canadian Theravadin monk named Ananda Bodhi (born Leslie George Dawson, 1931-2003, and later known as Namgyal Rinpoche). In 1967 it was taken over by Chogyam Trungpa and Akhon Rinpoche, who converted it to the Karma Kagyu tradition. It is currently administered as part of Akong Rinpoche's ROKPA Trust.

name_variants: Taktok; Takthok; Tak Tok,
description: Daktok Chokhor Pemaling was founded in the eighteenth century around a Padmasambhava meditation cave by a former Ladakhi court official named Kunga Puntsok, who was ordained by Katok Rigdzin Tsewang Norbu, The cave had been developed in the seventeenth century by Drubtob Pema Trinle, who had come to Ladakh to spread the Northern Treasures tradition. It operates as a branch of Dorje Drak Monastery in Tibet, the main seat of the Jangter tradition, and is the only major Nyingma monastery in Ladakh.

Gyama Rinchen Gang is a Geluk monastery in Meldro Gunkar region of central Tibet. It was founded as a Kadam monastery in 1118 by Gyar Gomchenpo Zhonnu Drakpa and later enlarged by his nephew Sanggye Wonton. It served as the seat of the Gyama myriarchy under the Yuan rule of Tibet.
Riwo Dangchen is a Geluk monastery in Tsang. Khedrub Gelek Pelzang founded it in 1412.

Kamkam is a small monastery in the Meldro region of central Tibet. It was founded by Nyamme Tromzherwa in the twelfth century as a Kadam monastery and later converted to Geluk. It is considered a branch of Reting Monastery.

name_variants: Ridak
description: Ridrak was a Kagyu hermitage to the northeast of Kanze in Kham. It was originally associated with a monastery that was destroyed in the seventeenth century, and continued to function through to the second half of the twentieth century. It was the birthplace of Kalu Rinpoche in an area well-known for its abundance of medicinal plants.

name_variants: Galingteng, sga len dgon; sga gling steng ,
description: Galenteng is a Sakya monastery in Derge. It was initially established as a Nyingma monastery in 1005 by Lhalung Pelgyi Dorje, then later restored and converted to Drukpa Kagyu by Lingrepa. It became a Sakya monastery in the thirteenth century, converted by Ga Anyen Dampa Kunga Drakpa.

Matho Gonpa is located in the village of Matho in Ladakh. A Sakya institution, it was founded in 1410. There are two oracles associated with the monastery and a well known oracle festival held around losar, or the lunar new year.

wylie_name: dpe thub dga' ldan dar rgyas gling dgon pa
name_variants: Petub Ganden Dargye Ling
description: Spituk, a Geluk monastery in Leh, Ladakh, was founded in the fifteenth century on the site of an earlier monastery founded in the 11th century. It is considered the first Geluk monastery in Ladakh. According to tradition, a disciple of the Buddha visited the region and prophesied a monastery on the location, which at the time was covered by water.

name_variants: Sumur Samtenling; Samstaling
description: Samstanling, a Geluk monastery in Ladakh, is located in the village of Sumur in the Nubra Valley. It was founded by Tsultrim Nyima in 1848. The Nineteenth Bakula Rinpoche spent winters at Samstanling when he was a child.
Petub Khamtsen, a residential house of Loseling College of Drepung Monastery, was home to Ladakhi monks. The Eighteenth and Nineteenth Bakula Rinpoches lived at Petub Khamsten.

wylie_name: dpe thub bstan rgyas chos 'khor gling dgon pa
name_variants: Petub Khiid; Pethub Stangey Choskhor Ling Khiid; Bakula Rinpoche Khiid; Betüv Khiid
description: Pethub Stangey Choskhorling, commonly known as Betub Khiid and Bakula Rinpoche's Monastery, is a Geluk monastery in Mongolia founded by the Nineteenth Bakula Rinpoche in 1999.

name_variants: Иволгинский дацан, Иволгинский дацан,
description: Ivolginsky Datsan is a Geluk Buddhist temple in the Republic of Buryatia, Russia. It was founded in either 1945 or 1946 (sources differ) with governmental and community support after a period of harsh religious repression in th 1930s. It housed Central Spiritual Administration of Buddhists of the Russian Federation and is considered a major center of Buddhist learning and practice in Russia.

name_variants: Kye; Ki; Kyi
description: Kyi is a Geluk monastery located in the Spiti Valley of Ladakh that is believed to have been founded eleventh century, possibly by Dromton. It was reconstituted in the fifteenth century under the patronage of King Nyima Drakpa by Sherab Zangpo.

name_variants: Pangen Gonpa; baige si, bsam gtan chos rdzong gling; paN rgan dgon ,
description: Bengen is a Karma Kagyu and Shangpa Kagyu monastery just outside of Denma near Kanze, in Kham. It was the seat of Kalu Rinpoche Karma Rangjung Kunkyab in Tibet. A new temple was constructed in recent years and the original ruins still exist nearby. The The subsequent Kalu incarnation is being educated in Sonada, which was founded in 1963.

wylie_name: bsam grub dar rgyas chos gling
name_variants: Samdrub Darjay Chöling Monastery
description: Sonada Monastery, Samdrub Darjay Chöling, is a monastery located in Darjeeling, India. It was founded in 1966 by Kalu Rinpoche in a formerly Geluk monastery. He established a three-year retreat center at Sonada. It served as Kalu Rinpoche's primary residence and as the international seat of the Shangpa Kagyu tradition. Kalu Rinpoche passed away at Sonada in 1989.

Diskit, a Geluk monastery in the Nubra Valley of Ladakh. Its founding is attributed Sherab Zangpo in the fifteenth century. It is believed to be the oldest monastery in Nubra containing a gathering hall, temples, shrines, and a school housing about 100 monks. It is also known for a large statue of Maitreya consecrated in 2010 by the Fourteenth Dalai Lama.

Charasa is located Charasa village in the Nubra Valley of Ladakh. Formerly a fortified settlement, it consists of palace and temple buildings. According to tradition is said to have been founded as a monastery by Sherab Zangpo.

name_variants: Wensa
description: Ensa is a Geluk monastery in the Nubra Valley of Ladakh. According to tradition, Sherab Zangpo (fifteenth century) meditated at this location, which later developed into a monastery. Archeological evidence suggests earlier activity at the site.
Tsazar is a monastery located near Zangla in Ladakh. It was founded by Sherab Zangpo in the fifteenth century.

name_variants: Tongde; Thongde
description: Stongdey is a Geluk monastery in the Zanskar region of Ladakh. According to tradition, this monastery was founded by Marpa in the eleventh century. It was visited by Sherab Zangpo in the fifteenth century.

Phuktal, currently a Geluk monastery located in the Zanskar region of Ladakh, was founded in the fifteenth century by Sherab Zangpo on the site of a hermitage established in the eleventh century by Pakpa Sherab. According to tradition, the location was also visted by numerous other masters including Padmasambhava and Marpa Lotsāwa.

name_variants: Kursha
description: Karsha is a monastery located in the Zanskar region of Ladakh. Padmasambhava is associated with the earliest foundations of the building while Lotsawa Pakpa Sherab is credited as founder in the eleventh century. Murals suggest a connection to structures built during the period of Rinchen Zangpo's activities. Sherab Zangpo is credited as rebuilding Karsha, presumably in the fifteenth century.

wylie_name: stag tshang lha mo kir+ti dgon
name_variants: Kirti Monastery Namgyel Dechen Ling, kirti dgon rnam rgyal bde chen ling ,
description: Takstang Lhamo Kīrti is one of two Geluk monasteries in Taktsang Lhamo, a town straddling the border between Gansu and Sichuan provinces. The location is considered sacred, as a deity is believed to reside in the nearby mountain and Padmasambhava is said to have eliminated demons from the space. Tāla Ngawang Pelzang built a hermitage at Taktsang Lhamo in 1713 that he later gave to the Fifth Kīrti. After this, it developed into a large monastery and one of the seats of the Kīrti incarnations.

Achung Namdzong is a Nyingma monastery in Qinghai, in present day Chentsa County. Situated within Khamra National Park, it is surrounded by native forests. It is associated with the protector deity Mesang, who, according to tradition, was given the site by Padmasambhava.

name_variants: , bo gangs dkar dgon ,
description: Bo Gangkar Monastery, also known as Khamsum Drakgon Monastery, is a Karma Kagyu monastery that was established in the twelfth century. It is the seat of the Gangkar Lamas. The Ninth Gangkar rebuilt and expanded it in the mid-twentieth century.

name_variants: skyid lung gsang sngags chos sde gling,
description: Kyilung Monastery is a branch of Katok. Do Khyentse lived there for some time in the early nineteenth century.
Kachok Monastery is a Nyingma monastery in Ngawa. It was a seat of Do Khyentse.
Minyak Kyernang is a Nyingma monastery in Teu, Kham. It was a seat of Do Khyentse.

name_variants: , gar nang dkar mdza' ri khrod ,
description: Kardza is a Nyingma monastery in the Dartsedo region. It was founded by Do Khyentse.
Lautang is a Nyingma monastery in Teu, Kham. It was a seat Dechen Rigpa Reltri.
Pema Rito is an important Nyingma hermitage site in Golok connected to Do Khyentse.
Tabka was a Kadam monastery in Penyul founded in the twelfth century by Tabka Darma Drak.
Trawakha was a Kadam monastery in the lower Lungsho valley. According to Katak Situ, it was founded by a man named Kambu Ale.
Tangsak was a Kadam monastery in the Penyul region of central Tibet. It was later converted to a Geluk institution.
Lekshe Nyida Ling was the monastic college at Shechen Monastery. It was established by Shechen Kongtrul in the early twentieth century.

Gampo Abbey is a Buddhist monastery on Cape Breton Island in Nova Scotia, Canada. It was founded by Pema Chödron in 1983, under the auspices of Chogyam Trungpa. Its current abbot is the Ninth Thrangu Rinpoche. The Stupa of Enlightenment contains relics of Trunpa.

Karmê Chöling is a dharma center in Barnet, Vermont, USA. It was founded in 1970 by Chogyam Trungpa on the site of a former dairy farm. It was the first of Trungpa's centers in America. The land was donated by Trungpa's students. The original name, Tail of the Tiger, was changed by the Sixteenth Karmapa in 1974. It was the site of Trungpa's cremation in 1987.
The Boulder Shambhala Center was established by Chogyam Trungpa in 1970 under the name Karma Dzong. In 1995 it became part of Shambhala International and was given its current name.

The Shambhala Mountain Center, in Red Feather Lake, Colorado, USA, was founded by Chogyam Trungpa in 1971 to serve as a residential facility for students and a location for retreats. It was initially named Rocky Mountain Dharma Center. Construction on the Great Stupa of Dharmakaya began in 1988. It contains relics of Chogyam Trungpa.

Yak Monastery is a Kagyu monastery located in Lhorong County, Kham. It is the seat of Dotrul Rinpoche and is affiliated with Katok. It contains brass sculptures, including one large one of Padmasambhava, in its main temple and has a mural gallery with paintings in the Karma Gadri style.

wylie_name: lha phu rmog lcog ri khrod
description: Lhapu Mokchok was located in the Shang Valley on and eastern branch of the Lhapu river. It was established by Mokchok Rinchen Tsondru in the twelfth century as a Shangpa Kagyu hermitage. It functioned as a nunnery in the twentieth century. The seat of the Mokchok incarnation was based at Nyetang Mokchok outside of Lhasa.

name_variants: Kagyu Kunkhyab Chuling; KKC,
description: Kagyu Kunchab Chuling is a dharma center in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada. Kalu Rinpoche established it in 1972 during his first visit to North America and was one of the first of many western dharma centers founded by Kalu Rinpoche. It was considered his seat in North America.

wylie_name: kun bzang bde chen 'od gsal gling
description: Kunzang Dechen Osel Ling is a retreat center on Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, Canada. It was established by Kalu Rinpoche in 1980, during his fourth visit to North America. It is associated with Kagyu Kunchab Chuling near Vancouver. It is considered the location of the first three-year retreat in North America.

name_variants: Kagyu Dzamling Kunkhyab,
description: Kagyu Dzamling Kunchab is a Shangpa Kagyu dharma center in New York City. Kalu Rinpoche established it during his second visit to North America, in 1975. It was initially located on 19th Street, later moving to its present location on Columbus Avenue. It is affiliated with Kagyu Thubten Choling, its retreat center in Wappingers Falls, NY.

Kagyu Droden Kunchab is a Shangpa Kagyu dharma center in the Height Ashbury neighborhood of San Francisco. Kalu Rinpoche established it in 1974, during his second visit to North America. It was among several early North American Shangpa Kagyu centers founded by Kalu Rinpoche and directed by Lama Lodru, Kalu Rinpoche's student.

Karma Rimay O Sal Ling is a Shangpa Kagyu and Karma Kagyu dharma center on Maui, Hawai'i. Kalu Rinpoche established it in 1974 during his second visit to North America. The first resident teacher was Lama Tezin, who filled this role until his death in 2001.

Kagyu Changchub Chuling is a Shangpa Kagyu dharma center in Portland, Oregon. Kalu Rinpoche established the center during a visit to Portland in 1976. Its current location was purchased in 1981. In 2001, land outside the city was purchased for the purpose of supporting retreats.

Kagyu Shenpen Kunchab is a Shangpa and Karma Kagyu dharma center in Sante Fe, New Mexico. Kalu Rinpoche established it in 1975 during his second visit to North America. Construction on a stūpa said to contain relics of the Buddha was initiated in 1982 and was consecrecrated  in 1986. It is said to one of the largest stūpas in North America.

Kagyu Dzong is a Kagyu dharma center in Paris, France adjacent to the Pagode du bois de Vincennes. Kalu Rinpoche laid the foundation in May 1983, and returned to consecrate the completed building in January, 1985. Kalu Rinpoche appointed his student, Lama Gyurme, director of the center.

name_variants: Dashang Kagyu Ling,
description: Dashang Kagyu Ling is a dharma center and retreat center in La Boulaye, Burgundy, France. Kalu Rinpoche founded it in 1974. In 1980, Kalu Rinpoche consecrecrated one of the first stūpas in Europe at Kagu Ling. In 1987 a large temple, popularly known as the Temple of One Thousand Buddhas, was constructed.

Kagyu Thubten Chöling (KTC) is a dharma center in Wappinger Falls, New York. Kalu Rinpoche and his disciple Lama Norlha established it in 1978 during Kalu's third visit to North America. A retreat center was added in 1980. Three-year retreats have been hosted at KTC since 1982.

name_variants: Palpung Sherabling, dpal spung shes rab gling ,
description: Sherabling is a Karma Kagyu monastery in Bir, Himachel Pradesh, India. It is the seat of the the Twelfth Tai Situ, who established it in 1975. It houses 1000 monks, maintains a monastic curriculum, and hosts three-year retreats. Palpung Yeshe Rabgyeling Nun Monastery is an affiliated nunnery located near Manali.

Gagu is a hermitage up the Dopu Valley from Dzongsar Monastery. It was primarily developed by Ga Lama Jamyang Gyeltsen in the early twentieth century. Dezhung Rinpoche studied with Ga Lama there in the 1920s.
Sengchen Namdrak is a small Nyingma monastery below the Sengchen Namdrak caves on the west bank of the Drichu River to the west of Derge.

Garpa Ritro is a small hermitage between Lhasa and Drak Yerpa. Its origin is not currently recorded, but it is known as the residence of the Ling incarnations from at least the time of the Fifth Ling. The Vajrabhairava sādhana he composed was published at the associated Garpa Ritro Printing House (established circa 1875) at the hermitage.

Upon arriving in India from Tibet, monks of Drepung were temporarily housed with Buddhist monks from all schools and monasteries at Tosam Tardo Ling at Buxa Duar from 1959-1969. The monks were later relocated to South India in 1969, where they reestablished the Drepung Monastery in exile. Modelled after Drepung, one of the three great monasteries in central Tibet, its monastic colleges Loseling and Gomang are attended by thousands of monks.

name_variants: Tritok Khang; Tripa House; Trithok Khang
description: Ganden Tritok Khang, is located at Ganden Monastery in-exile, in Karnataka, India. It is the office of the Throne Holders, or Tripa, of Ganden Monastery, who, as successors to Tsongkhapa Lobzang Drakpa, are considered the leaders of the Geluk tradition.

name_variants: Gaden Phelgye Ling,
description: Ganden Pelgye Ling is a Geluk monastery in Bodh Gaya, India. It was founded in 1938. In 1978 a renovated protector chapel was consecrated by the Sixth Ling Rinpoche, who was appointed abbot in 1965. Since 1998, it is considered a branch of Namgyel Monastery.

name_variants: Tibet-Institut Rikon; Kloster zum Rad der Lehre,
description: Chokhor Ling is a monastery in Rikon, Switzerland that was consecrated in 1968 by Trijang Rinpoche and Ling Rinpoche, the two principal tutors of the Fourteenth Dalai Lama. Among the first Tibetan Buddhist monastic communities in the West, it is the first Tibetan Buddhist monastery in Switzerland and western Europe.

Ganden Monastery in exile, located in Karnataka in southern India, was established in 1969 by monastic communities who had been temporarily settled at Tosam Tardo Ling in Buxa Duar. Shartse and Jangtse monastic colleges were re-established and are attended by thousands of students.

Ling Khamtsen in-exile is the residence of the Ling incarnation at Drepung Monastery in Karnataka, southern India. It was founded in 1974 and was consecrated by the Fourteenth Dalai Lama. The Sixth Ling Rinpoche briefly resided at the residence in Mundgod, though his primary home was at Chopra House in Dharamsala.

name_variants: Pomra Khamtsen; Bompora Khamtsen, spom ra ,
description: Pombora Khamtsen was one of the larger monastic residence houses at Sera Me monastic college of Sera Monastery. Traditionally home to monks from Litang, Mili, Gyeltang, Samling and Gangling regions of Kham, some of its famous residents included the Sixty Fifth Ganden Tripa Gendun Tsultrim.

wylie_name: sngo phu yang can phun tshogs gling
name_variants: Ganden Yangpachen, dga' ldan yangs pa can ,
description: Ngopu is a Geluk monastery in Jang. It was founded in 1574 as a Kagyu monastery, and converted in 1674.

wylie_name: sbom rag dga' ldan don grub gling
name_variants: Trungtrung Tsogang, khrung khrung mtsho sgang ,
description: Bomrak is a Geluk monastery in Jang. It was founded around 1575 as a Kagyu monastery, and converted in 1677 to the Geluk tradition.

name_variants: Sangchen Tashi Choling, gsang chen bkra shis gling ,
description: Adu Yakgo was a Geluk monastery in Ngawa. It was established in 1395 by Tsongkhapa's disciple Tsakho Ngawang Drakpa.

name_variants: Ganden Datsang Lhundrub Ling, dga' ldan da tshang lhun grub gling,
description: Datsang is a Geluk monastery in Gyarong. It was founded in 1414 by Tsakho Ngawang Drakpa, a disciple of Tsongkhapa.
Damtok is a large Sakya monastery in the Yushu region of northwestern Kham.

name_variants: Kelzang Peljor Ling, skal bzang dpal 'byor gling ,
description: Tridu Kelzang is a Sakya monastery in the Yushu region of northwestern Kham.

Serjong is a Sakya monastery in the Kuse region of Derge. Famous for its printing house, it was established by Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen in the thirteenth century. In the mid-twentieth century it was the seat of Khenpo Appey Yonten Zangpo. Its monastic college followed the curriculum of thirteen Sanskrit classics devised by Khenpo Zhenga.

name_variants: , go zi dgon ,
description: Guzi is a small Sakya monastery in the Lingtsang region of Derge. It was founded in the thirteenth century by Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen.

name_variants: Mu Takpoling
description: Takmo Lingkha is a Sakya monastery in the Mu valley. It was founded by Muchen Konchok Gyeltsen in 1436. Lama Dampa gave the Lamdre there in 1930s or 1940s.

wylie_name: ba' ra brag don grub lding
name_variants: Shang Bara Drakkar, shangs 'ba' ra brag dkar ,
description: Baradrak Dondrubding is a monastery belonging to the Barawa Kagyu tradition in the Shang Valley. It was established by Barawa Gelek Pelzang in the fourteenth century.
Dzinda Neseb is a hermitage in the Ga region of northern Kham. It was established in the mid-nineteenth century by Ngawang Shedrub Gyatso and is associated with Tarlam Monastery in Jyekundo.
Dzonyak Samdrub is a small Sakya monastery in the Ga region of Yushu, Kham. The Third Dezhung Rinpoche studied there in the early 1920s under Gaton Ngawang Lekpa.
Tubten is a Sakya monastery in Yushu, Kham. It was originally a Bon institution, and converted in the thirteenth century.
Dzonggo is a Sakya monastery in Yushu. It should not be confused with the Nyingma Dzonggo Monastery in Derge.

Jasa Lhakhang, a temple outside of Tsetang, was in existence by the ninth century. It contains an image of Vairocana that is said to have been sponsored by Pelkortsen, Langdarma's grandson. Over the centuries it has been associated with the Kadam tradition and later the Sakya.
Dechen Chokhor is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in southern Tibet. It was founded in the sixteenth century by the First Dechen Yongdzin, Ngawang Zangpo.

name_variants: Karmé Chökhor Dechen Ling,
description: Karmé Chökhor Dechen Ling is a nunnery above Rumtek in Sikkim that was initiated by the Sixteenth Karmapa in the 1970s. It was completed by 1985.

Ka-Nying Shedrub Ling is a monastery located near the Boudha stūpa in Kathmandu, Nepal. It was established on orders of the Sixteenth Karmapa to Tulku Urgyen Rinpoche, whose sons, Chokyi Nyima and Chokling, took on leadership roles in the institution.

name_variants: Karma Mingyur Ling
description: Karma Migyur Ling is a Karma Kagyu Buddhist center in Montchardon, France. It was founded in 1975 by the Sixteenth Karmapa, Rangjung Rigpai Dorje. Lama Teunsang was appointed spiritual director in 1976. It was built on land donated by a student of Kalu Rinpoche, Jean-Pierre Schnetzler.

Dhagpo Kagyu Ling is a Kagyu Buddhist center in Dordogne, France that was founded in 1975 under the direction of Lamas Gendun and Jigme Tsewang on the orders of the Sixteenth Karmapa. It is considered the European seat of the Karma Kagyu tradition under Trinley Thaye Dorje, one of two claimants to the title of Seventeenth Karmapa.

Buddhistisk Center København, or Buddhist Center Copenhagen, was founded in 1972 by Olé and Hannah Nydahl in Copenhagen, Denmark. After a visit from the Sixteenth Karmapa, the center made plans to move to a larger facility, with the move completed by 1975.

Karma Triyana Dharmachakra is a Karma Kagyu monastery and Buddhist center located in Woodstock, New York. It was founded in with the sponsorship of Dr. C. T. Shen (1913-2007) in 1976 by the Sixteenth Karmapa. It is considered the North American seat of the Karma Kagyu tradition under Ogyen Trinley Dorje, one of two claimants to the title of Seventeenth Karmapa.

Khampagar is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery founded in 1958 by the Eighth Kamtrul Rinpoche, who fled the seat of the Khamtrul incarnation at Khampa Gar monastery in Chamdo as a result of the Communist occupation of Tibet. Originally based in Kalimpong, the exile monastery moved to its present location in Tashi Jong, Himachal Pradesh, India in 1969.

wylie_name: karma grub brgyud dar rgyas gling
name_variants: Tilokpur Nunnery
description: Karma Drubgyu Thargay Ling is a Karma Kagyu nunnery located in Himachal Pradesh, northern India. It was founded in the 1960's by the British-born nun Fredi Bedi, known also as Sister Palmo, under the guidance of the Sixteenth Karmapa.
Karma Drupgyud Choeling is a Kagyu monastery in Ladakh that was founded by the Sixteenth Karmapa, who blessed the site in 1967. In 1975 construction began and it was completed in 1976.

wylie_name: phags zhing zhwa dmar dgon pa
description: Karma Raja Mahavihara is a Karma Kagyu monastery at the Swayambhunath stupa in Kathmandu, Nepal. The first structure is attributed to the Fourth Shamar Rinpoche. The Sixteenth Karmapa stayed at the monastery for several months during the 1969-1970 winter. At this time the Sixteenth Karmapa initiated its renovation. It was badly damaged in the 2015 earthquake.

wylie_name: rta'u gsang sngags mchog grub gling
description: Tawu is  Drigung Kagyu monastery in Nyemo, central Tibet. It was founded in 1612 by the twenty-second abbot of Drigung Monastery, Tashi Puntsok.

name_variants: Tsangsar Lhalam Monastery; Lhalam Wosel Ling, gtsang sar lha lam dgon; lha lam 'od gsal gling ,
description: Tsangsar Lhalam is a Barom Kagyu monastery in Nangchen that was founded by a lama named Tsangsar Karma Tenkyong in 1638. It was a family monastery of a branch of the Tsangsar family headed by Orgyen Chopel, the husband of Konchok Peldron, Chokgyur Lingpa's daughter. Their children included Samten Gyatso, Tersey Tulku, Lama Sangngak, and Chime Dorje, the father of Tulku Urgyen. Due to their influence, the monastery became a center for the practice of the revelations of Chokyur Lingpa, known as the Chokling Tersar.

name_variants: Tsangsar Lachab; Lachab Jangchub Norzin Choling, bla khyab byang chub nor 'dzin chos gling ,
description:
Lachab is a Barom Kagyu monastery in Nangchen. It was traditionally led by the Tsangsar family, and so is also known as Tsangsar Lachab. It was the seat of Samten Gyatso and his nephew, Tulku Urgyen. 

Coordinates kindly provided by Gerd Manusch.

name_variants: Jar Sang-ngak Choling, byar gsang sngags chos gling ,
description: Sangngak Choling is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in southern Tibet near the Indian and Bhutanese borders. It was founded in 1515 by Pema Karpo and expanded by the Fifth Drukchen.
Taser is a Kagyu nunnery in Nyemo. At the time of a 2000 survey, there were 33 nuns in residence.
Ru Gonsar, located in Nyemo, was founded by Nyemo Kuzhang Rinchen Tashi Gyeltsen of the Zhalu tradition. It later became associated with Hardong Khamtsem of Drepung Gomang College.

wylie_name: rgyud stod grwa tshang gsang chen rdo rje gling
name_variants: Labrang Upper Tantric College
description:
Gyuto Dratsang Sangchen Dorje Ling (rgyud stod grwa tshang gsang chen rdo rje gling), more popularly known as Gyuto Dratsang, meaning the ‘Upper Tantric College,’ is a monastic college for tantric studies at Labrang Tashikhyil (bla brang bkra shis 'khyil) Monastery. It is maintained that the college was founded by the Fifth Jamyang Zhepa, Yeshe Tenpai Gyaltsen ('jam dbyangs bzhad pa 05 ye shes bstan pa'i rgyal mtshan, 1916–1942), in 1928. In 1937, the Fifth Jamyang Zhepa and his brother, the Fourth Belmang, Jigme Tsultrim Namgyel (dbal mang 04 'jigs med tshul khrims rnam rgyal (1918(?)/1920–1957), traveled to Central Tibet. When they returned to Amdo in 1941, they brought along tantric masters from Gyuto Monastery (rgyud stod grwa tshang) in Lhasa. The Fifth Jamyang Zhepa then assigned his brother, the Fourth Belmang, to build the college infrastructure, including the assembly hall and ritual chapels, which were completed within two years. The college was formally inaugurated in 1943.

The college follows the tantric tradition and practice and adopts the same academic curriculum and administrative system as Gyuto Monastery of Lhasa, Central Tibet. It thus assumes the eponym from the central tantric monastery in Lhasa

Gyuto Dratsang is one of the four Tantric colleges of Labrang Monastery, the others being Gyume Dratsang (rgyud smad grwa tshang), Kyedor Dratsang (kya'i rdor grwa tshang), and Dukhor Dratsang (dus 'khor grwa tshang). Labrang also has two non-tantric monastic colleges—Tsenyi Dratsang (mtshan nyid grwa tshang) and Menpa Dratsang (sman pa grwa tshang).

wylie_name: bla brang rgyud smad grwa tshang
name_variants: Labrang Lower Tantric College
description:
Gyume Dratsang (rgyud smad grwa tshang) is a monastic college for tantric studies at Labrang Tashikhyil (bla brang bkra shis 'khyil) Monastery. It was established by the First Jamyang Zhepa, Jamyang Zhepai Dorje ('jam dbyangs bzhad pa 01 'jam dbyangs bzhad pa'i rdo rje, 1648–1721/1722), in 1716. Some scholars, however, date the establishment of the college as 1719.

The college follows the tantric tradition and practice and adopts the academic curriculum and administrative system of Gyume Monastery (rgyud smad grwa tshang) of Lhasa, Central Tibet. It thus assumes the eponym from the central tantric monastery in Lhasa.

Gyume Dratsang is one of the four Tantric colleges of Labrang Monastery, the others being Gyuto Dratsang (rgyud stod grwa tshang), Kyedor Dratsang (kya'i rdor grwa tshang), and Dukhor Dratsang (dus 'khor grwa tshang). Labrang also has two non-tantric monastic colleges—Tsenyi Dratsang (mtshan nyid grwa tshang) and Menpa Dratsang (sman pa grwa tshang).

name_variants: Ghoom Yiga Choling,
description: Yiga Choeling is a Geluk monastery located in Ghum, Darjeeling, in northern India. It was founded by Geshe Sherab Gyatso.

wylie_name: sgrub sde gsang sngag rdo rje gdan
name_variants: Yukzom; Drubde Sang Ngak Dorje Den
description: Dubdi, also known as Yukzom, is a Nyingma monastery in Sikkim that was founded in 1701 during the reign of Chakdor Namgyal, the Third King of Sikkim.

name_variants: Sanga Choeling
description: Sangngak Choling is a Nyingma monastery in Sikkim that was founded in the seventeenth century.
Doling is a Nyingma monastery in Sikkim that was founded in the eighteenth century.

wylie_name: ra langs karma rab brtan gling
name_variants: Ralang; Old Ralang Monastery
description: Karma Rabten Ling, also known as Old Ralong, is a Karma Kagyu monastery located in Sikkim. It was founded in the eighteenth century. There are two monasteries at Ralong, one called Old Ralong and a new monastery called Ralong Palchen Choling that was built in 1995

name_variants: , spa gro 'brang rgyas kha ,
description: Dranggyekha is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Paro, Bhutan. It was established in the fourteenth century by Barawa Gyeltsen Pelzang.
Do Chorten is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Bhutan. In the fourteenth century it was given to Barawa Gyeltsen Pelzang, but has since reverted to the Drukpa tradition.

Tsangsar Namgon was a Barom Kagyu monastery in Nangchen. It was one of three monasteries controlled by the Tsangsar family, alongside Lachab and Lhalam. It was founded by Tsangsar Sonam Yeshe, the previous incarnation of Chime Dorje. 

Map coordinates kindly contributed by Gerd Manusch.

name_variants: Gebchak; Gebchak; Gebchag, ge bcags ,
description:
Gechak is a Nyingma nunnery in Nangchen that was founded in 1893 by the First Gechak Rinpoche, Tsangyang Gyatso, on the suggestion of the First Tsoknyi, Pema Drime Wozer. 

Coordinates kindly provided by Gerd Manusch.

name_variants: Fortress Peak; Raja Dzong,
description:
Dzonggo Ling, known in English as Fortress Peak, is a hermitage associated with Lachab Monastery. It was a practice site of members of Tulku Urgyen's family as well as his previous incarnation. 

Coordinates kindly provided by Gerd Manusch.
Tergar Ösel Ling is a retreat center in Kathmandu Valley. Built by Tulku Urgyen in the early 1990s initially for Tsoknyi Rinpoche, it is now under the direction of his brother, Mingyur Rinpoche.
Pema Khyung Dzong is a hermitage above Tsurpu Monastery. It was first used by the Second Karmapa, Karma Pakshi. Many masters since have done retreat there, including Tulku Urgyen.

Benchen is a Kagyu monastery in the Swayambhu area of Kathmandu, Nepal, that was founded in 1987 and was led by Sangye Nyenpa Rinpoche and Tenga Rinpoche. There are several branch monasteries throughout the Himalayas and one in Europe, as well as the original Benchen Monastery located in Kham.
Pema Choling is a monastery in Nubri, Nepal. It was the monastery and ngakpa community of Lama Tashi Dorje, a contemporary of Tulku Urgyen. Tulku Urgyen stayed at Pema Choling for five years.

name_variants: Nyemo Chode Monastery, snye mo chos sde ,
description: Jekhar Chode, also known as Nyemo Chode, is a Bodong monastery in Nyemo. According to BDRC it was posibly founded in the tenth century by a lama named Jigme Drakpa.

name_variants: Tashi Choling, bkra shis chos gling ,
description: Drapu Choling, also known as Tashi Choling, is a Barawa Kagyu monastery in Kyirong. It was established on the site of a village temple in the sixteenth century by Namkha Dorje, who spread the Barawa tradition in the region. It was controlled by the Jampel Dechenling family since the early eighteenth century, and traditionally had close ties with Kagyu Gonsar in the Chumbi valley. It was destroyed in the Cultural Revolution and has not been rebuilt; a new monastery was built in Dharamsala by the Jampel Dechenling family and named Tashi Choling.
Tashi Choling is a Barawa monastery in Dharamsala. Jetsun Tenzin Norbu, a member of the Jampel Dechen Lingpa family of Kyirong, established it in 1984.

name_variants: Kagon Tshechokling; Dromo Kagyu; Ganden Tengye Ling, bka' dgon tshe mchog gling; gro mo bka' brgyud; dga' ldan bstan gyas gling,
description: Kagyu Gonsar is a Barawa monastery in the Chumbi valley. It was established by Drubchok Ngawang Donden either at the end of the seventeenth century or at the beginning of the eighteenth. It was initially a branch monastery of the nearby Tsamdrak Monastery, which had been earlier established by Tenzin Nyida, who was the first reincarnation of Konchok Gyeltsen and the first to bear the title of Kagyu Tulku. As the larger of the two, Kagyu Gonsar became the dominant institution in the area, and became the main seat of the Kagyu Tulku incarnations. In the second half of the nineteenth century the monastery was given the name Ganden Tengye Ling by the Twelfth Dalai Lama, but it remained a Barawa Kagyu monastery.
Chakkyi Yangtse is a hermitage affiliated to Dondrubding Monastery. It was likely established by Barawa Tulku Namkha Gyeltsen in the early sixteenth century.

name_variants: Tsunmo Rinchentang, btsun mor rin chen thang ,
description: Chungtang Monastery is a Nyingma institution in northern Sikkim. It was first established as a Barawa Kagyu monastery by Konchok Gyeltsen in the seventeenth century and was converted in 1788, apparently after the local people rebelled against the head lama. It was rebuilt in 1968, using wood from the original monastery, and a statue of Konchok Gyeltsen was placed on the main altar in the 1980s. A small stūpa above the monastery honors its original founder.
Jangchub Chokhor Ling is a Karma Kagyu monastery in Denma that was founded by the First Sanggye Nyenpa in the late fifteenth century.
Tangkya is a Sakya monastery located in the Gonjo region of Kham. It is the seat of the Sendo Rinpoche.

name_variants: Mindrol Norbu Ling, thub bstan yongs 'dus dga' tshal brag mkhar smin grol nor bu gling,
description: Drakkar is a Nyingma monastery in Lhagang. It was established in 1254 by Karma Pakshi while en route to China. It was converted to the Nyingma tradition, as a branch of Dzogchen Monastery, in 1670.
Ganden Chokhor Ling is a Geluk monastery in the Yarlung Valley. It was established as a Kadam monastery in the twelfth century.

Lhalung Hermitage was founded in the nineteenth century by Shakya Yarpel, the eleventh Nechung Oracle, near a cave where Lhalung Pelgyi Dorje is said to have visited. Considered a branch of Nechung before 1959, it was associated with the Nyingma tradition. Drepung monks were formerly in residence there. It is located in the hills above Lhasa.

name_variants: , grwa ma dgon ,
description: Dramagang, also known as Drama Monastery, was established in the nineteenth century by Kunga Loden and expanded in 1859 by Ngawang Lekdrub. It fell into disrepair and was restored and reconsecrated in 1926 by Jamyang Chokyi Lodro, Samten Lodro, and Khenpo Chokyi Wozer. Dezhung Rinpoche studied there in the 1920s.

name_variants: , mdo srid ,
description: Dosib is a Sakya monastery in Jomda, Kham.
Dungdo is a Sakya monastery in Jomda, Kham.
Dzamtok is a Sakya monastery in Jomda, Kham.
Shangto is a Sakya monastery in the Derge region of Kham.

name_variants: , mgon gzigs rab brtan dgon; 'bri rgyud rab brtan dgon ,
description: Rabten is a Sakya monastery in Derge. It was fist established as a Bon monastery and converted in the thirteenth century by Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen.
Wara is a Sakya monastery in Jomda.

name_variants: Kharlek, mkhar legs ,
description: Khalek is a Nyingma hermitage in the Jomda region of Kham. It was established in the nineteenth century by a master named Khenpo Pema Sherab Zangpo.
Dogyu Tosam Ling is the monastic college at Dartang Monastery.

Sakya Monastery is a Sakya dharma center in Seattle, Washington. It was established in 1974 as Sakya Tegchen Choling by Dezhung Rinpoche and Sakya Dagchen Rinpoche, and moved to its current location, a former Presbyterian church, in 1984.

name_variants: Tarlam
description: Tharlam is a Sakya monastery in Boudhanath, Nepal. It was founded in the 1980s by Dezhung Rinpoche as the exile monastery of Tarlam Monastery in Jyekundo, Kham
Jetsun Sakya Center in New York City was established by Dezhung Rinpoche in 1977.

Rizong is a Geluk monastery in Ladakh that was founded in 1833 by Tsultrim Nyima, who is credited with its murals depicting the life of Śākyamuni. Rizong is known for its strict adherance to the vinaya.
Tashigang is a Geluk monastery in western Ngari. It was established in the eleventh century and was converted to the Geluk tradition in the seventeenth century.
Labu was a Geluk monastery in Yushu, in what is now Labu Town in Trindu County. It was established in 1419 by Gyeltsabje Darma Rinchen, whose incarnations were leading lamas of the monastery.

name_variants: Ganden Sang-ngak Yarpel Ling; Dulam; Tulam, dga' ldan gsang sngags yar 'phel gling ,
description: Terlam was a major Geluk monastery in Amdo.

Sera Monastery in exile was formally established in Bylakuppe in southern India in 1969. Sera monks intially resided at the refugee settlement at Buxa Duar, where monks from other monasteries lived before resettling in Karnataka. Me and Je colleges were reestablished, as well as libraries and printing houses.
Tashi Lhunpo was established in exile in 1972 in Bylakuppe in south India on the advice of the Fourteenth Dalai Lama.
Stakna is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Ladakh.  Ngawang Namgyel, a brother of King Sengge Namgyel, is said to have restored the monastery from a preexisting structure in the seventeenth century.

name_variants: Bardam, bar gdan gsang sngags chos gling ,
description: Bardan is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in the Zanskar region of Ladakh that was founded in the seventeenth century. It is affiliated with Stakna Monastery.

name_variants: Trikal Maitreya Buddha Vihara; Great Maitreya Temple
description: The Jamchen Lhakhang, also known by its English name of Maitreya Temple, was built at the Boudhanath Stūpa in 1985 by Chobgye Trichen.

name_variants: Riding; Rindeng; Rinchending, rin gding; rin chen sding ,
description: Rinding was a nunnery associated with Nalendra Monastery in Penyul, north of Lhasa. Kunzang Tendron, a sister of Chogye Trichen Rinpoche, served as abbess in the 1950s and increased the number of nuns from around thirty to around eighty, most of whom came from the surrounding nomadic regions.

Lo Gekar is a Sakya monastery in Mustang, Nepal. It is said to have been first established by Padmasambhava in the eighth century as one of the "demon taming" temples, although it is not included in lists of such temples. Sanggye Lingpa is said to have revealed treasure there. In the twentieth century it was renovated by the king of Mustang, Jampel Tenzin Dradul, and used as a retreat center by Chogye Trichen Rinpoche.

name_variants: New Buddha Mandir
description: Dharma Swami Buddha Vihara is a Sakya monastery in Lumbini, Nepal. It was built in the early 1970s by Chogye Trichen Rinpoche, and was the location of the first Sakya three-year retreat in exile. The original name of the monastery was New Buddha Mandir, changed to the current name in 1978.

name_variants: Lo Tsarang Tubten Shedrub Dargye Ling, glo rtsa rang thub bstan bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling; rtsa brang ,
description: Tsarang is a Sakya monastery in Mustang, Nepal.

name_variants: Namgyel Chode Tubten Dargye Ling, rnam rgyal chos sde thub bstan dar rgyas gling,
description: Namgye Chode is a Sakya monastery in Mustang. It was founded in the thirteenth century, and restored in 1436-37 by Ngorchen Kunga Zangpo, who provided it with a new monastic code and its current name of Tubten Dargye Ling.

wylie_name: thang stong rgyal po lha khang
name_variants: Tanggyel Lhakhang; Tangyel Lhakhang; Tangtong Gyelpo Temple, thang rgyal lha khang ,
description: The Tangyel Lhakhang, or Tangtong Gyelpo Temple, is a small temple in the center of the old town of Gonchen, the capital of Derge.

name_variants: Moncho Drakkar Tekchen Ling, smon chos brag dkar theg chen gling ,
description: Montang Chode is a Sakya monastery in Mustang, Nepal.

name_variants: Kak Chode Tubten Sampel Ling; Kagbeni; Kakbeni, bkag chos sde thub bstan bsam ’phel gling ,
description: Kak Chode is a Sakya monastery in Kagbeni village in Mustang, Nepal.

name_variants: Shedrub Dargye Ling, bshad sgrub dar rgyas gling ,
description: Gemi Shedrub Dargye Ling is a Sakya monastery in Mustang, Nepal.

name_variants: Dzong Chode Shedrub Dargye Ling, rdzong chos sde bshad sgrub chos ’phel gling ,
description: Dzong Chode Shedrub Dargye Ling is a Sakya monastery in Muktinath, Nepal.

name_variants: bes ri bla chen dgon pa; dre'u ri bla chen dgon pa, 白日拉庆寺,
description: Beru Lachen is a Sakya monastery in Nangchen, Kham. Originally a Barom Kagyu monastery, it was converted in the thirteenth century and eventually became a branch of Nalendra Monastery.

name_variants: Jangchub Choling, byang chub chos gling, 尕拉寺/嘎寺,
description: Gar Gon is a Geluk monastery in Nangchen. It was established as a Drigung Kagyu monastery in the thirteenth century.

wylie_name: dkar mdzes bshad sgrub nor bu gling
name_variants: Kandze Monastery; Ganze,
description: Kandze Monastery, Shedrub Norbu Ling, was built in 1662 by Qosot Mongols who then controlled the region. It was once the largest monastery in Kham after Chamdo.

wylie_name: yar klung bkra shis chos sde
description: Yarlung Tashi Chode is a Sakya monastery in the Yarlung valley.

name_variants: Tsechen Tenpal Gatsal Shedup Chokhorling,
description: Sakya Centre is the Indian seat of the Sakya Trizin. It was established in 1964 by the Firty-First Sakya Trizin.
Shakya Shei-Drub Ling is a Sakya dharma center in Cambridge, Massachusettes. It was established in 1980 by Dezhung Rinpoche.
Dzogchen Monastery India was established in 1992 in Kollegal, South India. It is the seat of the Seventh Dzogchen Rinpoche.

The Tartse Labrang is one of the four main lama palaces of Ngor Monastery. It was established in the late fifteenth or early sixteenth century, and was controlled by the Drangti family beginning in the late sixteenth century.

name_variants: Penkhang Labrang, phan khang bla brang,
description: Pende Labrang is one of the four main lama palaces of Ngor Monastery. It appears to have originated as a branch of the Luding Labrang some time in the early eighteenth century, and made independent by the thirty-fourth abbot of Ngor, Pelden Chokyong.
The Khangsar Labrang is one of the four main lama palaces of Ngor Monastery. It was like established in the mid-seventeenth century by Sonam Gyatso, the twenty-first abbot of Ngor.
Luding Labrang is one of the four main lama palaces of Ngor Monastery. It was probably established by Jampa Kunga Tashi, the fourteenth abbot of Ngor, in the sixteenth century.
Yutsa is a Geluk monastery in Amdo.

wylie_name: bkra shis chos sdings kyi par khang
description: Ditsa Parkhang is the printing house of Ditsa Tashi Choding monastery in Amdo.
Pangshar is a Sakya monastery to the north of Jyekundo. It was established in 1265 by Pakpa Lodro Gyeltsen.

name_variants: Dhonthog, Dongtok Chode Rigdrol Puntsok Ling, gdon thog chos sde rig grol phun tshogs gling,
description: Dongtok is a Sakya monastery in Kandze, Kham. It was founded in 1587 by the Dongtok chieftain Sonam Sengge. It was the seat of Dhongthog Rinpoche.

wylie_name: d+hI phu dgon thub bstan dge legs gter mdzod gling
name_variants: mkhar mda' dgon,
description: Diphu Monastery in the Ngawa region of southern Amdo is the largest branch of Nalendra Monastery in eastern Tibet.

name_variants: 腰色寺,
description: Yakze is a Nyingma monastery outside of Manigango in the Yilhung valley, Kham, a branch of Dzogchen Monastery. It was established in 1687 under the instructions of Pema Rigdzin by his disciple Sanggye Gyatso. Sonam Namgyel famously attained rainbow body there in 1952.
Khyungtak is a meditation hermitage in Derge. It was opened in the early twentieth century by Gyarong Khandro Dechen Wangmo.
Tenpel is a Drukpa Kagyu monastery in Tromtar, Kham.
Bumsar is a Geluk monastery in the Sershul region of Kham.
Pema Osel Ling is a retreat center near Santa Cruz, California. It was established by Tharchin Rinpoche and follows the Dudjom Tersar tradition.
Rigdzin Gatsel is a dharma center in near Williams, Oregon, that was established in the early 1980s by Chagdud Tulku.
Ati Ling is a dharma center in Cazadero, California. It was established in 1987 by Chagdud Tulku and is the current seat of his son, Tulku Jigme Tromge.
Rigdzin Ling is a dharma center in Junction City, California. It was established by Chagdud Tulku in 1988.
Khadro Ling is a dharma center in Três Coroas, Brazil. It was established in 1995 by Chagdud Tulku.
Richung was a hermitage in Tsang where Jangsel Choje and later his daughter Kunden Rema both did retreat.
Sarwahai was a hermitage in Drongdzong, Gyarong, of Do Khyentse and his family.
Do Dzong was a hermitage in Gyarong of Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje.
Nechen Pema was a hermitage of Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje and his family.
Zhakdra Turquoise Lake is a hermitage site of Do Khyentse Yeshe Dorje and his family.
Pelri is a Nyingma monastery in Gyarong that dates back to the thirteenth century.
Tarpa Tse is a hermitage associated with Dartang Monastery.

wylie_name: kun bzang 'od gsal dpal yul byang chub chos gling
description: Kunzang Odsal Palyul Changchub Choling is a Nyingma dharma center in Poolesville, Maryland. Jetsuna Akhon Lhamo, a student of Penor Rinpoche, opened it in the mid 1980s.

The Palyul Retreat Center in McDonough, New York is the main seat of Penor Rinpoche in North America, established in 1998 by Khenpo Tsewang Gyatso. Penor Rinpoche personally presided over an annual Dzogchen retreat there.

name_variants: Dakpo Shedrubling,
description: Dakpo Shedrub Ling is a Geluk monastery in Naggar, Himachal Pradesh, India.

wylie_name: bras spungs sgo mang grwa tshang
description: Drepung Gomang College in Karnattaka is the Indian branch of Drepung Gomang, Tibet.

name_variants: Setenling Gompa,
description: Se Monastery is a Jonang monastery in Ngawa.

wylie_name: rtag brtan phun tshogs chos gling
description: Takten Puntsok Choling is a Jonang monastery in Simla, India, the seat of the Ninth Jebtsundampa. The Fourteenth Dalai Lama gave him the monastery a year after naming him the head of the Jonang tradition in 1997. The monastery had originally been established by a Lama Jinpa Gyatso in 1962 and given to the Dalai Lama in 1990.

name_variants: Lingshet,
description: Lingshed is a Geluk monastery in Ladakh.
The Nyingma Institute is a study and practice center in Berkeley, California. Tarthang Tulku established it in 1972.
Yeshe Nyingpo is a dharma center in New York City. Dudjom Rinpoche established it in 1976 as his main seat in North America.
Garchen Buddhist Institute is a Drigung Kagyu study and practice center in Arizona. The Eighth Garchen Rinpoche established it in 1997.
Orgyen Chö Dzong is a retreat center in Greenville, New York, associated with Yeshe Nyingpo in New York City. Dudjom Rinpoche established it in 1980.

The Vajrapani Institute for Wisdom Culture is a dharma center in Boulder Creek, California. Lama Yeshe and Lama Zopa first acquired land in 1977, and the first buildings were completed in 1982. Lama Yeshe passed away there in 1984.
Rigdzin Gatsel Ling is a hermitage in Kongpo that was built by Dudjom Rinpoche in the 1940s for the personal use of him and his wife, Tseten Yudron.
Lama Ling is a center in Kongpo for lay practitioners that was built in the 1940s by Dudjom Rinpoche.
Jangkar is a Nyingma monastery in Batang, Kham. It was founded in the fourteenth century.
Yaso is a branch monastery of Katok in southern Kham.
Nego is a branch monastery of Katok in Gandze.

wylie_name: theg chen chos gling gtsug lag khang
name_variants: Dalai Lama Temple, Thekchen Choeling,
description: Tekchen Choling is a temple located in Dharamsala, India that is connected to Namgyal Monastery and the private residence of the Dalai Lama. It was founded in 1969. Among the many statues and images in the temple is a statue of Avalokitesvara that was contstructed around fragments of the head section of a seventh century statue rescued from the Lhasa Tsuklakhang in Tibet in the 1960s.

name_variants: Züün Khüree Dashchoilin Monastery, Дашчойлин хийд,
description: Dashchoilin is a monastery located in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia.  Founded in 1990, it is comprised of three temples, a library and a monastic college. It is known for it annual tsam (Tib. 'cham) dance festival, which was revived based on pre-communist tsam rituals.

wylie_name: dga' ldan bshad sgrub chos 'khor gling
name_variants: Геден Шеддуп Чойкорлинг,
description: Geden Sheddup Choikhorling (Ganden Shedrub Chokhorling) is a Geluk monastery in Elista, Kalmykia. Founded in 1996, it was the first monastery established after the Soviet repression of Buddhism.

name_variants: Зеленая Тара,
description: Green Tara Center is a Geluk Buddhist center located in Ulan Ude, Buryatia.

name_variants: Московский буддийский Центр Ламы Цонкапы,
description: The Tsongkhapa Moscow Buddhist Center is a Geluk dharma center located in Moscow, Russia. It was founded in 1996 by students of Geshe Jampa Trinle. It is one of the older Buddhist centers in Moscow.

name_variants: Ngodrub Choling, dngos grub chos gling,
description: Lachen is a Nyingma monastery in Lachen, Sikkim.

Thangu is a Nyingma monastery in northern Sikkim. It was established in the early eighteenth century on the instructions of a local lama named Pema Wobar, the father of the Third Karma Tulku. The monastery now operates as a branch of Lachen Monastery .

Tashi Gomang Stupa in Crestone, Colorado, was consecrated in 1996 on land given to the Sixteenth Karmapa during his 1980 North American tour. It is among many Tibetan Buddhist centers and monuments located in Crestone.
Deer Park Buddhist Center grew out of Geshe Sopa's Ganden Mahayana Center, which was founded in 1976. The center moved from Geshe Sopa's home to nearby Oregon, Wisconsin, in 1981.
